questions.text: What is the primary function of the muscle attached at the marked point in the given image? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Depression

 

The marked point in the image indicates the lateral pterygoid plate of the sphenoid bone. The muscle attached to the lateral surface of the lateral pterygoid plate is the lateral pterygoid muscle.

 

The lateral pterygoid muscle is one of the four muscles of mastication and has a unique set of actions that can be remembered using the mnemonic "DPS" (Delhi Public School):

 

  • D - Depression (opening the jaw)
  • P - Protraction (moving jaw forward)
  • S - Side-to-side movement (lateral excursion)

 

The lateral pterygoid muscle originates from the lateral surface of the lateral pterygoid plate and inserts into the pterygoid fovea on the neck of the mandible and the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint. When it contracts, it pulls the mandible forward and downward, causing depression of the jaw.

 

Among the muscles of mastication, the lateral pterygoid is the only muscle that depresses the jaw. While the main depressors of the jaw are the digastric muscle and geniohyoid muscle, among the four muscles of mastication (masseter, temporalis, medial pterygoid, and lateral pterygoid), only the lateral pterygoid causes depression.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elevation: This is incorrect. Elevation of the jaw (closing the mouth) is performed by the masseter, temporalis, and medial pterygoid muscles. The lateral pterygoid does not elevate the jaw; instead, it depresses it.

 

Option C. Retraction: This is incorrect. Retraction of the jaw (pulling the jaw backward) is specifically performed by the posterior oblique fibers of the temporalis muscle. The temporalis is the only muscle among the muscles of mastication that causes retraction. The lateral pterygoid actually causes protraction (opposite of retraction).

 

Option D. Rotation: This is incorrect as stated. While the lateral pterygoid does contribute to side-to-side movements when working with the contralateral medial and lateral pterygoid muscles, "rotation" is not the primary or most accurate description of its action. The more precise actions are depression and protraction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral pterygoid muscle is the only muscle of mastication that depresses the jaw, and its actions can be remembered by the mnemonic "DPS" - Depression, Protraction, and Side-to-side movement.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is scheduled for cleft lip repair. During the surgical procedure, which of the following muscles is primarily corrected? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Orbicularis oris

 

In cleft lip surgery, the orbicularis oris muscle is the primary muscle that needs to be corrected and reconstructed.

 

The orbicularis oris is a circular muscle that surrounds the mouth opening and forms the muscular basis of the lips. It is responsible for:

 

  • Closing and pursing the lips
  • Speech articulation
  • Facial expressions involving lip movement
  • Maintaining oral competence (keeping the mouth closed)

 

In cleft lip, there is a congenital defect where the tissues of the upper lip fail to fuse properly during embryonic development. This results in:

 

  • Discontinuity of the orbicularis oris muscle across the cleft
  • Loss of the normal circular arrangement of muscle fibers
  • Impaired lip function and appearance

 

During cleft lip repair surgery, the primary goal is to:

 

  1. Reconstruct the orbicularis oris muscle by suturing the separated muscle segments together
  2. Restore the normal circular arrangement of muscle fibers
  3. Re-establish proper muscle function for lip closure and movement
  4. Create a functional and aesthetically pleasing lip

 

The surgical technique involves carefully identifying the disrupted muscle fibers on both sides of the cleft and suturing them together in layers to restore the normal anatomy and function of the orbicularis oris muscle.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Levator labii superioris: This is incorrect. The levator labii superioris elevates the upper lip and is involved in facial expressions (particularly the "sad" expression). While it may be involved in the surgical repair, it is not the primary muscle that is corrected in cleft lip surgery. The main issue is the discontinuity of the orbicularis oris.

 

Option C. Orbicularis oculi: This is incorrect. The orbicularis oculi is the circular muscle around the eye orbit responsible for closing the eyelids and blinking. It has no relationship to cleft lip pathology or repair, as cleft lip involves the oral region, not the orbital region.

 

Option D. Masseter: This is incorrect. The masseter is one of the four muscles of mastication responsible for elevating the jaw (closing the mouth). It is not involved in cleft lip pathology or surgical repair, as it is located in the cheek region and functions in jaw movement rather than lip formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The orbicularis oris muscle is the primary muscle corrected in cleft lip surgery, as cleft lip involves discontinuity of this circular muscle around the mouth, and surgical repair focuses on reconstructing the muscle to restore normal lip function and appearance.

questions.text: Olfactory sensation is transmitted by all of the following nerves, except: (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypoglossal nerve

 

The hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) is the correct answer because it is a purely motor nerve with no sensory function. It supplies the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue and has no role in olfactory sensation.

 

Other Options:

 

The other 3 nerves mentioned, have accessory roles in olfaction:

 

Option A. Trigeminal nerve (CN V): Detects irritants, temperature, and pressure in the nasal cavity through its general sensory function, contributing to the overall odor perception. This "trigeminal component" of smell helps in the overall perception of odors and explains why some strong odors can cause irritation.

 

Option B. Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX): Carries taste sensation from the posterior 1/3 of the tongue, and taste pathways integrate with olfactory pathways, and this nerve plays a supporting role in overall flavor perception, which combines taste and smell.

 

Option D. Vagus nerve (CN X): Carries taste sensation from the posterior-most part of the tongue and pharyngeal region, also contributing to smell-taste integration, that creates our overall sense of flavor.

 

Primary vs. Accessory olfactory components:

 

  • Primary: Olfactory nerve (CN I) - true smell sensation
  • Accessory: Trigeminal component (irritation, temperature), taste components (CN IX, X) that integrate with smell

 

The integration between taste and smell pathways explains why loss of taste (ageusia) often affects the perception of smell and vice versa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hypoglossal nerve is purely motor and supplies tongue muscles, having no sensory function or role in olfaction, unlike other cranial nerves that have accessory roles in smell perception through general sensation or taste integration.

 

Note:

 

  • The XII nerve is purely motor, while all other cranial nerves are mixed.
  • The taste pathway also contributes to olfactory sensation.
  • The VII, IX, X, and V nerves play a supporting role in the sense of smell, separate from the primary olfactory nerve.
  • While the olfactory nerve is responsible for detecting odors, the trigeminal nerve senses irritants, temperature, and pressure within the nasal cavity, enhancing overall odor perception.

questions.text: Pain originating from the marked structure is typically referred to which of the following locations? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Back of neck

 

The marked structure in the image appears to be the torcula herophili (confluence of sinuses), located in the posterior cranial fossa. This is the point where major venous sinuses converge, including the superior sagittal sinus, occipital sinus, transverse sinus, and straight sinus.

 

The nerve supply of the meninges varies according to the cranial fossa:

 

Posterior cranial fossa innervation:

 

  • Vagus nerve (CN X): meningeal branches
  • Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX): meningeal branches
  • Upper cervical spinal nerves (C1, C2, C3): dorsal rami

 

The pain from structures in the posterior cranial fossa follows the principle of referred pain, where pain is felt along the distribution of the nerves supplying the affected area. Since the posterior cranial fossa is innervated by upper cervical spinal nerves (C1-C3), pain from this region is characteristically referred to the back of the neck.

 

This is clinically relevant in conditions such as:

 

  • Posterior fossa tumors
  • Cerebellar lesions
  • Venous sinus thrombosis
  • Increased intracranial pressure affecting posterior structures

 

The cervical spinal nerves (C1-C3) that supply the posterior cranial fossa also innervate the neck musculature and skin, explaining the referred pain pattern to the back of the neck.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ear: This is incorrect. Ear pain is typically associated with structures innervated by the trigeminal nerve (particularly V3), facial nerve, or glossopharyngeal nerve, but not specifically from posterior cranial fossa pathology. The ear region would be more associated with middle cranial fossa or temporal region pathology.

 

Option C. Vertex: This is incorrect. Vertex pain is typically associated with anterior and middle cranial fossa pathology, as this region is primarily innervated by branches of the trigeminal nerve (V1 - ophthalmic division). The vertex is not in the distribution of the nerves supplying the posterior cranial fossa.

 

Option D. Shoulder: This is incorrect. Shoulder pain is not associated with posterior cranial fossa pathology. Shoulder pain can be referred from diaphragmatic irritation (phrenic nerve - C3,4,5) or cervical spine pathology, but not from intracranial posterior fossa structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pain from the posterior cranial fossa (including the torcula herophili region) is referred to the back of the neck due to innervation by upper cervical spinal nerves (C1-C3), which also supply the neck region.

 

Note:

 

  • Posterior fossa lesions or conditions can cause pain in the back of the head, neck, or even the occipital region. 
  • This is because the structures within the posterior fossa have a complex nervous innervation that can refer pain to these areas.

 

Anterior cranial fossa

 

  • Meningeal branches from the V1
  • Meningeal branches from the maxillary nerve V2

 

Middle cranial fossa

 

  • Meningeal branches of V1, V2, V3

 

Posterior cranial fossa

 

  • Sensory meningeal branches from the vagus nerve (CN X) and glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) supply the inferior surface of the tentorium and dura of the posterior fossa
  • Small sensory branches of the C1 to C3 dorsal rami supply around the foramen magnum .

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles are supplied by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve? (INICET MAY 2025)

  1. 3rd lumbrical
  2. 4th Dorsal interossei
  3. Opponens digiti minimi
  4. Flexor carpi ulnaris
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3

 

The ulnar nerve divides into superficial and deep branches as it enters the hand. The deep branch of the ulnar nerve is responsible for supplying most of the intrinsic muscles of the hand.

 

The deep branch of the ulnar nerve supplies multiple intrinsic muscles of the hand. Among the given options, 1, 2, and 3 are correctly supplied by the deep branch:

 

1. 3rd lumbrical: The lumbricals have a dual nerve supply pattern. The 1st and 2nd lumbricals (lateral two) are supplied by the median nerve, while the 3rd and 4th lumbricals (medial two) are supplied by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve. This follows the general rule that the ulnar nerve supplies muscles acting on the medial fingers.

 

2. 4th Dorsal interossei: All four dorsal interossei are supplied by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve. These muscles are responsible for finger abduction (DAB - Dorsal ABduct). The dorsal interossei are bipennate muscles that help spread the fingers apart from the middle finger.

 

3. Opponens digiti minimi: This muscle belongs to the hypothenar eminence group. All hypothenar muscles (abductor digiti minimi, flexor digiti minimi brevis, opponens digiti minimi) are supplied by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve. The opponens digiti minimi helps in opposing the little finger toward the thumb.

 

The ulnar nerve is known as the "musician's nerve" because it supplies most of the intrinsic hand muscles (15 out of 20 muscles). In the hand, only 5 muscles are supplied by the median nerve (thenar muscles except adductor pollicis, plus 1st and 2nd lumbricals), while the remaining muscles are supplied by the ulnar nerve through its deep branch.

 

Incorrect Option:

 

4. Flexor carpi ulnaris: This muscle is supplied by the superficial branch of the ulnar nerve, not the deep branch. The flexor carpi ulnaris is located in the forearm and receives its nerve supply before the ulnar nerve divides into superficial and deep branches at the wrist level. In the forearm, the ulnar nerve supplies only "one and a half muscles" - the flexor carpi ulnaris (completely) and the medial half of flexor digitorum profundus (making it a hybrid muscle, as its lateral half is supplied by the anterior interosseous nerve).

 

The key distinction is that the superficial branch of the ulnar nerve supplies muscles in the forearm and provides cutaneous innervation, while the deep branch specifically supplies the intrinsic muscles of the hand.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The deep branch of the ulnar nerve supplies the intrinsic muscles of the hand including: all hypothenar muscles, 3rd and 4th lumbricals, all palmar and dorsal interossei, and adductor pollicis (graveyard of ulnar nerve), while the flexor carpi ulnaris is supplied by the superficial branch of the ulnar nerve in the forearm.

choices.text: External rotation of hip/ Abduction of hip

questions.text: What is the primary action of the muscle attached to the area indicated by the arrow in the image given below? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) External rotation of hip/ Abduction of hip

 

The arrow in the image points to the attachment site of the gluteus maximus muscle on the sacrum. The gluteus maximus is the largest and most superficial muscle of the gluteal region.

 

Anatomical details of gluteus maximus:

 

  • Origin: Posterior gluteal line, area behind posterior gluteal line, outer lip of iliac crest (posterior 1/3rd), adjacent surfaces of sacrum and coccyx, and sacrotuberous ligament
  • Insertion: Gluteal tuberosity of femur (1/4th) and iliotibial tract (3/4th)
  • Nerve supply: Inferior gluteal nerve (L5, S1, S2)

 

Actions of gluteus maximus:

 

  1. Primary action: Extension at hip joint (chief extensor): helps in moving from sitting to standing position
  2. Secondary actions: 
    • External rotation of hip: due to its posterior placement and fiber direction
    • Abduction at hip: especially the upper fibers
    • Adduction at hip: especially the lower fibers

 

While extension at the hip would be the most accurate primary action, it is not listed among the options. Among the given choices, external rotation and abduction are both valid secondary actions of the gluteus maximus muscle.

 

The upper fibers of gluteus maximus, which attach more superiorly on the sacrum and iliac crest, particularly contribute to abduction of the hip. The muscle's position posterior to the hip joint axis makes it an effective external rotator of the femur.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial rotation of hip: This is incorrect. The gluteus maximus causes external rotation of the hip, not medial rotation. Its fiber direction and position posterior to the hip joint make it an external rotator.

 

Option C. Flexion at knee: This is incorrect. The gluteus maximus primarily acts on the hip joint. While some fibers insert into the iliotibial tract which crosses the knee, the primary action is not knee flexion. The muscle does not significantly contribute to knee flexion.

 

Option D. Extension at knee: This is incorrect. Although some fibers of gluteus maximus insert into the iliotibial tract which crosses the lateral aspect of the knee, the muscle does not significantly contribute to knee extension. The primary knee extensors are the quadriceps muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The gluteus maximus muscle, attached to the sacrum and other posterior pelvic structures, primarily extends the hip and secondarily performs external rotation and abduction of the hip joint.

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles are supplied by superficial peroneal nerve? (INICET MAY 2025)

 

  1. Peroneus brevis
  2. Peroneus longus
  3. Peroneus tertius
  4. Extensor hallucis longus
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2

 

The leg is divided into three compartments, each with its specific nerve supply. The lateral compartment of the leg contains only two muscles: peroneus longus and peroneus brevis. Both of these muscles are innervated by the superficial peroneal nerve.

 

The superficial peroneal nerve is the nerve of the lateral compartment and supplies:

 

  • Peroneus longus
  • Peroneus brevis

 

These muscles are responsible for eversion of the foot and play important roles in maintaining balance during walking and standing.

 

 

Incorrect Options:

 

Option 3: Peroneus tertius: This muscle belongs to the anterior compartment of the leg, not the lateral compartment. According to Grey's Anatomy 42nd edition (page 1418), peroneus tertius is supplied by the deep peroneal nerve, which is the nerve of the anterior compartment. This is a common source of confusion as the name suggests it belongs with the other peroneus muscles, but anatomically it functions with the anterior compartment muscles.

 

Option 4: Extensor hallucis longus: This muscle is located in the anterior compartment of the leg and is supplied by the deep peroneal nerve. It functions to extend the great toe and assist in dorsiflexion of the foot. The anterior compartment muscles include tibialis anterior, extensor digitorum longus, extensor hallucis longus, and peroneus tertius - all supplied by the deep peroneal nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The superficial peroneal nerve supplies only the two muscles of the lateral compartment of the leg: peroneus longus and peroneus brevis.

choices.text: 1-Undergoes hypertrophy on pulmonary stenosis, 2-Receives oxygenated blood, 3-Arises from left ventricle, 4- Lies to the right of ascending aorta
1-Receives oxygenated blood, 2- Undergoes hypertrophy on pulmonary stenosis, 3-Arises from left ventricle, 4- Lies to the right of ascending aorta
1-Receives oxygenated blood, 2- Undergoes hypertrophy on pulmonary stenosis, 3- Lies to the right of ascending aorta, 4-Arises from left ventricle
1-Receives oxygenated blood, 2- Arises from left ventricle, 3- Lies to the right of ascending aorta, 4- Undergoes hypertrophy on pulmonary stenosis

questions.text:
In the labeled transverse section of the thorax at the level of the heart shown below, match each numbered structure (1â€“4) with the appropriate anatomical or clinical description: (INICET MAY 2025)

 

 

  1. Undergoes hypertrophy on pulmonary stenosis
  2. Receives oxygenated blood
  3. Arises from left ventricle
  4. Lies to the right of ascending aorta
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-Undergoes hypertrophy on pulmonary stenosis, 2-Receives oxygenated blood, 3-Arises from left ventricle, 4- Lies to the right of ascending aorta

 

This is a transverse section of the thorax at the cardiac level. The structures can be identified as follows:

 

Structure 1. Right Ventricle: Located anteriorly, this chamber undergoes hypertrophy in pulmonary stenosis. In conditions like Tetralogy of Fallot, pulmonary stenosis causes narrowing of the pulmonary valve, forcing the right ventricle to work harder and subsequently hypertrophy. The right ventricle forms the anterior surface of the heart and most of the sternocostal surface.

 

Structure 2. Left Ventricle: This chamber receives oxygenated blood from the left atrium, which collects it from the lungs via pulmonary veins. The left ventricle has the thickest muscular wall and forms the apex of the heart. It pumps oxygenated blood to the systemic circulation through the aorta.

 

Structure 3. Ascending Aorta: This great vessel arises from the left ventricle. The ascending aorta originates from the left ventricular outflow tract and carries oxygenated blood to the systemic circulation. It has three aortic sinuses (anterior, left posterior, and right posterior) from which the coronary arteries arise.

 

Structure 4. Right Atrium: This chamber lies to the right of the ascending aorta and forms the right border of the heart. The right atrium receives deoxygenated blood from the superior and inferior vena cavae and coronary sinus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a transverse section of the thorax: Right ventricle (anterior) undergoes hypertrophy in pulmonary stenosis, left ventricle receives oxygenated blood, ascending aorta arises from left ventricle, and right atrium lies to the right of ascending aorta.

questions.text: Which of the following is not the boundary of hepatocystic triangle? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cystic artery

 

The hepatocystic triangle (also called hepatobiliary triangle) is an important surgical landmark used during cholecystectomy and other biliary procedures. The boundaries of the hepatocystic triangle are:

 

  • Superior border (base): Inferior border of the liver
  • Right border: Cystic duct
  • Left border: Common hepatic duct

 

The cystic artery is not a boundary of the hepatocystic triangle but rather passes through it as content. The cystic artery typically runs within this triangular space and is an important structure that needs to be identified and ligated during cholecystectomy.

 

This triangle is formed between the liver (hepato) and the gallbladder/biliary apparatus (cystic), creating a triangular space that contains important structures including the cystic artery and lymph nodes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Common hepatic duct: This forms the left border of the hepatocystic triangle. The common hepatic duct is formed by the union of right and left hepatic ducts and later joins with the cystic duct to form the common bile duct.

 

Option B. Inferior border of liver: This forms the superior border (base) of the hepatocystic triangle. The sharp inferior border of the liver provides the upper boundary of this important surgical triangle.

 

Option C. Cystic duct: This forms the right border of the hepatocystic triangle. The cystic duct connects the gallbladder to the biliary system and contains the spiral valve of Heister.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hepatocystic triangle has three boundaries: inferior border of liver (superior), cystic duct (right), and common hepatic duct (left). The cystic artery is content within the triangle, not a boundary.

choices.text: A-Prostate, B-Ureter, C-Vas deferens, D-Seminal vesicle
A-Vas deferens, B-Ureter, C-Prostate, D-Seminal vesicle
A-Ureter, B-Vas deferens, C-Seminal vesicle, D-Prostate
A-Vas deferens, B-Ureter, C-Prostate, D-Seminal vesicle

questions.text: Match the following in the given image below: (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) . A-Ureter, B-Vas deferens, C-Seminal vesicle, D-Prostate 

 

This cadaveric image shows the posterior surface of the urinary bladder with its related structures. The identification of each labeled structure is:

 

Structure A. Ureter: These are the paired muscular tubes that transport urine from the kidneys to the bladder. The ureters enter the bladder posterolaterally and have three natural constrictions along their course. They maintain close anatomical relationships with surrounding pelvic structures.

 

Structure B. Vas deferens/Ductus deferens: This is the muscular tube that transports sperm from the epididymis. The vas deferens has a thick muscular wall and travels from the scrotum through the inguinal canal, crosses over the ureter, and approaches the bladder posteriorly where it dilates to form the ampulla.

 

Structure C. Seminal vesicle: These are paired accessory glands that appear as lobulated, glandular structures posterior to the bladder. They produce seminal fluid that contributes to semen formation. The seminal vesicles unite with the ampullae of the vas deferens to form the ejaculatory ducts.

 

Structure D. Prostate gland: This is located at the neck of the bladder and surrounds the prostatic urethra. The prostate gland produces prostatic fluid and contains the openings of the ejaculatory ducts formed by the union of vas deferens and seminal vesicles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In posterior view of male urogenital anatomy: ureters enter bladder posterolaterally, vas deferens approaches bladder posteriorly, seminal vesicles are lobulated glands posterior to bladder, and prostate gland surrounds the bladder neck.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure from the histological slide given below? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Terminal bronchus

 

This histological image shows a section of lung tissue displaying various components of the respiratory pathway. The marked structure represents a terminal bronchiole (terminal bronchus), which is characterized by its relatively thick muscular wall compared to the surrounding structures.

 

The respiratory pathway follows a hierarchical organization: primary

 bronchus â†’ secondary bronchus â†’ tertiary bronchus (supplying bronchopulmonary segments) â†’ terminal bronchioles â†’ respiratory bronchioles â†’ alveolar ducts â†’ alveolar sacs â†’ alveoli.

 

Terminal bronchioles are the final conducting airways before the respiratory zone begins. They are distinguished by:

 

  • Thick muscular walls with smooth muscle
  • No gas exchange occurs at this level
  • They divide to form respiratory bronchioles where gas exchange begins
  • Larger caliber compared to respiratory bronchioles

 

The marked structure shows the characteristic thick-walled appearance of a terminal bronchiole, distinguishing it from the thinner-walled respiratory bronchioles and alveolar structures visible in the surrounding tissue.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory bronchus: These are thin-walled structures where gas exchange begins. They have alveolar outpouchings in their walls and appear much thinner than the marked structure. Respiratory bronchioles can be seen as the thinner-walled structures with small pouches (alveolar openings) in the image.

 

Option B. Bronchus: Larger bronchi have much thicker walls with cartilage support and are considerably larger in diameter than the marked structure. The marked structure is too small and lacks the cartilaginous framework characteristic of bronchi.

 

Option D. Alveoli: These are the thin-walled air sacs visible throughout the image as large, clear spaces. Alveoli are the sites of gas exchange and have extremely thin walls (respiratory membrane). The marked structure is clearly much thicker-walled and tubular compared to the spherical, thin-walled alveoli.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Terminal bronchioles are thick-walled conducting airways that mark the end of the conducting zone and precede the respiratory zone where gas exchange begins in respiratory bronchioles.

questions.text: In the histological section shown, how do the cells in the highlighted cluster most commonly exert their influence on neighboring pancreatic cells? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Paracrine effect

 

The marked cluster of cells represents the Islets of Langerhans within pancreatic tissue. The histological image shows the characteristic appearance of pancreatic parenchyma with dark eosinophilic areas representing serous acinar cells (exocrine pancreas) and lighter, less eosinophilic areas representing the islets of Langerhans (endocrine pancreas).

 

The islets of Langerhans contain different cell types including alpha cells (secreting glucagon), beta cells (secreting insulin), delta cells (secreting somatostatin), and other endocrine cells. These cells communicate through paracrine signaling, where secreted hormones affect nearby cells within the same islet or adjacent islets.

 

Paracrine signaling mechanism:

 

  • Para means "surrounding" or "nearby"
  • Cells release signaling molecules that act on neighboring cells in close proximity
  • For example: Beta cells secrete insulin which can affect nearby alpha cells, and alpha cells secrete glucagon which can influence beta cell function
  • This local communication helps coordinate hormonal responses and maintain glucose homeostasis
  • The effect occurs without the hormone entering systemic circulation

 

Paracrine literally means affecting surrounding cells, which is exactly what occurs in pancreatic islets.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Portal vasculature: While pancreatic islets have rich vascularization, the question specifically asks about how the cluster of cells affects nearby cells. Portal vasculature refers to a specialized circulatory system, not the mechanism of cellular communication between neighboring endocrine cells.

 

Option C. Transformation from epithelial to mesothelial: This refers to a pathological process where epithelial cells change their phenotype to become mesothelial cells, typically seen in certain disease processes. This is not relevant to normal islet cell function and communication.

 

Option D. Nerve mediated: While the pancreas receives autonomic innervation that can influence hormone secretion, the direct cell-to-cell communication within islets occurs primarily through paracrine mechanisms rather than neural pathways. Neural control is more of a systemic regulatory mechanism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pancreatic islets of Langerhans communicate through paracrine signaling, where hormones secreted by one cell type (e.g., insulin from beta cells, glucagon from alpha cells) directly affect neighboring cells within the same islet to coordinate endocrine function and glucose homeostasis.

questions.text:
In a 90 kg man following a meal, which of the following enzymes or intermediates is most likely activated to promote anabolic processes contributing to weight gain? (INICET MAY 2025)

 

  1. Malonyl CoA
  2. Acetyl CoA carboxylase
  3. Mitochondrial carnitine transporter
  4. Tricarboxylate transporter (citrate)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4 

 

In the fed state after eating, excess carbohydrates undergo conversion to fat for storage, leading to weight gain. This process involves several key enzymes and intermediates:

 

Option 1. Malonyl CoA: This is the key intermediate formed during fatty acid synthesis. When a person is in the fed state, approximately 50% of ingested carbohydrates are stored, with 40% being converted to triacylglycerol (fat). Acetyl CoA carboxylase converts acetyl CoA to malonyl CoA, which is the committed step in fatty acid synthesis. Malonyl CoA serves as the building block for fatty acid chain elongation, making it essential for fat formation and weight gain.

 

Option 2. Acetyl CoA carboxylase: This is the rate-limiting enzyme for fatty acid synthesis and is highly active during the fed state. It catalyzes the carboxylation of acetyl CoA to form malonyl CoA using ATP, biotin as cofactor, and COâ‚‚. Since this enzyme controls the first committed step of fatty acid synthesis, its activation directly correlates with increased fat production and subsequent weight gain.

 

Option 4. Tricarboxylate transporter/Citrate shuttle: When cellular energy requirements are fulfilled, excess acetyl CoA cannot directly cross the mitochondrial membrane. The citrate shuttle becomes active to transport acetyl CoA from mitochondria to cytosol. Acetyl CoA combines with oxaloacetate to form citrate, which exits the mitochondria. In the cytosol, citrate is cleaved back to acetyl CoA and oxaloacetate, providing substrate for fatty acid synthesis.

 

Incorrect Option: 

 

Option 3. Mitochondrial carnitine transporter (CPT-1): This option is incorrect. The mitochondrial carnitine transporter, specifically carnitine palmitoyltransferase-1 (CPT-1), is actually inhibited during the fed state and fatty acid synthesis. Malonyl CoA, which is produced during fatty acid synthesis, acts as a direct inhibitor of CPT-1. This inhibition prevents fatty acids from entering mitochondria for beta-oxidation, ensuring that fatty acid synthesis and beta-oxidation (opposing pathways) do not occur simultaneously. This reciprocal regulation prevents futile cycling and ensures efficient fat storage during the fed state.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the fed state, fatty acid synthesis is promoted through activation of acetyl CoA carboxylase (rate-limiting enzyme), production of malonyl CoA (key intermediate), and operation of the citrate shuttle, while simultaneously inhibiting CPT-1 to prevent beta-oxidation and ensure efficient fat storage for weight gain.

questions.text: Which of the following syndrome is not an aneuploidy?  (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bloom Syndrome 

 

Aneuploidy refers to an abnormal number of chromosomes, specifically trisomy (extra chromosome) or monosomy (missing chromosome). Three of the given options represent classic examples of aneuploidy: 

 

  • Down syndrome
  • Patau syndrome
  • Klinefelter syndrome

 

Bloom syndrome is fundamentally different as it does not involve abnormal chromosome numbers. Instead, it results from defective DNA repair mechanisms, specifically homologous recombination repair. This leads to chromosomal instability and increased cancer susceptibility, but the chromosome number remains normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Down syndrome: This is INCORRECT to choose because Down syndrome is a classic example of autosomal aneuploidy (Trisomy 21). It occurs due to nondisjunction during meiosis, resulting in an extra chromosome 21.

 

Option B. Patau syndrome: This is INCORRECT to choose because Patau syndrome represents Trisomy 13, another form of autosomal aneuploidy. It is associated with severe intellectual disability and multiple congenital anomalies.

 

Option C. Klinefelter syndrome: This is INCORRECT to choose because Klinefelter syndrome (XXY) is a sex chromosome aneuploidy. Affected individuals have 47 chromosomes instead of 46, with an extra X chromosome in males.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Aneuploidy involves abnormal chromosome numbers (trisomy or monosomy), while DNA repair disorders like Bloom syndrome maintain normal chromosome numbers but exhibit chromosomal instability due to defective homologous recombination repair mechanisms.

questions.text: After how many PCR cycles will the number of DNA copies be half of that obtained after 26 cycles? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 25

 

PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) follows exponential amplification where DNA copies double after each cycle. The mathematical relationship for PCR amplification is:

 

Number of DNA copies = 2â¿ (where n = number of cycles)

After 26 cycles: Number of copies = 2Â²â¶

To find half the copies of 26 cycles:

  • Half of 2Â²â¶ = (1/2) Ã— 2Â²â¶ = 2Â²âµ

 

Therefore, 2Â²âµ copies are produced after 25 cycles, which is exactly half the number of copies produced after 26 cycles.

 

Conceptual understanding: Since each PCR cycle doubles the number of copies, the number of copies in any given cycle is half of the next cycle. The quantity in the 25th cycle is half of the 26th cycle quantity, making this a straightforward mathematical relationship in exponential growth. This follows the pattern: 1â†’2â†’4â†’8, where each step is double the previous and half the next.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PCR amplification follows the formula 2â¿ where n is the number of cycles, and due to exponential doubling, the number of copies in cycle (n-1) is always exactly half the number of copies in cycle n.

choices.text: Lactic acid is produced despite presence of oxygen
Enhanced conversion of glucose to pyruvate
Increased pyruvate to acetyl CoA (High NADH/NAD ratio)

questions.text: The phenomenon of cancer cells consuming more glucose is due to? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lactic acid is produced despite presence of oxygen

 

The phenomenon described is the Warburg effect, a fundamental characteristic of cancer cell metabolism. Cancer cells exhibit metabolic reprogramming where they preferentially utilize glucose through aerobic glycolysis.

 

Key concept: In normal cells, aerobic glycolysis produces pyruvate as the end product, while anaerobic glycolysis produces lactate. However, in cancer cells, due to the Warburg effect, aerobic glycolysis produces lactate as the end product despite oxygen presence.

 

Metabolic reprogramming in cancer cells:

 

  • Pyruvate kinase exists in dimeric form with low catalytic activity (compared to tetrameric form in normal cells)
  • Pyruvate is diverted to lactate production rather than entering the TCA cycle
  • This provides rapid ATP generation (2 ATP per glucose) and biosynthetic precursors
  • Net gain is 2 ATP when lactate is produced, supporting rapid cell division

 

This inefficient but rapid glucose utilization explains why cancer cells consume significantly more glucose than normal cells, making them visible on PET scans using fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Enhanced conversion of glucose to pyruvate: This is INCORRECT. While glucose consumption is increased, the enhanced conversion is actually to lactate, not pyruvate. In cancer cells, pyruvate production may actually be reduced due to the dimeric form of pyruvate kinase having low catalytic activity compared to the tetrameric form in normal cells.

 

Option C. Increased pyruvate to acetyl CoA (High NADH/NAD ratio): This is INCORRECT. In cancer cells following the Warburg effect, pyruvate is NOT converted to acetyl CoA. Instead, pyruvate is diverted to lactate production. Since the pyruvate dehydrogenase reaction (which converts NAD to NADH) is bypassed, there is no increase in NADH/NAD ratio from this pathway.

 

Option D. Absence of Oxygen: This is INCORRECT. The Warburg effect specifically occurs in the PRESENCE of oxygen. If oxygen were truly absent, this would simply be normal anaerobic glycolysis, not the unique metabolic reprogramming characteristic of cancer cells. The term "aerobic glycolysis" emphasizes that oxygen is available but not utilized for complete oxidation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Warburg effect in cancer cells involves aerobic glycolysis producing lactate despite oxygen presence, representing metabolic reprogramming that supports rapid proliferation through increased glucose consumption and lactate production.

choices.text: Normal Direct bilirubin, Increased Indirect Bilirubin, Increased Urine urobilinogen
Increased Direct bilirubin, Normal Indirect Bilirubin, Absent Urine urobilinogen
Normal Direct bilirubin, Normal Indirect Bilirubin, Normal Urine urobilinogen
Decreased Direct bilirubin, Decreased Indirect Bilirubin, Increased Urine urobilinogen

questions.text: In glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency, which of the following statements is correct? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Normal Direct bilirubin, Increased Indirect bilirubin, Increased urine urobilinogen

 

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency leads to hemolytic anemia due to inadequate NADPH production, which is essential for maintaining reduced glutathione levels. This makes red blood cells vulnerable to oxidative damage and premature hemolysis.

 

Laboratory pattern in hemolytic anemia:

 

Normal direct (conjugated) bilirubin: The liver's conjugation function remains intact. Hepatocytes can still conjugate bilirubin normally, so direct bilirubin levels stay within normal limits.

 

Increased indirect (unconjugated) bilirubin: Due to increased red blood cell breakdown, large amounts of hemoglobin are released and converted to bilirubin. The rate of bilirubin production exceeds the liver's conjugation capacity, leading to accumulation of unconjugated bilirubin in blood.

 

Increased urine urobilinogen: The excess conjugated bilirubin that reaches the intestines is converted to urobilinogen by intestinal bacteria. Increased urobilinogen is then reabsorbed and appears in urine in elevated amounts.

 

This pattern is characteristic of hemolytic anemia and helps differentiate it from other types of jaundice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased direct bilirubin, Normal indirect bilirubin, Absent urine urobilinogen: This is INCORRECT. This pattern is characteristic of obstructive jaundice where bile flow is blocked (e.g., gallstones, pancreatic cancer). In obstructive jaundice, conjugated bilirubin cannot reach the intestines, so urobilinogen formation is absent. G6PD deficiency causes hemolysis, not biliary obstruction.

 

Option C. Normal direct bilirubin, Normal indirect bilirubin, Normal urine urobilinogen: This is INCORRECT. This represents a normal bilirubin profile with no evidence of hemolysis. G6PD deficiency with hemolytic anemia will always show elevated bilirubin levels due to increased red blood cell destruction.

 

Option D. Decreased direct bilirubin, Decreased indirect bilirubin, Increased urine urobilinogen: This is INCORRECT. Hemolytic anemia never causes decreased bilirubin levels. The increased hemolysis always leads to elevated bilirubin production. Additionally, decreased bilirubin with increased urobilinogen is not a recognized clinical pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemolytic anemia (including G6PD deficiency) produces a characteristic pattern of normal direct bilirubin, increased indirect bilirubin, and increased urine urobilinogen, distinguishing it from obstructive and hepatocellular jaundice patterns.

questions.text: In the given glycine titration curve, calculate or identify the pH at which glycine predominantly exists in its zwitterionic form? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6

 

The zwitterion form of an amino acid exists at the isoelectric point (pI), which is the pH at which the net charge on the molecule is zero. At this point, the amino acid has equal positive and negative charges.

Calculation for isoelectric point: For amino acids with two ionizable groups: 

 

pI = (pK1 + pK2) Ã· 2

 

From the titration curve:

 

  • pK1 = 2.3 (carboxyl group ionization)
  • pK2 = 9.6 (amino group ionization)
  • pI = (2.3 + 9.6) Ã· 2 = 11.9 Ã· 2 = 5.95 â‰ˆ 6.0

 

Understanding zwitterion:

 

  • At low pH: Amino acid is positively charged (both groups protonated)
  • At pI (pH 6): Zwitterion form with +NH3 and -COO groups (zero net charge)
  • At high pH: Amino acid is negatively charged (both groups deprotonated)

 

Clinical significance: Proteins are least soluble and precipitate most readily at their isoelectric point, which is important for protein purification and separation techniques.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The isoelectric point (pI) of amino acids with two ionizable groups is calculated as (pK1 + pK2) Ã· 2, representing the pH where the molecule exists as a zwitterion with zero net charge and minimum solubility.

questions.text: A patient presents with hepatosplenomegaly and a cherry-red spot on the macula. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for this clinical picture? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sphingomyelinase

 

This clinical presentation is pathognomonic for Niemann-Pick disease, which results from sphingomyelinase deficiency. The combination of hepatosplenomegaly and cherry red spot at macula is a classic diagnostic triad.

 

Key diagnostic features of Niemann-Pick disease:

 

  • Hepatosplenomegaly: Massive enlargement of liver and spleen due to accumulation of sphingomyelin in reticuloendothelial cells (Kupffer cells, splenic macrophages)
  • Cherry red spot at macula: Results from sphingomyelin accumulation in retinal ganglion cells, creating contrast with the red choroidal background visible through the thin foveal area
  • Neurological symptoms: Progressive neurodegeneration due to sphingomyelin storage in neural tissue

 

Pathophysiology: Sphingomyelinase deficiency leads to impaired breakdown of sphingomyelin, causing its accumulation in lysosomes of various cell types, particularly affecting the reticuloendothelial system and nervous system.

 

Mnemonic: "Pick" sounds like "big" - referring to the big liver and spleen (hepatosplenomegaly) characteristic of this condition.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hexosaminidase A: This is incorrect. Hexosaminidase A deficiency causes Tay-Sachs disease, which presents with cherry red spots and severe neurological symptoms but does NOT cause hepatosplenomegaly. The mnemonic "T for Tiny organs" helps remember that Tay-Sachs has no organomegaly, making it easily distinguishable from Niemann-Pick disease.

 

Option C. Glucose 6 phosphatase: This is incorrect. Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency causes von Gierke disease (Type I glycogen storage disease), which presents with hepatomegaly, severe fasting hypoglycemia, kidney enlargement, lactic acidosis, increased uric acid, and elevated triglycerides and cholesterol. However, it does not cause cherry red spots or splenomegaly.

 

Option D. Galactocerebrosidase: This is incorrect. Galactocerebrosidase deficiency causes Krabbe disease, which primarily affects the central and peripheral nervous systems with demyelination. It does not typically present with hepatosplenomegaly or cherry red spots at the macula.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Niemann-Pick disease (sphingomyelinase deficiency) presents with the classic triad of hepatosplenomegaly, cherry red spots at macula, and neurological symptoms, distinguishing it from Tay-Sachs disease which lacks organomegaly.

 

Lysosomal Storage Diseases and Associated Enzyme Deficiencies

questions.text: Carbon monoxide and cyanide cause death primarily due to their interference with which of the following cellular processes? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cytochrome oxidase

 

Both carbon monoxide (CO) and cyanide (CNâ») cause death primarily by inhibiting cytochrome c oxidase (Complex IV) of the electron transport chain. This is the final and crucial enzyme in cellular respiration that transfers electrons to oxygen.

 

Mechanism of lethal toxicity:

 

  • Both toxins bind to the heme iron center in cytochrome c oxidase (Complex IV)
  • This completely blocks the final step of electron transfer to oxygen
  • Results in histotoxic hypoxia - cells cannot utilize oxygen despite adequate oxygen delivery
  • Cellular ATP production ceases, leading to rapid cell death
  • Most critically affects high-energy organs like brain and heart

 

Key distinction: While carbon monoxide can also bind to hemoglobin and myoglobin, the primary cause of death for both CO and cyanide is the inhibition of cytochrome c oxidase. Cyanide does not significantly bind to hemoglobin, making cytochrome c oxidase inhibition the common lethal mechanism for both toxins.

 

Clinical presentation: Cherry-red skin in CO poisoning (due to carboxyhemoglobin), but both toxins cause similar cellular suffocation despite normal blood oxygen levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myoglobin: This is incorrect as the primary cause of death. While carbon monoxide can bind to myoglobin, this interaction does not explain the lethal mechanism. Cyanide does not bind to myoglobin at all. The primary lethal effect is through cytochrome c oxidase inhibition, not myoglobin binding.

 

Option C. Hemoglobin: This is incorrect as the primary cause of death. Carbon monoxide does bind to hemoglobin forming carboxyhemoglobin, but cyanide does not significantly affect hemoglobin. The common lethal mechanism for both toxins is cytochrome c oxidase inhibition, not hemoglobin interference.

 

Option D. NADH Dehydrogenase: This is incorrect NADH dehydrogenase (Complex I) is inhibited by different toxins like rotenone, amobarbital, and piericidin A, not by carbon monoxide or cyanide. The mnemonic "ROT-ONE" helps remember Complex I inhibitors.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Carbon monoxide and cyanide cause death by inhibiting cytochrome c oxidase (Complex IV), preventing cellular oxygen utilization and causing histotoxic hypoxia despite adequate oxygen delivery to tissues.

 

Inhibitors of ETC Complexes:

questions.text: Which of the following statements about free radicals is incorrect? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fibrinoid necrosis

 

Fibrinoid necrosis is a type of tissue damage characterized by the deposition of fibrin-like material in blood vessel walls and tissues, typically seen in conditions like malignant hypertension, autoimmune diseases, and acute arterial necrosis. This pathological process is not directly caused by free radical damage. Fibrinoid necrosis primarily results from immune-mediated damage, acute hypertensive injury, or other non-oxidative mechanisms that lead to vessel wall damage and fibrin deposition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lipid peroxidation: correct. Free radicals actively cause lipid peroxidation by attacking polyunsaturated fatty acids in cell membranes. This process involves the oxidation of lipids, particularly affecting membrane phospholipids, leading to membrane damage, increased permeability, and ultimately cell death. Lipid peroxidation is one of the primary mechanisms by which reactive oxygen species (ROS) damage cellular structures.

 

Option B. SOD inactivates free radicals: correct. Superoxide dismutase (SOD) is a crucial antioxidant enzyme that inactivates free radicals, specifically superoxide anions (O2-). SOD catalyzes the dismutation of superoxide radicals into hydrogen peroxide and molecular oxygen, thereby protecting cells from oxidative damage. This enzyme represents one of the body's primary defense mechanisms against free radical-induced cellular damage.

 

Option C. Produced by neutrophils: correct. Neutrophils actively produce free radicals during the respiratory burst as part of their antimicrobial defense mechanism. Through NADPH oxidase activation, neutrophils generate superoxide anions, hydrogen peroxide, hydroxyl radicals, and hypochlorous acid to kill invading microorganisms. This process is essential for the innate immune response and microbial elimination.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Free radicals cause lipid peroxidation and cellular damage, are neutralized by antioxidant enzymes like SOD, and are produced by neutrophils during immune responses, but fibrinoid necrosis is not directly caused by free radical damage.

questions.text: A patient presents with hepatosplenomegaly and hypoglycemia. After a meal, glucagon administration increases blood glucose levels. However, after an overnight fast, glucagon administration does not improve blood glucose levels. Liver biopsy reveals increased abnormal glycogen accumulation. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Debranching enzyme

 

The clinical presentation is characteristic of Cori's disease caused by debranching enzyme deficiency. When abnormal glycogen accumulates in the liver, there are only two possible diagnoses: Anderson disease (branching enzyme deficiency) or Cori's disease (debranching enzyme deficiency). The key diagnostic feature here is the glucagon challenge test pattern - glucagon administration shows improvement in blood glucose after a meal (fed state) but no improvement after overnight fasting. This specific pattern is pathognomonic for Cori's disease with debranching enzyme deficiency. In the fed state, some normally structured glycogen is still available for mobilization, but after fasting, only abnormally structured glycogen with very short outer branches remains, which cannot be effectively broken down without the debranching enzyme.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Muscle phosphorylase: Incorrect. This causes McArdle disease (Type V), which affects skeletal muscle and presents with exercise intolerance and rhabdomyolysis, not hepatosplenomegaly.

 

Option B. Glycogen phosphorylase: Incorrect. This causes Hers disease, but the glycogen structure would be normal, not abnormal as described in this case.

 

Option D. Glucose-6-phosphatase: Incorrect. This causes von Gierke's disease where glucagon shows no improvement in both fed and fasted states, unlike the differential pattern seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Abnormal glycogen accumulation in liver occurs only in Anderson disease (branching enzyme deficiency) and Cori's disease (debranching enzyme deficiency), with Cori's disease showing characteristic differential glucagon response between fed and fasted states.

questions.text: Which of the following types of pulse is generated in accordance with the Frank-Starling law? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pulsus alternans

 

Pulsus alternans is the only pulse among the given options that directly demonstrates the Frank-Starling mechanism. The Frank-Starling law states that within physiological limits, the cardiac output (stroke volume) is directly proportional to the venous return (end-diastolic volume/preload). In simple terms: increased input leads to increased output.

 

Pulsus alternans occurs primarily in congestive heart failure and is characterized by alternating beats of high and low amplitude. The mechanism works as follows:

 

  1. First beat (low amplitude): In heart failure, despite increased preload, the stroke volume is reduced due to pathological changes, leading to increased residual volume in the ventricle.
  2. Second beat (high amplitude): The residual volume from the previous beat adds to the normal venous return, creating a larger end-diastolic volume (EDV). This increased EDV causes greater ventricular stretching.
  3. Frank-Starling response: The increased stretching leads to enhanced calcium availability and improved contractility, resulting in a relatively higher amplitude beat.
  4. Cycle continues: This creates the characteristic alternating pattern of weak and strong beats.

 

This phenomenon directly demonstrates the Frank-Starling mechanism where changing ventricular filling volumes (EDV) result in corresponding changes in stroke volume and pulse amplitude.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulsus bisferiens: This is a double-peaked pulse within a single cardiac cycle, typically seen in aortic regurgitation combined with aortic stenosis, or in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. It results from the ejection pattern of blood from the left ventricle and is not related to the Frank-Starling mechanism.

 

Option B. Pulsus paradoxus: This refers to an abnormal decrease in pulse amplitude during inspiration (>10 mmHg decrease in systolic pressure). It occurs due to ventricular interdependence and altered venous return during respiration, commonly seen in conditions like cardiac tamponade, severe asthma, or tension pneumothorax. While it involves changes in venous return, it is primarily due to mechanical factors rather than the intrinsic Frank-Starling relationship.

 

Option D. Pulsus parvus: This describes a weak, small-amplitude pulse typically associated with conditions causing reduced stroke volume, such as aortic stenosis, heart failure, or hypovolemia. While it may be related to reduced preload in some cases, it does not demonstrate the dynamic relationship between changing preload and stroke volume that characterizes the Frank-Starling mechanism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frank-Starling law describes the intrinsic ability of the heart to increase stroke volume in response to increased venous return (preload), and that pulsus alternans is the only pulse pattern that directly demonstrates this mechanism through alternating ventricular filling volumes producing corresponding changes in pulse amplitude.

questions.text:
Which of the following features are characteristic of the Bezoldâ€“Jarisch reflex? (INICET MAY 2025)

 

  1. Hypotension
  2. Bradycardia
  3. Hypopnea
  4. Tachycardia

 

Which among the options are correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

 

The Bezold-Jarisch reflex is a protective cardiovascular reflex that occurs when certain irritants are introduced into the circulation. This reflex is characterized by a triad of responses:

 

  1. Hypotension - There is a significant decrease in blood pressure as the body attempts to prevent the spread of potentially harmful irritants throughout the cardiovascular system.
  2. Bradycardia - The heart rate decreases due to increased vagal stimulation. This is contrary to other reflexes and represents the body's protective mechanism.
  3. Hypopnea - The respiratory rate decreases, which helps minimize the circulation and distribution of the irritant substances.

 

The reflex is triggered by various irritants including:

 

  • IV alkaloids
  • Serotonin
  • Veratrogen
  • Capsaicin
  • Other bizarre IV substances

 

The mechanism involves stimulation of vagal nerve pathways, leading to parasympathetic dominance. The body essentially "slows down" all major systems to prevent the harmful substances from spreading throughout the circulation and causing more severe complications.

 

This reflex is particularly important in clinical scenarios where patients might receive accidental IV injections of inappropriate substances or experience certain drug reactions.

 

Incorrect Option:

 

4. Tachycardia: The Bezold-Jarisch reflex is specifically a bradycardic reflex, not a tachycardic one. The only tachycardic reflex among cardiovascular reflexes is the Bainbridge reflex (also known as the atrial reflex).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bezold-Jarisch reflex is a protective cardiovascular reflex characterized by the triad of hypotension, bradycardia, and hypopnea occurring in response to irritant substances, mediated through vagal stimulation to prevent systemic spread of harmful agents.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen during rapid ascent to high altitude? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Respiratory alkalosis

 

During rapid ascent to high altitude, respiratory alkalosis occurs due to the following physiological sequence:

 

  1.  Decreased Oxygen Availability: At high altitudes, the atmospheric oxygen content is significantly reduced, leading to decreased oxygen availability to the body tissues.
  2.  Development of Hypoxia: The reduced oxygen content causes the individual to develop hypoxia, especially if they are not acclimatized to high altitude conditions.
  3.  Peripheral Chemoreceptor Stimulation: Hypoxia stimulates the peripheral chemoreceptors (located in the carotid and aortic bodies), which are sensitive to decreased oxygen levels in the blood.
  4.  Compensatory Hyperventilation: In response to peripheral chemoreceptor stimulation, the respiratory center increases ventilation dramatically. The person begins to hyperventilate as a compensatory mechanism to increase oxygen uptake.
  5.  Increased COâ‚‚ Washout: Hyperventilation leads to excessive elimination of carbon dioxide (COâ‚‚) from the lungs. This process is called "COâ‚‚ washout."

  6.  Development of Alkalosis: Since COâ‚‚ combines with water to form carbonic acid (Hâ‚‚COâ‚ƒ), the excessive elimination of COâ‚‚ reduces the acid content in the body, leading to alkalosis.

     

This alkalosis is classified as "respiratory" because it results from changes in ventilation (respiratory function), not from kidney dysfunction or metabolic processes.

 

The key mechanism is: Hypoxia â†’ Hyperventilation â†’ COâ‚‚ washout â†’ Respiratory alkalosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Respiratory acidosis: Incorrect. Respiratory acidosis occurs when there is COâ‚‚ retention, typically due to hypoventilation or lung disease. During high altitude ascent, the opposite occurs.

 

Option C. Metabolic alkalosis: Incorrect. Metabolic alkalosis results from non-respiratory causes such as loss of gastric acid (vomiting), diuretic use, or excess bicarbonate intake. The alkalosis at high altitude is purely due to respiratory changes (hyperventilation), not metabolic dysfunction.

 

Option D. Metabolic acidosis: Incorrect. Metabolic acidosis occurs due to conditions like diabetic ketoacidosis, lactic acidosis, or kidney disease. At high altitude, the primary acid-base disturbance is alkalosis (not acidosis) caused by respiratory factors (not metabolic factors).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rapid ascent to high altitude causes respiratory alkalosis due to hypoxia-induced hyperventilation leading to excessive COâ‚‚ washout, making this the characteristic acid-base disturbance in unacclimatized individuals at high altitude.

choices.text: Goes from standing to supine position

questions.text: During which phase is the surface tension in the alveoli at its highest? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inspiration

 

Surface tension in alveoli varies during the respiratory cycle and is primarily dependent on surfactant concentration per unit area of the alveolar surface. Here's the detailed mechanism:

 

During Inspiration (Alveolar Inflation):

 

  • Alveoli expand and increase in surface area
  • The same amount of surfactant is now distributed over a larger surface area
  • This results in decreased surfactant concentration per unit area
  • Since surface tension is inversely proportional to surfactant concentration, decreased surfactant concentration leads to increased surface tension

 

During Expiration (Alveolar Deflation):

 

  • Alveoli contract and decrease in surface area
  • The same amount of surfactant is now concentrated over a smaller surface area
  • This results in increased surfactant concentration per unit area
  • Higher surfactant concentration leads to decreased surface tension

 

Functional Significance:

 

  • High surface tension during inspiration helps maintain alveolar stability during expansion
  • Low surface tension during expiration prevents alveolar collapse
  • This dynamic change in surface tension is crucial for efficient ventilation

 

Surfactant Composition: Surfactant is primarily composed of phospholipids (especially dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine), proteins, and cholesterol, produced by Type II pneumocytes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Expiration: Incorrect. During expiration, alveoli deflate and their surface area decreases. This concentrates the surfactant over a smaller area, increasing surfactant concentration per unit area. Higher surfactant concentration results in decreased, not increased, surface tension.

 

Option C. Standing from supine position: Incorrect. Postural changes do not directly affect surfactant concentration or distribution within individual alveoli. Surface tension is determined by the surfactant-to-surface area ratio, which is not influenced by body position. The amount and distribution of surfactant remain constant regardless of whether a person is standing or lying down.

 

Option D. Goes from standing to supine position: Incorrect.  Similar to option C, changing from standing to supine position does not alter the fundamental relationship between surfactant concentration and alveolar surface area. Surface tension changes are related to the respiratory cycle (inspiration/expiration), not postural changes. The physical properties of surfactant and its concentration per unit area of alveolar surface remain unaffected by positional changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Surface tension in alveoli is increased during inspiration due to decreased surfactant concentration per unit area as alveoli expand, demonstrating the inverse relationship between surface tension and surfactant concentration that is essential for proper pulmonary mechanics.

questions.text: A patient is asked to close his eyes and then reopen them. Which of the following EEG waves would show a decrease upon eye opening? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alpha wave

 

Alpha waves show a characteristic decrease upon eye opening. Here's the detailed physiological mechanism:

 

Alpha Wave Characteristics:

 

  • Frequency: 8-13 Hz
  • Amplitude: Moderate (20-60 Î¼V)
  • Location: Most prominent in occipital and parietal regions
  • Associated state: Relaxed wakefulness with eyes closed

 

Physiological Sequence:

 

  1.  Eyes Closed State: When the patient closes their eyes and is in a relaxed, wakeful state, alpha waves become prominent, especially in the posterior regions of the brain (occipital cortex). This represents a state of "relaxed alertness" where the visual cortex is not actively processing visual information.
  2. Eye Opening Response: As soon as the patient opens their eyes, several changes occur:
    • Visual stimuli activate the visual cortex
    • The brain shifts from a relaxed state to an active, attentive state
    • Alpha waves are immediately suppressed and replaced by beta waves
  3. Alpha Blocking (Berger Effect): This phenomenon of alpha wave suppression upon eye opening is called "alpha blocking" or the "Berger effect," named after Hans Berger who first described EEG patterns.
  4. Beta Wave Dominance: Upon eye opening, beta waves (14-30 Hz) become dominant, reflecting:

 

  • Active mental processing
  • Visual information processing
  • Increased cortical activation
  • Alert, focused attention

 

Clinical Significance: The alpha rhythm and its response to eye opening/closing is used clinically to assess:

 

  • Normal brain function
  • Level of consciousness
  • Posterior brain region integrity

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Theta wave: Incorrect. Theta waves (4-8 Hz) are associated with drowsiness, light sleep, meditation, and certain memory processes. They are not characteristically prominent during relaxed wakefulness with eyes closed in normal adults. Eye opening does not specifically cause a decrease in theta waves; instead, it would tend to increase alertness and reduce theta activity if present.

 

Option C. Beta wave: Incorrect. Beta waves (14-30 Hz) actually increase upon eye opening, not decrease. Beta waves are associated with active, alert mental states, concentration, and problem-solving. When eyes open, beta waves become more prominent as the brain engages in active visual processing and heightened awareness. This is the opposite of what the question asks.

 

Option D. Delta Wave: Incorrect. Delta waves (0.5-4 Hz) are the slowest brain waves and are primarily associated with deep sleep (slow-wave sleep), unconsciousness, or certain pathological conditions. In normal, awake individuals, delta waves are not prominent regardless of whether eyes are open or closed. Eye opening would not cause a significant decrease in delta waves since they are not normally present during wakefulness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alpha waves (8-13 Hz) are prominent during relaxed wakefulness with eyes closed and characteristically decrease upon eye opening due to alpha blocking (Berger effect), being replaced by higher-frequency beta waves that reflect increased cortical activation and visual processing.

choices.text: Increase in heart rate on standing from supine position
Increase in cardiac output in response to anemia

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a feedforward mechanism? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vasoconstriction after exposure to cold

 

Feedforward mechanisms are anticipatory control systems that initiate corrective actions before the controlled variable actually changes. This is in contrast to feedback mechanisms, which respond after a change has occurred.

 

Vasoconstriction after cold exposure is a classic example of feedforward mechanism because:

 

  1. Anticipatory Response: When the body is exposed to cold environment, peripheral vasoconstriction occurs immediately to prevent heat loss, even before core body temperature actually drops.
  2. Temperature Regulation Strategy:
    • Shell temperature (skin and peripheral tissues) decreases upon cold exposure
    • Core body temperature needs to be maintained for vital organ function
    • Vasoconstriction occurs to preserve core temperature before it falls
  3. Predictive Nature: The system "predicts" that cold exposure will lead to heat loss and core temperature drop, so it initiates vasoconstriction as a preventive measure rather than waiting for core temperature to actually decrease.
  4. Homeostatic Advantage: This anticipatory response is more efficient than waiting for core temperature to drop and then responding, as it prevents the potentially dangerous decrease in core body temperature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increase in heart rate on standing from supine position: Incorrect.  While this can have feedforward components, it's primarily a feedback mechanism. When someone stands up, blood pools in the lower extremities due to gravity, leading to decreased venous return and cardiac output. Baroreceptors detect the resulting drop in blood pressure and then trigger compensatory tachycardia. This is a response after the hemodynamic change has occurred.

 

Option C. Increase in cardiac output in response to anemia: Incorrect.  The phrase "in response to" clearly indicates this is a feedback mechanism. Anemia reduces oxygen-carrying capacity, leading to tissue hypoxia. The cardiovascular system detects this change and responds by increasing cardiac output to compensate for the reduced oxygen delivery. This correction occurs after anemia has already developed.

 

Option D. Increased vasopressin secretion during dehydration: Incorrect.  This is a feedback mechanism. Dehydration leads to increased plasma osmolality and decreased blood volume. Osmoreceptors and volume receptors detect these changes and then stimulate vasopressin (ADH) release. The hormone secretion occurs after dehydration has already begun, making it a corrective response rather than a preventive one.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Feedforward mechanisms are anticipatory control systems that initiate corrective actions before the controlled variable changes, as exemplified by vasoconstriction upon cold exposure to maintain core body temperature before it actually decreases.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old patientâ€™s pulmonary function test shows:  (INICET MAY 2025)

 

FEV1/FVC = 0.62

FVC = 60%

RV/TLC = 142%

 

Which of the following best explains these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Air trapping

 

This pulmonary function test shows a classic pattern of air trapping associated with obstructive lung disease. Let's analyze each parameter:

 

  1. FEV1/FVC Ratio = 0.62 (62%):
    • Normal value: >75% (or >70% in some references)
    • Interpretation: This reduced ratio indicates obstructive lung disease
    • Mechanism: Airways are narrowed/obstructed, making it difficult to exhale air rapidly
  2. FVC = 60%:
    • Normal value: Should be close to 100% (at least 98%)
    • Interpretation: Significantly reduced forced vital capacity
    • Mechanism: In this context (with reduced FEV1/FVC), this indicates that more air cannot be expelled due to airway obstruction and air trapping
  3. RV/TLC = 142%:

 

  • Normal value: Approximately 20-25%
  • Interpretation: Dramatically increased residual volume to total lung capacity ratio
  • Mechanism: Residual volume is increased because air gets trapped in alveoli and cannot be exhaled completely

 

Pathophysiology of Air Trapping:

 

  • Airways become narrowed or obstructed (bronchospasm, inflammation, structural changes)
  • During expiration, airways collapse or close prematurely
  • Air becomes trapped in alveoli distal to the obstruction
  • This leads to hyperinflation of the lungs
  • Residual volume increases significantly
  • Patient cannot empty lungs completely during forced expiration

 

Clinical Conditions Associated with Air Trapping:

 

  • COPD (Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease)
  • Emphysema - most characteristic
  • Severe asthma
  • Bronchiectasis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Restrictive: Incorrect. Restrictive lung disease shows a different pattern:

 

  • Normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio (>75%)
  • Proportionally reduced FEV1 and FVC
  • Normal or decreased RV/TLC ratio
  • The patient's reduced FEV1/FVC ratio of 62% rules out restrictive disease

 

Option B. Reduced compliance: Incorrect. Reduced compliance is a characteristic of restrictive lung disease, not obstructive disease:

 

  • Occurs in conditions like pulmonary fibrosis, chest wall deformities
  • Would show restrictive pattern with normal/high FEV1/FVC ratio
  • The obstructive pattern (low FEV1/FVC) and high RV/TLC indicate this is not primarily a compliance issue

 

Option D. Age related: Incorrect. Several factors rule out age-related changes:

 

  • Patient age: 42 years (age-related physiological changes typically become significant after 55-60 years)
  • Severity of abnormality: The values are too severely abnormal for physiological aging 
    • FVC of 60% is markedly reduced
    • RV/TLC of 142% is dramatically elevated
  • Age-related changes would be gradual and mild, not this severe
  • Pattern mismatch: Age-related changes don't typically cause such severe air trapping

 

Educational Objective:

 

Air trapping in obstructive lung disease is characterized by reduced FEV1/FVC ratio (<70%), significantly increased RV/TLC ratio, and reduced FVC, indicating airways obstruction with inability to completely exhale trapped air, commonly seen in COPD and emphysema.

choices.text: Decreased reabsorption of sodium from kidney
Decreased sodium absorption from the intestine

questions.text: Which of the following best explains the development of hyponatremia in a hypovolemic patient presenting with diarrhea? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Non-osmotic release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH)

 

In a hypovolemic patient with diarrhea who develops hyponatremia, the non-osmotic release of ADH is the primary mechanism responsible for the development of hyponatremia. Here's the detailed pathophysiology:

 

Initial Pathophysiology:

 

  1. Diarrhea causes loss of both water and electrolytes (including sodium)
  2. Hypovolemia develops due to fluid losses
  3. Hyponatremia occurs initially due to sodium losses

 

Non-osmotic ADH Release Mechanism:

 

  1. Volume-mediated ADH Stimulation:
    • Despite hyponatremia (which normally should suppress ADH), hypovolemia acts as a powerful stimulus for ADH release
    • Volume receptors (baroreceptors) in the atria, ventricles, and great vessels detect decreased blood volume
    • This triggers non-osmotic ADH secretion to preserve body water
  2. Priority of Volume over Osmolality:
    • The body prioritizes volume preservation over osmolality correction
    • Since 60-70% of body weight is water, maintaining adequate circulating volume is critical for survival
    • ADH continues to be secreted despite low sodium levels
  3. Development of Dilutional Hyponatremia:
    • ADH causes increased water reabsorption in collecting ducts
    • More water is retained relative to sodium, leading to dilutional hyponatremia
    • This worsens the existing hyponatremia despite the body's attempt to maintain volume
  4. Vicious Cycle:
    • ADH release â†’ Water retention â†’ Further dilution of sodium â†’ Worsening hyponatremia
    • Volume preservation takes precedence over sodium concentration

 

Clinical Significance: This mechanism explains why hyponatremia can paradoxically worsen in dehydrated patients and why simple fluid replacement without electrolyte consideration can be problematic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased reabsorption of sodium from kidney: Incorrect. This contradicts normal physiological compensation. In a hypovolemic, hyponatremic patient, compensatory mechanisms are activated, including:

 

  • RAS activation (Renin-Angiotensin-Aldosterone System)
  • Increased aldosterone secretion
  • Enhanced sodium reabsorption in distal tubules and collecting ducts
  • The kidney attempts to increase, not decrease sodium reabsorption to restore volume and electrolyte balance

 

Option B. Decreased secretion of aldosterone: Incorrect. This is physiologically incorrect. Hypovolemia is a powerful stimulus for aldosterone secretion:

 

  • Decreased blood volume â†’ Decreased renal perfusion â†’ Increased renin release â†’ Angiotensin I â†’ Angiotensin II â†’ Stimulates aldosterone secretion â†’ (Aldosterone acts on epithelial sodium channels-ENaC) â†’ increase sodium reabsorption
  • The RAS system is activated, not suppressed in this scenario

 

Option D. Decreased sodium absorption from the intestine: Incorrect. While this may contribute to the initial sodium loss in diarrhea, it does not best explain the development of hyponatremia:

 

  • Intestinal sodium loss explains the cause of volume depletion, not the mechanism of ongoing hyponatremia
  • The gastrointestinal tract typically increases sodium reabsorption during diarrhea as a compensatory mechanism
  • Even if intestinal absorption is impaired, the kidney would compensate by increasing sodium reabsorption

The primary mechanism preventing correction of hyponatremia is the continued ADH release due to volume depletion

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-osmotic ADH release due to hypovolemia is the primary mechanism causing hyponatremia in diarrheal patients, where volume preservation takes priority over osmolality correction, leading to dilutional hyponatremia despite the body's attempts at electrolyte conservation.

questions.text: Which of the following brain regions is primarily associated with the processing of explicit memory? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hippocampus

 

Explicit memory (also known as declarative memory) is primarily processed by the hippocampus and associated medial temporal lobe structures. Here's the detailed explanation:

 

Explicit/Declarative Memory Characteristics:

 

  • Conscious, intentional recall of facts and events
  • "Declarative" because you can "declare" or verbally express these memories
  • Can be consciously accessed and articulated
  • Two main subtypes: episodic and semantic memory

 

Hippocampus and Explicit Memory:

 

 

Clinical Evidence:

 

  • H.M. case: Patient with bilateral hippocampal damage showed severe explicit memory deficits
  • Alzheimer's disease: Early hippocampal damage leads to prominent explicit memory loss
  • Hippocampal lesions: Specifically impair explicit memory while leaving implicit memory intact

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amygdala: Incorrect. The amygdala is primarily involved in emotional memory and associative learning, not explicit memory processing:

 

  • Primary function: Fear conditioning, emotional associations, threat detection
  • Memory type: Implicit emotional memories (e.g., fear responses, emotional associations)
  • Relationship to explicit memory: Can modulate explicit memory formation through emotional enhancement, but is not the primary processor

 

Option C. Insular cortex: Incorrect. The insular cortex is involved in interoception and sensory integration, not explicit memory:

 

  • Primary functions: Processing internal bodily sensations, taste, pain, emotional awareness
