  • Memory involvement: May contribute to embodied aspects of memory but is not a primary explicit memory processor
  • Location: Deep within lateral sulcus, primarily involved in sensory and emotional processing

 

Option D. Cerebellum: Incorrect. The cerebellum is primarily involved in implicit memory, particularly motor learning and conditioning:

 

  • Primary functions: Motor control, balance, coordination, procedural learning
  • Memory type: Implicit memory - motor skills, habits, classical conditioning
  • Examples: Learning to ride a bike, developing motor skills, associative conditioning
  • Contrast with explicit: Cerebellar memories are unconscious and automatic, opposite of the conscious, declarative nature of explicit memory

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hippocampus is the primary brain structure for processing explicit (declarative) memory, including both episodic memories of personal experiences and the initial formation of semantic memories, serving as the central hub for conscious memory formation, consolidation, and retrieval.

questions.text: IGF-1 and IGF-2 (Insulin-like Growth Factors) are structurally most similar to which of the following molecules? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Proinsulin

 

IGF-1 and IGF-2 are structurally most similar to proinsulin because they share the same single chain peptide structure. Here's the detailed structural comparison:

 

  1. IGF-1 and IGF-2 Structure:
    • Single chain peptides with continuous amino acid sequence
    • No separation between different peptide chains
    • Maintain their single-chain structure throughout their functional life
  2. Proinsulin Structure:
    • Single chain peptide consisting of B-chain + C-peptide + A-chain all connected
    • The "immature" or precursor form of insulin
    • Contains all components in one continuous peptide chain
    • Structural similarity: Both IGF-1/IGF-2 and proinsulin are single chain molecules
  3. Mature Insulin Structure (Different from IGFs):
    • Double chain peptide after processing
    • A-chain and B-chain connected by disulfide bonds
    • C-peptide is removed during maturation process
    • No longer has the connecting peptide chain
    • Structural difference: Insulin becomes a two-chain molecule, unlike IGFs

 

Insulin Maturation Process:

 

  1. Preproinsulin â†’ (N-terminal removal) â†’ Proinsulin â†’ (C-peptide cleavage) â†’ Mature Insulin
  2. Key step: When proinsulin matures in secretory vesicles, C-peptide is cleaved out
  3. Result: Two separate chains (A and B) connected only by disulfide bonds
  4. IGFs never undergo this processing - they remain as single chain peptides

 

Functional Significance:

 

  • Single chain structure of IGF-1/IGF-2 allows different receptor binding properties
  • Proinsulin's single chain structure represents the "blueprint" that IGFs structurally resemble
  • This similarity explains why they're called "insulin-like" growth factors

 

Clinical Correlation:

 

  • Both IGF-1/IGF-2 and proinsulin can be measured as markers of different physiological states
  • Understanding their structural relationship helps explain their similar but distinct biological functions

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Insulin: Incorrect. Mature insulin has a fundamentally different structure:

 

  • Two separate chains (A-chain and B-chain) connected by disulfide bonds. 
  • C-peptide has been removed during the maturation process
  • No connecting peptide between the A and B chains
  • Structural mismatch: IGF-1 and IGF-2 are single chain peptides, while mature insulin is a double chain molecule
  • The processing that converts proinsulin to insulin creates a structural divergence from the IGF family

 

Option C. C peptide: Incorrect. C-peptide is only a small connecting fragment:

 

  • Function: Connects the B-chain to A-chain in proinsulin
  • Size: Much smaller than IGF-1 or IGF-2
  • Structure: Simple connecting peptide without the complex structure of growth factors
  • Biological role: Primarily serves as a marker of endogenous insulin production

 

Option D. Preproinsulin: Incorrect. Preproinsulin contains additional structural elements:

 

  • Extra component: Contains the N-terminal signal peptide that proinsulin lacks
  • Processing stage: Represents an even earlier precursor form
  • Structural difference: The N-terminal extension makes it structurally more complex than IGFs

 

Functional relevance: The signal peptide is involved in cellular processing, not in the final functional structure

 

Educational Objective:

 

IGF-1 and IGF-2 are structurally most similar to proinsulin because all three molecules share a single chain peptide structure, unlike mature insulin which becomes a double chain molecule after C-peptide cleavage during processing.

 

 

Insulin is composed of two peptide chains (A and B) linked by disulfide bonds.

 

Proinsulin is a single-chain precursor containing A, B, and C domains.

IGF-1 and IGF-2 are single-chain molecules containing A, B, C, and D domains.

questions.text: Tight junction are located at which part of the cell? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Apicolateral

 

Tight junctions are primarily located at the apicolateral membrane of epithelial cells. This strategic positioning serves a crucial physiological function in maintaining cellular polarity and controlling paracellular transport.

 

The epithelial cell has distinct membrane regions:

 

  • Apical surface: Faces the lumen or external environment
  • Basal surface: Attached to the basement membrane
  • Lateral surfaces: Adjacent to neighboring cells
  • Apicolateral: The junction between apical and lateral surfaces

 

Tight junctions are positioned at the apicolateral region because they need to prevent paracellular transport from the apical side toward the basal side where blood vessels are located. This creates a selective barrier that maintains the directional flow of substances and prevents unwanted leakage between cells.

 

The tight junction complex consists of transmembrane proteins including claudins, occludins, and JAM (Junctional Adhesion Molecules) that form intercellular seals. This location allows tight junctions to effectively separate the apical and basolateral compartments, maintaining cellular polarity essential for proper epithelial function.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Apical: Incorrect. While tight junctions are near the apical region, they are not located directly on the apical membrane itself. The apical membrane faces the lumen and has different structural components like microvilli for absorption.

 

Option C. Basal: Incorrect. The basal membrane is attached to the basement membrane and contains hemidesmosomes and other adhesion structures, not tight junctions. This location would be too far from the apical surface to control paracellular transport effectively.

 

Option D. Basolateral: Incorrect. The basolateral membrane contains different types of junctions and transport proteins. If tight junctions were located here, they would not be able to prevent paracellular transport from the apical side, defeating their primary purpose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tight junctions are located at the apicolateral membrane of epithelial cells to prevent paracellular transport and maintain cellular polarity by creating a selective barrier between apical and basolateral compartments.

questions.text: If a simple muscle twitch has a latent period of 10 milliseconds, a contraction period of 40 milliseconds, and a relaxation period of 50 milliseconds, what is the tetanizing frequency? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 25HZ

 

The tetanizing frequency is calculated using the formula:

Tetanizing Frequency (TF) = 1/Contraction Period (CP)

 

Given data:

 

  • Latent period = 10 ms (not used in calculation)
  • Contraction period = 40 ms
  • Relaxation period = 50 ms (not used in calculation)

 

Calculation:

 

TF = 1/CP 

TF = 1/40 ms 

TF = 1/0.04 seconds (converting milliseconds to seconds) 

TF = 25 Hz

 

The tetanizing frequency represents the minimum frequency of stimulation required to produce tetanic contraction in a muscle. It depends only on the contraction period because this determines how quickly the muscle can respond to successive stimuli. The latent and relaxation periods do not affect the tetanizing frequency calculation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tetanizing frequency is calculated as 1/Contraction Period and represents the minimum stimulus frequency needed to produce tetanic muscle contraction, depending only on how quickly the muscle can complete its contraction phase.

questions.text: Which center in the brain is responsible for producing fever during infection? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Preoptic Nucleus

 

The preoptic nucleus of the hypothalamus is the primary center responsible for fever generation during infection. This process follows a specific pathway:

 

Mechanism of Fever Production:

 

  1. Infection â†’ Release of pyrogens â†’ Stimulate release of Prostaglandin E2 (PG-E2) â†’ Alters the hypothalamic set point (thermostat) â†’ Activates heat-sensitive neurons in the preoptic nucleus â†’ Triggers fever response

 

Thus preoptic nucleus is part of the anterior hypothalamus and is the most important center for thermoregulation. It integrates thermal information from both peripheral and central thermoreceptors and coordinates appropriate responses to maintain or alter body temperature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paraventricular nucleus of hypothalamus: Incorrect. The paraventricular nucleus is primarily involved in neuroendocrine functions, including ADH and oxytocin release, and stress responses. While it may have some role in temperature regulation, it is not the primary fever center.

 

Option B. Dorsomedial nucleus: Incorrect. The dorsomedial nucleus is involved in heat production and becomes active during cold exposure to increase metabolic heat generation. It helps maintain core body temperature when environmental temperature is low, but it does not initiate fever during infection. This would be a secondary answer only if preoptic nucleus were not available as an option.

 

Option D. Cerebellum: Incorrect. The cerebellum is involved in motor coordination, balance, and procedural learning. It has no direct role in temperature regulation or fever production. It is part of the hindbrain and does not contain thermosensitive neurons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The preoptic nucleus of the hypothalamus is the primary fever center that responds to pyrogen-induced PG-E2 release by altering the hypothalamic temperature set point and activating heat-sensitive neurons during infection.

questions.text: In uncontrolled diabetes mellitus, which of the following cell types exhibit decreased glucose uptake as a result of insulin deficiency? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Skeletal Muscle

 

Skeletal muscle shows decreased glucose uptake in uncontrolled diabetes due to insulin deficiency because it relies on GLUT4 transporters, which are insulin-dependent.

 

GLUT4 Transporter Mechanism:

 

  • GLUT4 transporters are stored in intracellular vesicles in skeletal muscle
  • Insulin binding to its receptor triggers translocation of GLUT4 vesicles to the cell membrane
  • Without insulin, GLUT4 transporters remain sequestered intracellularly and cannot facilitate glucose entry
  • This makes skeletal muscle insulin-dependent for glucose uptake

 

Tissues with GLUT4 (Insulin-dependent):

 

  • Skeletal muscle
  • Cardiac muscle
  • Adipose tissue

 

In uncontrolled diabetes mellitus, insufficient insulin production or action results in poor glucose utilization by these tissues, leading to hyperglycemia and the characteristic symptoms of diabetes. Skeletal muscle, being a major glucose-consuming tissue, significantly contributes to this impaired glucose homeostasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RBC: Incorrect. Red blood cells use GLUT1 and GLUT3 transporters, which are insulin-independent. These transporters have high affinity for glucose and work continuously regardless of insulin levels, allowing RBCs to maintain glucose uptake even in diabetic conditions.

 

Option C. Liver: Incorrect. Hepatocytes contain GLUT2 transporters, which are insulin-independent and have high capacity but low affinity for glucose. GLUT2 allows bidirectional glucose transport based on concentration gradients, enabling the liver to both take up and release glucose independent of insulin status.

 

Option D. Brain: Incorrect. Brain tissue primarily uses GLUT1 and GLUT3 transporters, which are insulin-independent. This ensures continuous glucose supply to neural tissue regardless of insulin availability, as the brain requires constant glucose for proper functioning and cannot afford insulin-dependent glucose uptake.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GLUT4 transporters in skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, and adipose tissue are insulin-dependent, making these tissues show decreased glucose uptake during insulin deficiency in uncontrolled diabetes, while GLUT1, GLUT2, and GLUT3 transporters in other tissues are insulin-independent.

choices.text: Increase absorption of urea in the medullary collecting duct
Increase absorption of urea in the descending loop of Henle
Decrease absorption of NaCl in the ascending loop of Henle
Increase water permeability in the collecting ducts

questions.text: Which of the following is not a mechanism by which antidiuretic hormone (ADH) facilitates the excretion of concentrated urine? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increase absorption of urea in the descending loop of Henle

 

The descending limb of the loop of Henle does NOT absorb urea and this is NOT a mechanism of ADH action for urine concentration.

 

Key Facts about Descending Limb:

 

  • The descending limb is only permeable to water. Its primary function is water reabsorption due to the hypertonic medullary interstitium
  • It is impermeable to urea, sodium, and other solutes

 

Actual ADH Mechanisms for Concentrated Urine:

 

  1. V2 receptor activation â†’ cAMP â†’ Aquaporin-2 (AQP2) insertion in collecting duct â†’ Increased water permeability â†’ more water reabsorption
  2. Enhanced urea absorption in medullary collecting duct â†’ maintains medullary osmolarity
  3. Coordination with loop function to maintain medullary concentration gradient

 

The descending limb's role is passive water reabsorption driven by the medullary osmotic gradient, not active urea transport.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase absorption of urea in the medullary collecting duct : Correct mechanism. ADH increases urea permeability in the medullary collecting duct, allowing urea reabsorption that contributes 45-50% of the medullary osmolarity. This maintains the concentration gradient essential for water reabsorption and urine concentration.

 

Option C. Decrease absorption of NaCl in the ascending loop of Henle : Correct mechanism. While not a direct ADH action, decreased NaCl reabsorption in the ascending limb helps maintain the medullary concentration gradient. This works synergistically with ADH to preserve the osmotic driving force for water reabsorption.

 

Option D. Increase water permeability in the collecting ducts: Correct mechanism. This is the primary action of ADH. ADH binds to V2 receptors, activating cAMP pathway that leads to insertion of Aquaporin-2 (AQP2) channels in the apical membrane of collecting duct principal cells, dramatically increasing water reabsorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The descending limb of loop of Henle is only permeable to water and does not participate in urea transport, making "increased urea absorption in descending limb" an incorrect mechanism of ADH action for urine concentration.

questions.text: The murmur associated with mitral stenosis corresponds to which phase of the ECG cycle? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) P Wave

 

The murmur of mitral stenosis corresponds to the P wave on ECG because it occurs during ventricular filling in diastole, which is temporally related to atrial depolarization.

 

Pathophysiology of Mitral Stenosis:

 

  • Mitral valve stenosis creates obstruction to blood flow from left atrium to left ventricle
  • During diastole, when the ventricle should fill, the stenotic valve creates turbulent flow
  • This turbulence generates the characteristic mid-diastolic murmur

 

ECG-Mechanical Correlation:

 

  1. Electrical phenomenon precedes mechanical phenomenon
  2. P wave represents atrial depolarization
  3. Following P wave â†’ Atrial contraction â†’ Ventricular filling phase
  4. Ventricular filling occurs during mid to late diastole
  5. The stenotic mitral valve causes turbulent flow during this filling phase
  6. This creates S3 and S4 gallop sounds and the diastolic murmur

 

Timing Sequence:

 

  • T wave â†’ Ventricular relaxation â†’ Early diastolic filling â†’ P wave â†’ Late diastolic filling with atrial kick â†’ Murmur generation

 

The murmur is most prominent during the atrial contribution to ventricular filling, which occurs after the P wave, making P wave the correct ECG correlation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. QRS Complex: Incorrect. The QRS complex represents ventricular depolarization and occurs during systole when the ventricles are contracting. Mitral stenosis murmur is a diastolic murmur that occurs when the ventricles are filling, not contracting. During systole, the mitral valve is closed.

 

Option C. ST segment: Incorrect. The ST segment represents early ventricular repolarization and occurs during systole. Since mitral stenosis produces a diastolic murmur during ventricular filling, it cannot correspond to the ST segment which occurs during ventricular contraction phase.

 

Option D. T wave: Incorrect. The T wave represents ventricular repolarization and occurs at the end of systole. While ventricular relaxation begins after the T wave, the murmur is heard during active ventricular filling which occurs later in diastole, corresponding more closely to P wave timing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitral stenosis produces a mid-diastolic murmur that corresponds to the P wave on ECG because the murmur occurs during ventricular filling in diastole, which follows atrial depolarization represented by the P wave.

choices.text: Reassurance as this much variation is common

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant is able to roll over, babble â€˜mamaâ€™ and â€˜dada,â€™ and exhibits stranger anxiety but is unable to sit without support. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reassurance as this much variation is common

 

The scenario describes a 9-month-old baby with some developmental milestones achieved while others are delayed. 

 

Milestone analysis:

 

Rolling: The baby can roll, which is expected by 6 months according to standard developmental timelines.

 

Speech Development: The baby can say "mama dada." Monosyllables typically appear by 6 months, while meaningful "mama" or "dada" develops by 9 months, so this is age-appropriate.

 

Stranger Anxiety: This is present, which is normal as stranger anxiety typically develops between 6-7 months.

 

Sitting Without Support: This is the only delayed milestone. Sitting with support usually develops by 6 months, while sitting without support typically occurs by 8 months.

 

The key principle here is that "common things are common and rare things are rare." When only one or two milestones are delayed in an otherwise normally developing child, reassurance is appropriate. Minor variations in developmental timing are common and usually represent normal individual differences rather than pathological delays. The child shows appropriate development in most areas (rolling, speech, social awareness), suggesting overall normal neurological development.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Get development test: This would be premature at this stage. Formal developmental testing is reserved for children with multiple delayed milestones or significant developmental concerns. A single delayed milestone in an otherwise appropriately developing child does not warrant immediate formal testing.

 

Option C. Give training to sit: Direct training for specific motor milestones is not recommended and can be counterproductive. Babies develop motor skills naturally through exploration and practice. Forced training may interfere with natural developmental progression and can create stress for both baby and parents.

 

Option D. Get an MRI: This is completely inappropriate for this scenario. MRI would only be considered if there were signs of neurological abnormalities, multiple developmental delays, or other concerning neurological symptoms. A single delayed milestone does not warrant neuroimaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sitting without support is expected by 8 months, and when only one milestone is delayed in an otherwise normally developing child, reassurance is the appropriate initial management rather than immediate investigation or intervention.

questions.text: Which of the following condition best explains the development of hypophosphatemia and hypomagnesemia in a malnourished child following the initiation of nutritional rehabilitation? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mechanism of refeeding syndrome

 

The scenario describes a classic presentation of refeeding syndrome in a malnourished child. Refeeding syndrome occurs when nutrition is reintroduced too rapidly to severely malnourished patients, particularly when high-energy, carbohydrate-rich foods are given suddenly.

 

Pathophysiology of Refeeding Syndrome: During prolonged malnutrition, the body adapts to a state of starvation with significantly depleted intracellular stores of phosphate, magnesium, and potassium. When carbohydrate-rich food is suddenly introduced, it stimulates a rapid insulin release. This insulin surge drives glucose and essential electrolytes (particularly phosphate, magnesium, and potassium) from the extracellular space into cells for glucose metabolism and anabolic processes.

 

The Classic Triad: Refeeding syndrome is characterized by the development of:

 

  1. Hypophosphatemia - the most characteristic and dangerous finding
  2. Hypomagnesemia - as mentioned in the question
  3. Hypokalemia - completes the triad

 

Clinical Context: This commonly occurs when well-meaning caregivers provide high-calorie foods such as chocolate, sweets, or other energy-dense foods to severely malnourished children without proper medical supervision. The connection with insulin is crucial - the sudden carbohydrate load triggers massive insulin release, leading to the dangerous electrolyte shifts.

 

Prevention: Proper refeeding protocols start with F75 diet (lower calorie, controlled approach) initially, followed by gradual progression to F100 diet. This prevents the sudden metabolic changes that trigger refeeding syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Insulin mediated uptake of electrolytes: While this is mechanistically correct and describes part of what happens in refeeding syndrome, it is too narrow and incomplete as an explanation. This option describes the immediate mechanism but fails to identify the complete syndrome. Insulin-mediated electrolyte uptake is actually the underlying mechanism of refeeding syndrome, not a separate condition. Therefore, option A is more comprehensive and clinically accurate.

 

Option C. Urinary loss of phosphates: This is incorrect as the primary mechanism in this scenario. In refeeding syndrome, the electrolyte depletion is due to rapid intracellular shifts rather than urinary losses. The child's kidneys would actually try to conserve phosphates in this situation. Moreover, urinary phosphate loss would not explain the concurrent hypomagnesemia mentioned in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Refeeding syndrome is characterized by the triad of hypophosphatemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypokalemia, which occurs when malnourished patients are given high-energy foods too rapidly, causing insulin-mediated intracellular electrolyte shifts that can be life-threatening.

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant presents with non-bilious vomiting and a normal abdominal examination. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CHPS 

 

The clinical presentation of a 3-week-old baby with non-bilious vomiting and normal abdominal examination is classic for Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (CHPS).

 

Key Clinical Features Supporting CHPS:

 

Age of Presentation: The most common age group for CHPS is 2-6 weeks of life. This 3-week-old baby fits perfectly within this typical age range, making CHPS the most likely diagnosis.

 

Type of Vomiting: Non-bilious vomiting is characteristic of CHPS because the obstruction occurs at the pylorus (gastric outlet), before the duodenum where bile is added to intestinal contents. The hypertrophied pyloric muscle creates a functional obstruction that prevents gastric contents from passing into the duodenum, resulting in forceful, projectile, non-bilious vomiting.

 

Normal Abdominal Examination: Early in the course of CHPS, the abdominal examination may appear normal. The classic "olive-shaped" mass in the epigastrium may not always be palpable, especially in early stages, in thin infants, or if the examiner lacks experience in pediatric examination.

 

Pathophysiology: CHPS involves progressive hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the circular muscle fibers of the pylorus. This creates a functional gastric outlet obstruction that typically manifests between 2-6 weeks of age as the muscle hypertrophy reaches a critical point where gastric emptying becomes significantly impaired.

 

 

Clinical Progression: The vomiting in CHPS is typically progressive, becoming more frequent and forceful over time. It usually occurs shortly after feeding and may become projectile in nature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GERD (Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease): This is incorrect because GERD typically presents with regurgitation of feeds rather than true vomiting. GERD involves the reflux of gastric contents into the esophagus, leading to effortless spitting up or regurgitation, not the forceful vomiting described. Additionally, GERD rarely presents with such acute onset at exactly 3 weeks of age.

 

Option C. Cow milk protein allergy: This condition has a completely different presentation. Cow milk protein allergy typically presents with bloody diarrhea as the predominant symptom, often accompanied by other gastrointestinal symptoms like cramping, irritability, and sometimes skin manifestations like eczema. There would also be a clear history of cow's milk-based formula feeding. Isolated vomiting without bloody stools makes this diagnosis unlikely.

 

Option D. Intestinal obstruction: While intestinal obstruction can cause vomiting, most forms of intestinal obstruction produce bilious vomiting because the obstruction typically occurs distal to the ampulla of Vater (where bile enters the duodenum). The non-bilious nature of the vomiting in this case effectively rules out most forms of intestinal obstruction. Additionally, intestinal obstruction would likely present with other signs like abdominal distension, absence of stool passage, and abnormal abdominal examination findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis typically presents between 2-6 weeks of age with progressive, non-bilious, projectile vomiting due to gastric outlet obstruction caused by pyloric muscle hypertrophy, and should be the primary consideration in any infant in this age group presenting with this characteristic pattern of vomiting.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in Turner syndrome? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prominent occiput

 

Turner syndrome is a chromosomal disorder affecting females with karyotype 45,XO. 

 

Prominent occiput is a characteristic feature of Edwards syndrome (Trisomy 18), not Turner syndrome. This is an important distinguishing feature that helps differentiate between different chromosomal disorders. 

 

Characteristic Features of Turner syndrome that ARE present:

 

  • Karyotype: 45,XO 
  • Affects only females
  • Physical features: Webbed neck, widely spaced nipples, short stature, horseshoe kidney, bicuspid aortic valve
  • Reproductive: Streak ovaries leading to infertility and amenorrhea
  • Cardiac: Coarctation of aorta, bicuspid aortic valve
  • Intelligence: Normal intelligence (unlike some other chromosomal disorders)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Widely spaced nipples: This is a characteristic feature of Turner syndrome. Patients with Turner syndrome typically have a broad chest with widely spaced nipples, making this an incorrect choice for what is "NOT seen."

 

Option B. Short stature: This is a classic feature of Turner syndrome. Growth hormone deficiency and the underlying chromosomal abnormality lead to short stature in affected individuals. This is one of the most consistent findings in Turner syndrome.

 

Option D. Barr body: This refers to the inactivated X chromosome in female cells. In Turner syndrome (45,XO), there is only one X chromosome, so there is NO Barr body present (Barr body absent). However, the question asks what is NOT seen, and since "absent Barr body" is actually a feature of Turner syndrome, this option could be interpreted as correct. But based on Dr. Anand's specific emphasis on prominent occiput being the distinguishing feature NOT seen in Turner syndrome, option C is the intended Ans..

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome (45,XO) is characterized by webbed neck, widely spaced nipples, short stature, and absent Barr body, but does NOT have prominent occiput, which is instead a feature of Edwards syndrome (Trisomy 18).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of Stridor in children? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hemorrhagic polyp

 

Stridor is a harsh, high-pitched respiratory sound caused by turbulent airflow through a narrowed or partially obstructed upper airway. It is typically heard during inspiration and becomes more pronounced with increased airflow demand (crying, feeding, agitation).

 

Hemorrhagic polyps are typically found in the nasal cavity or nasopharynx and do not usually cause the characteristic upper airway obstruction that leads to stridor. These lesions are more likely to cause nasal obstruction, epistaxis (nosebleeds), or nasal discharge rather than the inspiratory stridor sound that originates from laryngeal or immediately supraglottic structures.

 

Common Causes of Stridor:

 

  1. Laryngomalacia - The MOST COMMON cause of stridor, especially in neonates and infants
  2. Laryngeal web - Congenital malformation causing partial laryngeal obstruction
  3. Laryngeal stenosis - Narrowing of the laryngeal airway
  4. Vocal cord paralysis - Can cause functional airway obstruction

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laryngomalacia: This is the most common cause of stridor, especially in infants. It involves immature, floppy laryngeal cartilages that collapse inward during inspiration, causing the characteristic inspiratory stridor. The stridor typically worsens with agitation, crying, or feeding when inspiratory effort increases.

 

Option B. Laryngeal web: This is a recognized cause of stridor. Laryngeal webs are congenital malformations where tissue bridges across part of the laryngeal opening, creating a partial obstruction that can cause stridor, especially with increased airflow.

 

Option C. Laryngeal stenosis: This is definitely a cause of stridor. Laryngeal stenosis involves narrowing of the laryngeal airway, which can be congenital or acquired. The narrowed airway creates turbulent flow that manifests as stridor, particularly during inspiration when the soft tissues are drawn inward.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stridor is an abnormal inspiratory sound caused by upper airway obstruction, with laryngomalacia being the most common cause. Hemorrhagic polyps do not typically cause stridor as they are usually located in the nasal cavity rather than the laryngeal region where stridor originates.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the mechanism of breast milk jaundice? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Breast milk jaundice is a benign form of neonatal jaundice that occurs in breastfed infants. 

 

Option A. Unconjugated Hyperbilirubinemia: Breast milk jaundice definitely causes unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The specific components in breast milk interfere with the baby's bilirubin metabolism, leading to elevated levels of unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin in the blood.

 

Option B. Late Onset: Breast milk jaundice has a characteristic late onset pattern. It typically appears after the second week of life and can persist into the second, third, and fourth weeks of life. This distinguishes it from physiological jaundice, which typically appears earlier and resolves sooner.

 

Option C. Beta Glucuronidase Enzyme Involved: This is a key mechanistic component. Breast milk contains specific components that interfere with bilirubin metabolism, including beta glucuronidase enzyme and 3-alpha-20-beta diol. These components travel from the mother to the baby during breastfeeding and interfere with the normal bilirubin conjugation and excretion process.

 

Detailed Mechanism: The breast milk contains substances that inhibit the normal processing of bilirubin. The beta glucuronidase enzyme can deconjugate already conjugated bilirubin back to unconjugated form, and 3-alpha-20-beta diol can interfere with bilirubin uptake and conjugation. This creates a cycle where more bilirubin remains in the unconjugated form and accumulates in the blood.

 

Clinical Pattern: The more the mother feeds her baby breast milk, the more pronounced the jaundice becomes. This is a dose-dependent relationship â€“ increased breastfeeding leads to increased exposure to these interfering substances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Breast milk jaundice is characterized by late-onset unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia caused by specific components in breast milk (including beta glucuronidase enzyme and 3-alpha-20-beta diol) that interfere with normal bilirubin metabolism, with severity correlating with the amount of breast milk consumed.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ASD, left ventricular hypertrophy

 

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is the most common cyanotic congenital heart disease. It consists of four specific anatomical components.

 

The Four Classical Components of Tetralogy of Fallot:

 

  1. Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) - NOT Atrial Septal Defect (ASD)
  2. Pulmonary Stenosis - Narrowing of the pulmonary valve or outflow tract
  3. Overriding of Aorta - The aortic root is positioned above the VSD
  4. Right Ventricular Hypertrophy - Secondary to pulmonary stenosis and increased workload

 

ASD (Atrial Septal Defect): This is completely incorrect. TOF involves a VSD (Ventricular Septal Defect), not an ASD. The septal defect in TOF occurs at the ventricular level, not the atrial level.

 

Left Ventricular Hypertrophy: This is also incorrect. TOF causes Right Ventricular Hypertrophy, not left. The right ventricle hypertrophies because it has to pump blood against the stenotic pulmonary valve and also contributes to systemic circulation through the VSD and overriding aorta.

 

Pathophysiology: The combination of VSD and pulmonary stenosis leads to right-to-left shunting of blood, causing cyanosis. The pulmonary stenosis limits blood flow to the lungs, while the VSD and overriding aorta allow deoxygenated blood to enter the systemic circulation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pulmonary stenosis: This is a component of TOF. Pulmonary stenosis is one of the four classical features and is the primary reason for decreased pulmonary blood flow and subsequent cyanosis.

 

Option C. Overriding of aorta: This is a component of TOF. The aortic root is positioned directly above the VSD, allowing it to receive blood from both ventricles. This anatomical arrangement contributes to the mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood.

 

Option D. Right ventricular hypertrophy: This is a component of TOF. The right ventricle hypertrophies due to the increased workload from having to pump blood against pulmonary stenosis and contributing to systemic circulation through the overriding aorta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tetralogy of Fallot consists of four components: VSD (not ASD), pulmonary stenosis, overriding of aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy (not left ventricular hypertrophy). It is the most common cyanotic congenital heart disease with a characteristic "boot-shaped" heart on chest X-ray.

questions.text: A 36-week newborn presents with breathing difficulty that improves with FiOâ‚‚ at 30%. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hyaline membrane disease

 

This case presents a classic scenario of Hyaline Membrane Disease (HMD), also known as Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS). 

 

Key Clinical Features Supporting HMD:

 

Gestational Age: The baby is 36 weeks gestational age, which is preterm (less than 37 weeks). HMD is the most common cause of respiratory distress in preterm infants due to surfactant deficiency.

 

Chest X-ray Findings: The image shows characteristic "white-out lungs" or "ground-glass appearance" bilaterally. 

 

Response to Oxygen: The baby improved with FiO2 30%, which is consistent with HMD. The improvement with supplemental oxygen supports the diagnosis of surfactant deficiency leading to poor gas exchange.

 

Pathophysiology: HMD occurs due to surfactant deficiency in preterm infants. Surfactant is produced by type II pneumocytes and helps maintain alveolar stability by reducing surface tension. Without adequate surfactant, alveoli collapse (atelectasis), leading to poor gas exchange and the characteristic radiographic appearance.

 

The combination of prematurity (36 weeks), characteristic white-out lung appearance on chest X-ray, respiratory distress, and improvement with oxygen therapy is pathognomonic for HMD/RDS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Transient tachypnea of newborn (TTN): This typically occurs in term or near-term babies, often following cesarean section due to delayed clearance of fetal lung fluid. The chest X-ray in TTN shows fluid in the interlobar fissures and perihilar streaking, not the complete white-out appearance seen in this case. TTN also typically resolves within 2-3 days without significant oxygen requirement.

 

Option C. Meconium aspiration syndrome (MAS): This condition occurs when a baby aspirates meconium-stained amniotic fluid, typically in term or post-term infants. The chest X-ray in MAS shows patchy, coarse, irregular infiltrates throughout both lungs, not the uniform ground-glass or white-out appearance. There's no mention of meconium-stained amniotic fluid in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyaline Membrane Disease (HMD) should be suspected in any preterm infant presenting with respiratory distress and bilateral white-out or ground-glass appearance on chest X-ray, caused by surfactant deficiency leading to alveolar collapse and poor gas exchange.

choices.text: Protein loss is responsible for edema in this patient

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Marasmus in children? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Voracious appetite is seen

 

Marasmus is a form of severe acute malnutrition caused by deficiency of both proteins and calories, resulting in severe wasting and loss of muscle mass and subcutaneous fat.

 

Children with Marasmus characteristically maintain a strong appetite despite their severe malnutrition. This preserved hunger drive is a key distinguishing feature that differentiates Marasmus from Kwashiorkor, where children typically show apathy and poor appetite. The voracious appetite reflects the body's survival mechanism to seek nutrition while cognitive function remains relatively intact.

 

Key Features of Marasmus:

 

  • Definition: Marasmus is a form of severe protein-energy malnutrition characterized by severe wasting
  • Appearance: "Skinny baby" with severe muscle wasting and loss of subcutaneous fat
  • Characteristic sign: "Baggy pant appearance" due to loss of subcutaneous fat and muscle mass
  • Appetite: Preserved and often voracious appetite
  • Liver: Atrophic liver (unlike Kwashiorkor which has fatty liver)
  • Edema: Typically absent (unlike Kwashiorkor)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Seen due to calories deficiency: This is incorrect. Marasmus is not caused by calorie deficiency alone. It results from a combined deficiency of both proteins AND calories (protein-energy malnutrition). This is a fundamental distinction - while calories are certainly deficient, the condition involves inadequate intake of both macronutrients, making this statement incomplete and therefore incorrect.

 

Option B. Protein loss is responsible for edema in this patient: This is incorrect. Marasmus typically does NOT present with edema. Edema is characteristically absent in Marasmus because, despite protein deficiency, the severe caloric restriction leads to overall tissue wasting rather than fluid retention. Edema is more characteristic of Kwashiorkor, where hypoproteinemia with relatively better caloric status leads to fluid retention and swelling.

 

Option C. Subcutaneous fat is preserved: This is incorrect. Loss of subcutaneous fat is actually one of the hallmark features of Marasmus. The severe caloric restriction leads to mobilization and depletion of fat stores, resulting in the characteristic "baggy pant" or "old man" appearance. The skin hangs loose due to the absence of underlying subcutaneous fat, creating prominent skin folds and a wasted appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marasmus is characterized by severe wasting due to protein-calorie deficiency, loss of subcutaneous fat creating a "baggy pant" appearance, absence of edema, and characteristically preserved voracious appetite despite the severe malnutrition.

choices.text: The infant's lower lip should be inverted
The infant's cheeks should not appear full during feeding
Upper areola should be covered more than lower
The infant's chin should touch the breast

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding breastfeeding technique is/are correct? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The infant's chin should touch the breast

 

The correct breastfeeding technique involves proper positioning and attachment of the infant to ensure effective milk transfer and prevent nipple trauma. The infant's chin touching the breast is a fundamental sign of good attachment and proper latch. This positioning allows the infant's mouth to open wide and encompasses a large portion of the areola, with the nipple positioned deep in the baby's mouth against the soft palate. When the chin touches the breast, it indicates that the baby's head is tilted back appropriately, allowing the tongue to cup the breast and compress the milk ducts effectively. This position also ensures that the baby can breathe comfortably through the nose while feeding.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The infant's lower lip should be inverted: This is incorrect. The infant's lower lip should be everted (turned outward), not inverted. An everted lower lip allows for better attachment to the areola and more effective milk extraction. An inverted lower lip would indicate poor latch and could lead to inadequate milk transfer and nipple pain.

 

Option B. The infant's cheeks should not appear full during feeding: This is incorrect. During proper breastfeeding, the infant's cheeks should appear full and rounded, indicating good suction and milk transfer. Dimpled or hollowed cheeks suggest inadequate latch or poor suction, which may result in insufficient milk intake.

 

Option C. Upper areola should be covered more than lower: This is incorrect. In proper latch technique, the lower areola should be covered more than the upper areola. The baby's mouth should be positioned with more areola visible above the upper lip than below the lower lip. This asymmetric latch allows the nipple to be positioned against the soft palate and enables effective milk extraction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The infant's chin touching the breast is a key indicator of proper breastfeeding latch and positioning, ensuring effective milk transfer and comfortable feeding for both mother and baby.

questions.text: Which bone tumor is classically associated with the formation of a Codman's triangle and a sunburst appearance on radiographic imaging? (INICET May 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteosarcoma

 

  • Osteosarcoma is the correct answer because both Codman's triangle and sunburst (sun ray) appearance are classical radiological features strongly associated with this malignant bone tumor. Codman's triangle forms when the periosteum is lifted by aggressive tumor growth, creating a triangular area of new bone formation between the cortex and elevated periosteum. The sunburst appearance occurs due to aggressive perpendicular bone spicules extending from the cortex, representing the tumor's attempt to break through the bone.
  • Osteosarcoma is a primary malignant bone tumor that predominantly affects the metaphyseal region of long bones, most commonly around the knee (distal femur and proximal tibia). It typically occurs in the second decade of life and is characterized by the production of osteoid matrix. Both radiological signs indicate aggressive, malignant lesions and are pathognomonic features that should immediately suggest osteosarcoma as the primary differential diagnosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ewings sarcoma: This tumor characteristically shows onion peel (laminated) periosteal reaction rather than Codman's triangle or sunburst appearance. Ewing's sarcoma typically affects the diaphysis of long bones and is more common in the first decade of life, presenting as a round cell tumor with permeative bone destruction.

 

Option C. GCT (Giant Cell Tumor): This benign but locally aggressive tumor shows soap bubble appearance on radiographs, not Codman's triangle or sunburst pattern. GCT typically occurs in the epiphyseal region after skeletal maturity (20-40 years) and is the only bone tumor that can involve joint cartilage.

 

Option D. Chondrosarcoma: This malignant cartilage tumor demonstrates popcorn calcification patterns and dense calcification rather than the aggressive periosteal reactions seen in osteosarcoma. Chondrosarcoma commonly involves the pelvis and has the best prognosis among malignant bone tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Codman's triangle and sunburst appearance are pathognomonic radiological features of osteosarcoma, indicating aggressive malignant bone lesions that require immediate oncological evaluation.

questions.text: According to WHO guidelines, which investigation is specifically recommended for confirming the diagnosis of TB spine? (INICET May 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CBNAAT

 

  • CB-NAAT (Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test) is the correct answer according to WHO guidelines for TB spine diagnosis. This molecular diagnostic test provides rapid and specific detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis DNA through nucleic acid amplification technology. CB-NAAT is highly sensitive and specific for tuberculosis detection and also provides rifampicin resistance testing, which is crucial for appropriate anti-tubercular therapy selection.
  • TB spine (Pott's spine) involves two contiguous vertebrae along with the intervening disc, creating a paradiscal lesion. The infection spreads hematogenously and affects the anterior aspect of the vertebral bodies. While radiological investigations can suggest TB spine, definitive diagnosis requires microbiological confirmation, which CB-NAAT provides effectively and rapidly compared to traditional culture methods.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. X-ray: While X-ray shows important features like loss of spinal curvature, vertebral destruction, and paradiscal involvement, it cannot establish a definitive diagnosis of TB. Radiological features are suggestive but not diagnostic, as similar appearances can be seen in other infections or malignancies.

 

Option B. CT scan: CT scan is primarily used for guiding biopsy procedures rather than establishing TB diagnosis itself. While it provides better bony detail than X-ray, it cannot differentiate TB from other infections or confirm the presence of tubercular bacilli.

 

Option D. Culture and sensitivity: Though culture can grow TB organisms, it is a general term and takes much longer (weeks) compared to CB-NAAT. Traditional cultures have lower sensitivity and longer turnaround time, making them less practical for rapid diagnosis and treatment initiation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to WHO guidelines, CB-NAAT is the investigation of choice for establishing the diagnosis of TB spine due to its rapid, specific detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis and rifampicin resistance testing capability.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate treatment of choice for an intertrochanteric femoral fracture in a 72-year-old woman? (INICET May 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intramedullary nailing

 

  • Intramedullary nailing is the preferred treatment for inter-trochanteric fractures in elderly patients. Specifically, a cephalo-medullary nail (also known as proximal femoral nail) is the treatment of choice. Inter-trochanteric fractures are extracapsular fractures that occur in the area between the greater and lesser trochanters of the femur. These fractures typically affect elderly patients around 80 years of age and are more common in males, characterized by significant pain, shortening, and external rotation greater than 45 degrees.
  • The advantages of intramedullary nailing include better biomechanical stability, earlier mobilization, reduced operative time, and lower complication rates compared to other fixation methods. The nail provides excellent load-bearing capacity and allows for controlled collapse at the fracture site, promoting healing while maintaining stability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemiarthroplasty / DHS: Hemiarthroplasty is indicated for neck of femur fractures in patients over 65 years, not for inter-trochanteric fractures. Dynamic Hip Screw (DHS) is an alternative treatment for inter-trochanteric fractures but is less preferred than intramedullary nailing due to higher failure rates and complications in unstable fracture patterns.

 

Option C. ORIF with plating: Open reduction with plate fixation is not the preferred method for inter-trochanteric fractures as it provides less stable fixation compared to intramedullary devices and may lead to higher rates of mechanical failure, especially in elderly patients with osteoporotic bone.

 

Option D. Boot and bar: This is an outdated non-operative treatment method that was used in older times for upper femur fractures. It involved placing a shoe with a scale (bar) and is no longer preferred due to prolonged immobilization, complications from bed rest, and poor functional outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inter-trochanteric fractures in elderly patients are best treated with intramedullary nailing (cephalo-medullary nail/proximal femoral nail) rather than hemiarthroplasty, which is reserved for neck of femur fractures.

choices.text: Thumb spica cast and follow-up after 10-14 days

questions.text: A laborer presents with wrist pain after falling on an outstretched hand. Tenderness is noted in the anatomical snuffbox. What is the most appropriate next step in management? (INICET May 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thumb spica cast and follow-up after 10-14 days

 

  • The combination of fall on outstretched hand (FOOSH) and tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox strongly suggests a scaphoid fracture. The immediate management priority follows the fundamental principle of fracture care: immobilization before investigation. A thumb spica cast should be applied immediately to stabilize the suspected fracture and prevent further displacement.
  • The follow-up after 10-14 days is crucial because scaphoid fractures may not be visible on initial X-rays due to minimal displacement. During this period, granulation tissue formation and increased vascularity at the fracture site make the fracture line more apparent on repeat imaging. This is known as the "rule of two" - which includes two views on X-ray, comparing two sides, and repeat imaging on two occasions (initially and at 10-14 days).
  • The anatomical snuffbox contains three bones (scaphoid, trapezium, and base of first metacarpal), but scaphoid is the most commonly fractured carpal bone, especially with FOOSH mechanism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NSAIDs and discharge: This violates the basic principle of fracture management. Suspected fractures must be immobilized regardless of X-ray findings. Discharging a patient with potential scaphoid fracture without immobilization can lead to displacement, non-union, and avascular necrosis.

 

Option B. MRI of the wrist: While MRI is excellent for detecting early scaphoid fractures and marrow changes, it is not the immediate next step. Emergency management prioritizes stabilization over advanced imaging. MRI can be considered later if initial X-rays remain negative despite strong clinical suspicion.

 

Option D. CT scan of the wrist: CT scan can identify fracture fragments and is useful for surgical planning, but like MRI, it is not the immediate priority. The first step must always be immobilization to prevent complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In suspected scaphoid fractures, immediate immobilization with thumb spica cast takes priority over advanced imaging, with repeat evaluation after 10-14 days when fracture lines become more visible.

questions.text: A child presents with low-grade fever, pain, and a hole in the thigh for the past 2 weeks. X-ray of the femur shows a sclerotic shaft. Which of the following organisms is least likely to be responsible for this condition? (INICET May 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Klebsiella

 

  • The clinical presentation describes chronic osteomyelitis of the femoral shaft in a child. Klebsiella is not a typical causative organism for bone infections. The most common organism causing osteomyelitis is Staphylococcus aureus, which affects the metaphyseal region predominantly.
  • Osteomyelitis can be caused by various organisms depending on specific circumstances. Streptococcus species can cause bone infections, particularly in certain populations. Mycobacterium tuberculosis is a well-recognized cause of chronic osteomyelitis, especially in endemic areas like India, typically causing paradiscal lesions in the spine but can affect long bones. E.coli, though rare, can cause osteomyelitis, particularly in immunocompromised patients or in specific clinical scenarios like urinary tract infections with hematogenous spread.
  • However, Klebsiella pneumoniae is primarily a respiratory and urinary tract pathogen and is not classically associated with bone and joint infections in orthopedic practice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streptococcus: Streptococcus species are well-recognized causes of osteomyelitis and can cause both acute and chronic bone infections, particularly Streptococcus pyogenes and Streptococcus agalactiae.

 

Option B. Mycobacterium tuberculosis: TB is a major cause of chronic osteomyelitis, especially in endemic regions. TB osteomyelitis typically presents with chronic symptoms, low-grade fever, and characteristic radiological features including bone destruction and sclerosis.

 

Option D. E.coli: Though uncommon, E.coli can cause osteomyelitis, particularly in elderly patients, immunocompromised individuals, or through hematogenous spread from urinary tract infections or abdominal sources.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Klebsiella is not a typical causative organism for osteomyelitis, while Staphylococcus aureus remains the most common cause, others are Pseudomonas, Streptococcus, TB, and rarely E.coli in specific circumstances.

questions.text: A patient with rheumatoid arthritis presents with neck pain and clinical signs of myelopathy. What is the most likely underlying diagnosis? (INICET May 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Atlantoaxial dislocation

 

  • Rheumatoid arthritis characteristically involves the upper cervical spine, particularly the atlantoaxial (C1-C2) joint. The inflammatory process in RA affects the synovial joints and ligaments, including the transverse ligament of the atlas and the alar ligaments, leading to instability and potential dislocation at the atlantoaxial level.
  • Atlantoaxial dislocation in RA patients occurs due to erosion and weakening of the supporting ligamentous structures. This can result in compression of the spinal cord, leading to myelopathy with symptoms such as weakness, sensory disturbances, hyperreflexia, and in severe cases, respiratory compromise. The combination of established RA with neck pain and myelopathic signs strongly suggests atlantoaxial instability.

 

 Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteoarthritis of vertebrae: While osteoarthritis can affect the cervical spine, it typically involves the lower cervical segments (C5-C6, C6-C7) and doesn't commonly cause the severe instability patterns seen in RA. OA changes are degenerative rather than inflammatory.

 

Option B. C2-C3 intervertebral stenosis: This level is not typically affected in RA-related cervical spine pathology. RA predominantly affects the upper cervical spine, especially the atlantoaxial joint, rather than causing stenosis at the C2-C3 level.

 

Option D. Disc herniation: While disc herniation can cause myelopathy, it's not the characteristic cervical spine complication of RA. RA primarily affects synovial joints and ligaments rather than causing disc pathology.

 

 Educational Objective:

 

Rheumatoid arthritis characteristically involves the upper cervical spine, with atlantoaxial dislocation being the most common and serious complication leading to myelopathy.

 

Rheumatoid arthritis

 

  • Young female
  • Bilateral hand pain
  • Morning stiffness (age is not criteria)
  • Most common area involved in spine is upper cervical spine (AKA craniovertebral junction)
  • Craniovertebral junctional involvement: RA > AS > Gout
  • C1-C2 anomaly: spine flexion / extension view

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man noticed a slow, progressive, asymptomatic plaque on the side of the neck. He did not complain of any other systemic signs and symptoms. Which of the following tests are useful in this case? (INICET MAY 2025)

 

 

a) HIV 
b) Skin biopsy
c) KOH mount 
d) Chest X-ray
questions.solution:
Ans. D) b and d

 

This patient presents with a slowly progressive asymptomatic plaque that advances on one end while healing with atrophic changes/scarring on the other end. This clinical presentation is characteristic of lupus vulgaris, the most common form of cutaneous tuberculosis in adults. The key features that point to this diagnosis are:

 

  • Slowly progressive annular lesion
  • Central scarring (not clearing as in tinea, not crusting as in leishmaniasis)
  • Asymptomatic nature
  • No systemic symptoms

 

A skin biopsy is essential as it will identify the presence of granulomas characteristic of tuberculosis. A chest X-ray is also important because 10-20% of patients with lupus vulgaris may have concurrent pulmonary tuberculosis, making it necessary to evaluate for systemic disease.

 

Incorrect Options:

 

  • HIV testing (a) - Not indicated because the patient has no systemic symptoms or signs suggestive of immunodeficiency or opportunistic infections. The absence of systemic symptoms indicates normal immunity.
  • KOH mount (c) - This is used for diagnosing fungal infections by visualizing fungal elements, which is not relevant for this tuberculous condition.

 

Educational Objective: 


Lupus vulgaris presents as a slowly progressive annular plaque with central scarring and peripheral advancement, and requires skin biopsy for diagnosis and chest X-ray to rule out pulmonary tuberculosis.

 

Note â€“ 

 

  • Diascopy: test where a glass slide is pressed over the lesion
  • Lesion color changes to golden brown color â€“ called as apple jelly nodules
  • Apple jelly nodules are a feature of granulomatous diseases (hence not specific)

questions.text: A young male presented with painful vesicular lesions over the genitalia with superficial erosion. Tzanck smear findings are as shown in the image. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this condition? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acyclovir

 

The clinical presentation of painful vesicular lesions over the genitalia strongly suggests herpes genitalis (HSV-2 > HSV-1). The Tzanck smear showing multinucleated giant cells and acantholytic cells confirms the herpes simplex viral infection. Acyclovir is the drug of choice for herpes genitalis, typically given as 400 mg three times daily for 7 days. This corresponds to NACO kit number 5 (red kit) used in syndromic management of genital herpes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ceftriaxone: Used for gonococcal urethritis, not viral infections

 

Option C. Penicillin: Used for syphilis (Treponema pallidum), present in NACO kit number 3 for genital ulcer disease

 

Option D. Prednisolone: A corticosteroid, not appropriate as primary treatment for viral infections

 

Educational Objective: 


Herpes genitalis presents with painful vesicular lesions and is diagnosed by Tzanck smear showing multinucleated giant cells; acyclovir is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man came with complaints of pigmented lesions on palms and soles. He gave the history of sexual encounter followed by the development of transient genital lesion, 4 weeks ago. Which of the following investigation is most appropriate for this patient? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serology

 

This patient has secondary syphilis. The sequence of events is characteristic: sexual encounter â†’ transient painless genital ulcer (primary syphilis - hard chancre) â†’ 4-10 weeks later â†’ secondary manifestations including pigmented lesions on palms and soles (syphilids). 

 

These palmoplantar lesions are pathognomonic of secondary syphilis and represent a hypersensitivity reaction to Treponema pallidum. In secondary syphilis, serological tests (VDRL or RPR) are the investigations of choice, unlike primary syphilis where dark-field microscopy showing corkscrew motility is preferred.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation: This test is used to diagnose superficial fungal infections by dissolving keratinocytes and revealing fungal hyphae and spores. It would not detect Treponema pallidum, which is a spirochete bacterium, making this test inappropriate for syphilis diagnosis.

 

Option B. Tzanck smear: This cytological test is used to diagnose viral infections, particularly herpes simplex virus and varicella-zoster virus, by identifying multinucleated giant cells and viral cytopathic effects. Since syphilis is a bacterial infection, the Tzanck smear would not reveal the characteristic findings and is not useful for diagnosing syphilis.

 

Option C. Punch biopsy of palmar lesion: While histopathology can show chronic inflammation with plasma cell infiltration characteristic of syphilis, it is invasive, expensive, and the findings are relatively non-specific. Biopsy is typically reserved for cases where serological tests are inconclusive or when other diagnoses need to be excluded.

 

Educational Objective: 


Secondary syphilis presents with pigmented lesions on palms and soles (syphilids) following primary chancre, and is diagnosed by serology (VDRL/RPR).

 

Diagnostic Strategy in Syphilis: 

 

Stage-Specific Investigations

questions.text:
Which of the following are recognized local side effects associated with the use of topical corticosteroids? (INICET MAY 2025)

 

  1. Blue grey discolouration of skin
  2. Atrophy
  3. Acneiform eruption
  4. Hypertrichosis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 3 and 4 only

 

The side effects of topical corticosteroids can be remembered by the mnemonic STEROID:

 

  • Skin thinning and Striae (atrophy)
  • Telangiectasias
  • Ecchymosis and easy bruising
  • Rosacea
  • Opportunistic infections (folliculitis, tinea incognito)
  • Induced acne (steroid acne/ acneiform eruption) and hypertrichosis (Increased hair growth)
  • Decreased pigmentation and Delayed wound healing

 

Atrophy (2), acneiform eruption (3), and hypertrichosis (4) are all documented side effects of topical corticosteroids.

 

Incorrect Option:

 

Blue grey discoloration of skin (1): Not caused by topical steroids. Associated with drugs like minocycline and amiodarone or post-inflammatory dermal pigmentation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Topical corticosteroids cause atrophy, acneiform eruptions, and hypertrichosis, but not blue-grey skin discoloration.

 

Note -

 

Class of Drugs Causing Bluish-Grey Discoloration of Skin (Ceruloderma)

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct? (INICET MAY 2025)

 

  1. Epidermis can regenerate from deeper follicular cells such as hair follicles and sebaceous glands 
  2. Stratum corneum is the outermost cellular layer
  3. Epidermis is ectodermal in origin 
  4. Dermis and hypodermis are endodermal in origin
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a and c

 

  • Statement a is correct: The epidermis has stem cells located at three sites - interfollicular stem cells in stratum basale, stem cells at the base of sebaceous glands, and stem cells at the bulge of hair follicles (where erector pili muscle attaches). These stem cells help regenerate the epidermis after injury.
  • Statement c is correct: The epidermis is derived from ectoderm during embryonic development.

 

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

  • Statement b is incorrect: Stratum corneum is the outermost layer but it is ACELLULAR (anucleate), not cellular. It consists of dead, keratinized cells without nuclei or metabolism.
  • Statement d is incorrect: Dermis and hypodermis are derived from MESODERM, not endoderm. However, the dermis of face and frontal scalp specifically are derived from neural crest.

 

Educational Objective: 


Epidermis regenerates from stem cells in hair follicles and sebaceous glands and is ectodermal in origin; stratum corneum is acellular, and dermis/hypodermis are mesodermal.

questions.text: A 24-year-old sexually active male presents to the outpatient department with complaints of painful urination and a thick yellow urethral discharge for the past 3 days. He denies any fever, chills, or flank pain. He reports multiple unprotected sexual encounters in the past one week. A urethral swab is sent for Gram stain, which shows intracellular gram-negative diplococci within polymorphonuclear leukocytes. On culture for antimicrobial sensitivity, the organism shows resistance to penicillin's. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ceftriaxone

 

This patient has gonococcal urethritis caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. The key features include:

 

  • Short incubation period (3 days after sexual contact)
  • Purulent urethral discharge with severe dysuria
  • Gram-negative intracellular diplococci in PMNs
  • Penicillin resistance

 

The current CDC 2021 guidelines recommend ceftriaxone as first-line treatment for uncomplicated gonococcal infection of the cervix, urethra or rectum:

 

  • For Patient weight <150 kg: 500 mg IM, single dose
  • For patient weight â‰¥150 kg: 1 gm IM single dose is advised.
  • Always add doxycycline 100 mg BD Ã— 7 days for possible chlamydial co-infection (dual therapy)

 

Other Scenarios: 

 

  • For Cephalosporin allergy â€“ Give Gentamicin 240 mg IM single dose + Azithromycin 2gm orally single dose.
  • If Ceftriaxone is unavailable â€“ Give Cefixime 800mg orally, single dose + Doxycycline 100 mg orally BD for 7 days. (Kit no 8 â€“ for Anorectal Discharge Syndromeâ€“ Brown color kit)      

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amoxicillin: Will also be ineffective due to penicillin resistance

 

Option C. Vancomycin: Only effective against gram-positive organisms, not gram-negative gonococci

 

Option D. Tetracycline: Used for non-gonococcal urethritis (chlamydia), not as monotherapy for gonorrhea

 

Educational Objective: 


Gonococcal urethritis is diagnosed by gram-negative intracellular diplococci and treated with ceftriaxone plus doxycycline (dual therapy).

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA) is incorrect? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Biopsy done under L/A

 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a highly vascular benign tumor that exclusively affects adolescent males. Biopsy is absolutely contraindicated in JNA because it is a vascular tumor with absent contractile muscular components in blood vessel walls. Any attempt to perform a biopsy (whether punch biopsy, needle biopsy, or any other form) will result in profuse, uncontrollable bleeding that is extremely difficult to manage. This is a fundamental in managing vascular tumors - never biopsy suspected JNA, glomus tumors, or hemangiomas.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Recurrent epistaxis: This is correct for JNA. Profuse, recurrent nosebleeds are the hallmark presentation of JNA, often described as heavy nasal bleeding that cannot be controlled by regular clinical measures.

 

Option B. Unilateral nasal obstruction: This is correct for JNA. The tumor typically causes progressive nasal obstruction, which can be unilateral initially but may become bilateral as the tumor grows.

 

Option C. Exclusively adolescent male: This is correct for JNA. This tumor has a unique demographic pattern, occurring only in adolescent males, making this a pathognomonic feature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Biopsy is contraindicated in juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma due to risk of uncontrollable hemorrhage.



Note -

questions.text:
Cochlear implantation is not indicated in which of the following conditions? (INICET MAY 2025)

 

  1. Otosclerosis
  2. Congenital hearing loss
  3. Fixed malleus
  4. Ototoxicity induced hearing loss
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 & 3

 

Cochlear implantation is not indicated in otosclerosis and fixed malleus because these are conductive hearing loss conditions that can be effectively treated with surgical correction. Cochlear implants are designed specifically for sensorineural hearing loss where the cochlear hair cells are damaged but the auditory nerve remains intact.

 

1. Otosclerosis: Otosclerosis involves abnormal bone growth around the stapes footplate, causing fixation and conductive hearing loss. This condition is best treated with stapedectomy or stapedotomy, which directly addresses the mechanical problem by replacing or bypassing the fixed stapes. Success rates for stapedectomy exceed 90% for hearing improvement.

 

3. Fixed malleus: Fixed malleus also causes conductive hearing loss due to mechanical fixation of the ossicular chain. This condition is treated with ossiculoplasty or malleus fixation release procedures that restore normal sound transmission through the middle ear. These surgical interventions directly correct the underlying mechanical problem and can restore near-normal hearing.

 

Incorrect Options:

 

2. Congenital hearing loss: Cochlear implant IS indicated here. This is actually a major indication for cochlear implantation, especially for pre-lingual deaf children (age limit 6 years) where hearing aid trial for 6 months shows no improvement in speech development.

 

4. Ototoxicity induced hearing loss: Cochlear implant IS indicated here. Ototoxic drugs like aminoglycosides (neomycin, gentamicin), chemotherapy agents (cisplatin, carboplatin), diuretics (furosemide, bumetanide), and antimalarials (quinine, chloroquine) cause permanent damage to outer hair cells in the cochlea. When this damage is severe and irreversible, cochlear implantation is the treatment of choice.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Cochlear implants are contraindicated in middle ear pathologies that can be surgically corrected.

questions.text:
Which of the following conditions are potential causes of stridor in a newborn? (INICET MAY 2025)

 

  1. Laryngomalacia
  2. Subglottic stenosis
  3. Papilloma
  4. Hemorrhagic polyp
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 & 2

 

Stridor in newborns is primarily caused by congenital airway abnormalities that compromise the airway from birth. 

 

1. Laryngomalacia: Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital anomaly of the larynx and the most common cause of stridor in infants. It presents with inspiratory stridor due to excessively flaccid supraglottis that collapses during inspiration. 

 

2. Subglottic stenosis: Subglottic stenosis also causes stridor in newborns because the subglottis is the narrowest part of the airway in children, and any further narrowing causes significant airway compromise, resulting in biphasic stridor.



Other Options:

 

3. Papilloma: This typically presents in children aged 3-5 years, not in newborns. Although caused by HPV infection acquired during birth through the vaginal canal, the clinical presentation occurs years later, not in the neonatal period.

 

4. Hemorrhagic polyp: This appears on the vocal cord surface and primarily causes hoarseness of voice rather than stridor. It does not cause sufficient airway obstruction to produce stridor in newborns.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Laryngomalacia and subglottic stenosis are the primary causes of stridor in newborns.

questions.text: While attempting to remove a fish bone lodged in the pyriform fossa, injury to which of the following nerves is most likely? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Internal laryngeal

 

The pyriform fossa is part of the hypopharynx (laryngopharynx) and is located lateral to the arytenoid cartilages. 

 

The key anatomical landmark for understanding nerve supply in this region is the level of the vocal cords. The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve supplies the mucosa above the level of the vocal cords, while the recurrent laryngeal nerve supplies the mucosa below this level. Since the pyriform fossa is positioned lateral to the arytenoids and at the level of or slightly above the vocal cords, it receives sensory innervation from the internal laryngeal nerve.

 


 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Vagus: While the internal laryngeal nerve is a branch of the vagus nerve, the specific nerve innervating the pyriform fossa is the internal laryngeal branch, making this answer too general.

 

Option C. Recurrent laryngeal: This nerve supplies structures below the level of the vocal cords, including the post-cricoid area and lower portions of the hypopharynx, but not the pyriform fossa.

 

Option D. Glossopharyngeal: This nerve primarily supplies the oropharynx, posterior third of the tongue, and tonsillar region, not the hypopharyngeal structures like the pyriform fossa.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The pyriform fossa receives sensory innervation from the internal laryngeal nerve.

questions.text: A patient presents with vertigo and vomiting that is consistently triggered by turning in bed or changing head position. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vestibular neuritis

 

The combination of vertigo with vomiting triggered by positional changes is characteristic of vestibular neuritis. While BPPV also causes positional vertigo, it typically presents with vertigo alone without significant nausea and vomiting. Vestibular neuritis involves infection or inflammation of the vestibular nerve, and because these neural tracts are connected to the chemoreceptor trigger zone and vomiting centers in the brainstem, patients experience both severe vertigo and associated nausea/vomiting with head movements.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. BPPV: Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo typically causes only vertigo on positional change without significant vomiting. It results from displaced otoconia in the semicircular canals causing brief episodes of vertigo.

 

Option C. MÃ©niÃ¨re's disease: This presents with a tetrad of symptoms: vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss (fluctuating), aural fullness, and tinnitus (VAST). The question doesn't mention hearing loss or ear fullness.

 

Option D. Labyrinthitis: This condition presents with vertigo plus sensorineural hearing loss but typically doesn't emphasize the positional component or prominent vomiting seen in vestibular neuritis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Vestibular neuritis presents with positional vertigo accompanied by nausea and vomiting.

questions.text: A child presents with trismus and painful limb spasms following a recent untreated ear infection. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tetanus

 

This presentation describes otogenic tetanus, a rare but serious complication of ear infections. The combination of trismus (difficulty opening mouth) and limb spasms following an ear infection is pathognomonic for tetanus. The tetanus organism (Clostridium tetani) can invade through the infected ear, particularly when there is tympanic membrane perforation. The bacteria enter the middle ear space, get absorbed systemically, and release neurotoxins that affect the muscular system, causing the characteristic muscle spasms and lockjaw. Early treatment with tetanus immunoglobulin is crucial - if untreated, mortality approaches 100%, but early intervention can achieve 80% success rates.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Meningitis: While this can be a complication of ear infections, it typically presents with neck stiffness, headache, fever, and altered consciousness rather than the specific combination of trismus and limb spasms.

 

Option C. Sigmoid sinus thrombosis: This complication presents with hectic fever, Griesinger sign (mastoid edema), and increased intracranial pressure, not with muscle spasms and trismus.

 

Option D. Bezold's abscess: This is a deep neck abscess that tracks along the sternocleidomastoid muscle, presenting as neck swelling and pain, not with neuromuscular symptoms.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Otogenic tetanus presents with trismus and muscle spasms following ear infection and requires immediate tetanus immunoglobulin therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following drug is used to reverse muscle relaxation induced by vecuronium? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neostigmine

 

Neostigmine is the anticholinesterase of choice for reversing neuromuscular blockade caused by vecuronium. When neuromuscular blockade needs to be reversed at the end of surgery, approximately 80% of acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction are already free of vecuronium molecules. The remaining blockade can be reversed by increasing the acetylcholine concentration at the neuromuscular junction.
