The logic "Lord Hanuman was celibate, I am celibate, therefore I am Lord Hanuman" is fundamentally flawed and represents the kind of illogical reasoning seen in autistic thinking.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Verbigeration: This is verbal stereotypy involving spontaneous, purposeless repetition of phrases or sentences for extended periods, which is not demonstrated here.

 

Option C. Neologism: This involves creating new words whose meaning or derivation cannot be understood (e.g., calling a pencil "tintintapa"), which is not present in this example.

 

Option D. Loosening of Association: This formal thought disorder involves the first half of a sentence being unrelated to the second half, which is not the case here as the sentence flows logically (though the logic is flawed).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Autistic thinking involves illogical, fantasy-based reasoning where entities are considered identical based on sharing a single property (Von Domarus law).

choices.text: Buprenorphine can be used for the management of opioid withdrawal
Flumazenil is used for the management of long-term management of alcohol dependence syndrome
Cannabis withdrawal is associated with minimal physical symptoms

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct except: (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Flumazenil is used for the management of long-term management of alcohol dependence syndrome

 

Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine receptor antagonist used specifically for benzodiazepine overdose/toxicity, not for alcohol dependence syndrome management. It reverses the effects of benzodiazepines by competitively blocking benzodiazepine receptors. It has no role in the long-term management of alcohol dependence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Opioid withdrawal is rarely fatal: This is correct. Unlike alcohol withdrawal (which can cause fatal delirium tremens), opioid withdrawal, while extremely uncomfortable, is rarely life-threatening.

 

Option B. Buprenorphine can be used for opioid withdrawal: This is correct. Buprenorphine (along with methadone) is used for opioid replacement therapy and withdrawal management.

 

Option D. Cannabis withdrawal has minimal physical symptoms: This is correct. Cannabis withdrawal primarily presents with psychological symptoms (irritability, depression, anxiety) with minimal physical manifestations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine receptor antagonist used for benzodiazepine overdose, not for alcohol dependence management.

choices.text: Alcohol in low dose causes brain stimulation and in higher doses, causes brain suppression
Cannabis use can result in self-driven, repetitive behaviours
Volatile Inhalational agents are mostly toxic to humans

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alcohol in low dose causes brain stimulation and in higher doses, causes brain suppression

 

Alcohol is a CNS depressant at all dosages. The statement that alcohol causes brain stimulation at low doses is pharmacologically incorrect. While behaviorally people may appear disinhibited, excited, or stimulated at lower doses of alcohol (singing, laughing, talking excessively), this occurs because alcohol initially inhibits the inhibitory centers of the brain. This "inhibition of inhibition" leads to apparent behavioral excitation, but the underlying pharmacological effect remains CNS depression. As the dose increases, the depressant effects become more obvious with sedation, stupor, and eventually coma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cannabis use can result in self-driven, repetitive behaviours â€“ CORRECT- Cannabis dependence leads to repetitive drug-seeking behaviors including procuring the drug, visiting dealers, using the substance, and spending money repeatedly in a cycle. This represents the compulsive, self-driven repetitive pattern seen in substance dependence.

 

Option C. Opioids are very effective analgesics â€“ CORRECT- Opioids are among the most potent and effective analgesics available in medicine. They work by binding to opioid receptors in the CNS and are considered the gold standard for severe pain management.

 

Option D. Volatile Inhalational agents are mostly toxic to humans â€“ CORRECT- Volatile inhalational agents (like toluene, gasoline vapors) can cause significant toxicity including brain damage, cardiac arrhythmias, and sudden death. They are indeed toxic to humans with chronic use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alcohol is a CNS depressant at all dosages; apparent behavioral stimulation at low doses occurs due to disinhibition of inhibitory brain centers, not true CNS stimulation.

choices.text: Low mood for most of the day
Loss of interest in pleasurable things

questions.text: Which of the following is not an ICD-10 diagnostic criterion for Depression? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Low self-esteem and confidence

 

ICD-10 classifies depressive symptoms into two distinct categories: core symptoms and other common symptoms. 

 

The three core symptoms that define depression according to ICD-10 are:

 

  1. Depressed mood, 
  2. Loss of interest and enjoyment, and 
  3. Reduced energy leading to increased fatigability and diminished activity.

 

Low self-esteem and confidence, while being a recognized symptom of depression, is classified under "other common symptoms" in ICD-10 rather than being a core diagnostic criterion. 

 

The ICD-10 requires the presence of at least two core symptoms for a diagnosis of depression, making the distinction between core and additional symptoms clinically significant for diagnostic purposes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low energy levels: This is incorrect as an answer choice because reduced energy leading to increased fatigability and diminished activity is one of the three core symptoms in ICD-10 diagnostic criteria for depression. This symptom is fundamental to the diagnosis and must be present along with at least one other core symptom.

 

Option B. Low mood for most of the day: This is incorrect as an answer choice because depressed mood is the primary and most characteristic core symptom in ICD-10 criteria for depression. It refers to persistent and pervasive sadness that is present for most of the day, nearly every day, and represents a clear departure from the person's normal mood state.

 

Option C. Loss of interest in pleasurable things: This is incorrect as an answer choice because loss of interest and enjoyment (anhedonia) is one of the three core symptoms in ICD-10. This symptom involves the inability to experience pleasure from activities that were previously enjoyable and is considered essential for depression diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ICD-10 classifies depression symptoms into three core symptoms (depressed mood, loss of interest/enjoyment, reduced energy) and other common symptoms, with low self-esteem being classified as an "other common symptom" rather than a core diagnostic criterion.

 

Note:

 

â€œSIGECAPSSâ€ mnemonic for Depression (DSM IV)

 

  • S â€“ Sadness of mood
  • I â€“ Loss of Interest
  • G â€“ Guilt
  • E â€“ Low energy levels
  • C â€“ Poor concentration and cognition (negative thoughts)
  • A â€“ Appetite changes (usually decreased, but may also increase)
  • P â€“ Psychomotor agitation or retardation
  • S â€“ Sleep disturbances (often insomnia, but may also involve excessive sleep)
  • S â€“ Suicidal thoughts

 

ICD-10 Depressive Episode â€“ Common Features

 

A person typically experiences depressed mood, loss of interest and enjoyment, and reduced energy, which can lead to increased fatigue and diminished activity. Even small efforts may cause marked tiredness.

 

Other common symptoms include:

 

  • Reduced concentration and attention
  • Reduced self-esteem and self-confidence
  • Feelings of guilt and worthlessness (even in mild cases)
  • Bleak and pessimistic views of the future
  • Thoughts or acts of self-harm or suicide
  • Disturbed sleep
  • Diminished appetite

questions.text: Which of the following new psychoactive agent results in rapid onset of action in the management of depression? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ketamine

 

Ketamine, specifically S-ketamine (es ketamine), represents a revolutionary breakthrough in depression treatment due to its uniquely rapid onset of action. When clinicians encounter questions about rapid onset of action in depression management, the two primary considerations are electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) and ketamine, with ketamine being the newer pharmacological option.

 

S-ketamine nasal spray is FDA-approved for treatment-resistant depression, which is defined as the lack of response to two different antidepressants given for adequate duration in adequate dosages. The mechanism of action differs fundamentally from traditional antidepressants - ketamine works as an NMDA receptor antagonist rather than through monoamine pathways, allowing for antidepressant effects within hours to days rather than weeks.

 

Initially approved as adjunctive therapy to be used alongside existing antidepressants, S-ketamine received expanded FDA approval in January 2025 for use as monotherapy, meaning it can now be used as a standalone treatment for treatment-resistant depression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cannabinoids: These substances do not have established evidence for rapid-onset antidepressant effects in clinical practice. While some research exists on cannabinoids and mood disorders, they are not recognized as first-line or rapid-acting treatments for depression.

 

Option C. Bupropion: This is a well-established atypical antidepressant classified as a norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibitor (NDRI). While bupropion has advantages such as minimal sexual side effects and lower risk of weight gain, it follows the typical antidepressant timeline with onset of action occurring over 1-2 weeks for initial effects and 4-6 weeks for maximum therapeutic benefit. It does not provide the rapid onset characteristic of ketamine.

 

Option D. Mephedrone: This is a synthetic stimulant and recreational drug, not an approved antidepressant medication. Mephedrone is associated with significant abuse potential and adverse effects, and has no legitimate clinical use in depression management. It would not be considered a therapeutic psychoactive agent for depression treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

S-ketamine (es ketamine) is the first FDA-approved antidepressant with rapid onset of action (hours to days) for treatment-resistant depression, working through NMDA receptor antagonism and now approved both as adjunctive therapy and monotherapy.

questions.text: In a village with 100 children, 10 had developed measles in the previous year. In the current year, 20 children developed measles for the first time. What is the incidence rate of measles for the current year? [INICET MAY 2025]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 22.2%

 

To calculate the incidence rate, we use the formula:

 

Incidence Rate = (Number of new cases / Total population at risk) Ã— 1000

 

In this question:

 

  • New cases this year: 20 children developed measles for the first time
  • Total population: 100 children
  • Population NOT at risk: 10 children who had measles the previous year

 

The key concept here is understanding "population at risk." Children who had measles previously are no longer susceptible because measles infection provides lifelong immunity. Therefore, these 10 children are not at risk of developing measles again.

 

Population at risk = Total population - Immune population
Population at risk = 100 - 10 = 90 children

 

Calculation:
 

Incidence Rate = (20/90) Ã— 100 = 22.22%

 

This represents the rate of new measles cases among the susceptible population during the specified time period.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Incidence rate measures the frequency of NEW cases of a disease among the population at risk during a specific time period, excluding individuals who are no longer susceptible due to previous infection or immunization.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a High-risk group for HIV? [INICET MAY 2025]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Long distance truck drivers (LDTD)

 

Long distance truck drivers are classified as bridge population because they facilitate HIV transmission from high-risk groups to the general population through their mobility and behavioral patterns, but they are not inherently at the highest risk level.

 

For HIV/AIDS epidemiology, the World Health Organization and public health experts classify populations into three distinct categories based on their risk of HIV acquisition and transmission:

 

1. HIGH-RISK POPULATION (Core Groups): These groups have the highest probability of acquiring and transmitting HIV due to their behavioral patterns and practices:

 

  • Commercial Sex Workers (CSW) - High number of sexual partners, often inconsistent condom use
  • Men having Sex with Men (MSM) - Higher transmission risk through anal intercourse
  • Injecting Drug Users (IDU) - Needle sharing practices lead to direct blood-to-blood transmission
  • Trafficked women and transgender individuals

 

2. BRIDGE POPULATION (Intermediate Risk): These groups act as a link between high-risk and general populations, facilitating HIV spread:

 

  • Long Distance Truck Drivers (LDTD) - Mobile lifestyle, away from families for extended periods
  • Clients of Commercial Sex Workers - Connect high-risk CSW with general population
  • Partners of Injecting Drug Users
  • Migrant and mobile populations
  • Populations in conflict situations

 

3. GENERAL POPULATION (Low Risk):

 

  • Married women and men
  • Children and youth
  • General community members

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Injecting drug users (IDU): Incorrect. IDU represents one of the highest risk groups for HIV transmission. Sharing contaminated needles and syringes leads to direct blood-to-blood transmission, making this group extremely vulnerable. The risk is further amplified by potential engagement in risky sexual behaviors to obtain drugs.

 

Option B. Men having sex with men (MSM): Incorrect. MSM constitutes a high-risk group due to biological factors (anal intercourse has higher transmission risk than vaginal intercourse), behavioral factors (multiple partnerships), and social factors (stigma leading to reduced access to prevention services). This group remains disproportionately affected by HIV globally.

 

Option C. Commercial sex workers (CSW): Incorrect. CSW are at extremely high risk due to multiple sexual partners, inconsistent condom use, power imbalances with clients, substance abuse, and often limited access to healthcare services. They serve as a core transmitter group in HIV epidemiology models.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HIV risk group classification divides populations into High-risk (core groups with highest transmission probability), Bridge populations (intermediate risk groups that connect high-risk and general populations), and General population (lowest risk), with long distance truck drivers classified as bridge population, not high-risk group.

questions.text: In a given population of a town, 6000 were below the age of 15 years. At the same time, there were 2000 above the age of 65 years. A total of 12000 were earning members in the town. Calculate the dependency ratio? [INICET MAY 2025]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 0.66

 

  • The Dependency Ratio is a socioeconomic indicator that measures the ratio of non-earning (dependent) population to the earning (productive) population. 
  • It indicates how many non-productive individuals are supported by each productive member of society.

 

Formula: Dependency Ratio = Non-earning Population / Earning Population

 

Components:

 

  • Non-earning Population: Includes children (<15 years) + elderly (>65 years)
  • Earning Population: Working age population (15-65 years)

 

Given data:

 

  • Population below 15 years = 6,000
  • Population above 65 years = 2,000
  • Earning members (15-65 years) = 12,000

 

Calculation: Non-earning Population = <15 years + >65 years
 

Non-earning Population = 6,000 + 2,000 = 8,000

 

Dependency Ratio = Non-earning Population / Earning Population
 

Dependency Ratio = 8,000 / 12,000 = 2/3 = 0.66

 

Interpretation: A dependency ratio of 0.66 means:

 

  • For every 100 earning members, there are 66 dependents
  • Every 3 earning people support 2 dependents
  • 66% of the earning population represents the dependent burden

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dependency ratio measures the economic burden on the productive population by calculating the ratio of non-earning population (children under 15 and elderly over 65) to the working-age population (15-65 years), expressed as dependents per earning member.

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps in correct sequence for conducting a research? [INICET MAY 2025]

 

  1. Finalise research setting
  2. Selecting population
  3. Setting research question
  4. Setting research objective
questions.solution:
Ans. (d)  3-4-1-2

 

The correct sequence for conducting research follows a logical progression from conceptualization to implementation:

 

Step 1: Setting Research Question (3)

 

  • This is the foundation of any research project
  • Defines WHAT you want to study
  • Example: "Does smoking cause lung cancer?"
  • Must be specific, measurable, and researchable
  • Forms the basis for all subsequent decisions

 

Step 2: Setting Research Objective (4)

 

  • Defines the specific goals and purposes of the study
  • Specifies WHAT you want to achieve through this research
  • Example: "To determine the association between smoking and lung cancer incidence"
  • Can include primary and secondary objectives
  • Directly flows from the research question

 

Step 3: Finalise Research Setting (1)

 

  • Determines WHERE and HOW the study will be conducted
  • Includes selecting study design (cohort, case-control, cross-sectional, etc.)
  • Decides methodology and data collection techniques
  • Example: "Conduct a cohort study in urban hospitals over 5 years"
  • Depends on the research question and objectives

 

Step 4: Selecting Population (2)

 

  • Identifies WHO will be included in the study
  • Defines inclusion and exclusion criteria
  • Selects study subjects based on the chosen design
  • Example: "Smokers and non-smokers aged 40-65 years" (for cohort study)
  • Must align with research setting and methodology

 

This logical sequence ensures that each step builds upon the previous one, creating a coherent and well-planned research protocol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Research methodology follows a systematic sequence: Research Question â†’ Research Objectives â†’ Research Setting/Design â†’ Population Selection, ensuring each step logically builds upon the previous one to create a scientifically sound study protocol.

questions.text: Match the following vectors with their most commonly associated Rickettsial diseases: [INICET MAY 2025]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 1-C, 2-D, 3-A, 4-B

 

Rickettsial diseases are transmitted by various arthropod vectors. Each vector has specific rickettsial diseases associated with it:

 

1. Tick â†’ C-RMSF (Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever)

 

  • Vectors: Hard ticks (Dermacentor species, Rhipicephalus sanguineus)
  • Causative organism: Rickettsia rickettsii
  • Disease: Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever (RMSF)
  • Also transmits: Indian Tick Typhus (R. conorii)
  • Geographic distribution: Americas, Mediterranean spotted fever globally

 

2. Mite â†’ D-Rickettsial pox

 

  • Vectors: House mouse mites (Liponyssoides sanguineus)
  • Causative organism: Rickettsia akari
  • Disease: Rickettsial pox
  • Characteristics: Mild, self-limiting disease with vesicular rash
  • Also important: Trombiculid mites transmit scrub typhus (though not in this list)

 

3. Louse â†’ A-Epidemic typhus

 

  • Vector: Human body louse (Pediculus humanus corporis)
  • Causative organism: Rickettsia prowazekii
  • Disease: Epidemic typhus (louse-borne typhus)
  • Characteristics: Severe, potentially fatal disease
  • Epidemiology: Associated with overcrowding, poor hygiene, war conditions

 

4. Flea â†’ B-Endemic typhus

 

  • Vector: Oriental rat flea (Xenopsylla cheopis)
  • Causative organism: Rickettsia typhi
  • Disease: Endemic typhus (murine typhus, flea-borne typhus)
  • Reservoir: Rats and other rodents
  • Characteristics: Milder than epidemic typhus

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each rickettsial disease has a specific arthropod vector: Ticks transmit RMSF and spotted fevers, mites transmit rickettsial pox, lice transmit epidemic typhus, and fleas transmit endemic (murine) typhus.

questions.text: Which of the following statistical terms is incorrectly matched with its associated concept? [INICET MAY 2025]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Mean, Median: Dispersion

 

Mean and Median are measures of CENTRAL TENDENCY, NOT dispersion.

 

Central Tendency Measures:

 

  • Mean: Average value of all observations
  • Median: Middle value when data is arranged in order
  • Mode: Most frequently occurring value

 

These measures tell us about the center or typical value of a distribution.

 

Dispersion/Variability Measures:

 

  • Standard Deviation (SD): Average deviation from the mean
  • Variance: Square of standard deviation
  • Range: Difference between maximum and minimum values
  • Interquartile Range (IQR): Range of middle 50% of data
  • Coefficient of Variation: Relative measure of variability

 

These measures tell us about the spread or scatter of data around the central value.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Standard error: Variability: Correct. Standard error measures the variability or precision of a sample statistic (usually the sample mean). It indicates how much sample means would vary if we repeated the sampling process multiple times. It's calculated as SD/âˆšn and is indeed a measure of variability.

 

Option B. Coefficient of correlation: Relationship: Correct. The coefficient of correlation (Pearson's â€œrâ€) measures the strength and direction of linear relationship between two quantitative variables. Values range from -1 to +1, where -1 indicates perfect negative correlation, +1 indicates perfect positive correlation, and 0 indicates no linear relationship.

 

Option C. Moments: Skewness: Correct. Moments are mathematical measures that describe different characteristics of a probability distribution:

 

  • First moment: Mean (central tendency)
  • Second moment: Variance (dispersion)
  • Third moment: Skewness (asymmetry)
  • Fourth moment: Kurtosis (peakedness of distribution)

 

The third moment about the mean is specifically used to calculate skewness, which measures the asymmetry of the distribution.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Statistical measures are classified into specific categories: Mean and median are measures of central tendency (not dispersion), while standard deviation, variance, and range are measures of dispersion that quantify the spread of data around the central value.

questions.text: You are a medical officer at PHC collecting data for disease burden in your catchment population. You divide diseased population into mild, moderate and severe groups. And then few are selected from each group for the study. This is which type of sampling? [INICET MAY 2025]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Stratified random sampling

 

The scenario describes Stratified Random Sampling perfectly. This sampling method involves:

 

Key Steps in Stratified Sampling:

 

  1. Stratification: Divide the heterogeneous population into homogeneous subgroups (strata)
  2. Random Selection: Select samples randomly from each stratum
  3. Representation: Ensure all important subgroups are represented in the final sample

 

In this question:

 

  • Population: Diseased population in catchment area
  • Stratification: Division into mild, moderate, and severe disease groups
  • Sampling: Few selected from each group (stratum)

 

 

Advantages of Stratified Sampling:

 

  • Ensures representation of all disease severity levels
  • More precise estimates for each subgroup
  • Can compare disease burden across severity levels
  • Reduces sampling bias
  • More efficient than simple random sampling when strata are truly different

 

When to use Stratified Sampling:

 

  • When population has distinct subgroups
  • When you want to ensure representation of all subgroups
  • When subgroups have different characteristics (like disease severity)
  • For comparative studies across different categories

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Simple random sampling: Incorrect. In simple random sampling, every individual in the population has an equal chance of being selected without any grouping or stratification. You would randomly select from the entire diseased population without considering disease severity. This method doesn't guarantee representation of mild, moderate, and severe cases.

 

Option B. Systematic random sampling: Incorrect. Systematic sampling involves selecting every kth element after a random starting point. For example, if you have 1000 patients and need 100, you'd select every 10th patient after randomly choosing the first one. This method doesn't involve dividing the population into severity groups.

 

Option D. Cluster random sampling: Incorrect. Cluster sampling involves dividing the population into naturally occurring groups (clusters), usually geographic areas like villages or blocks. You then randomly select entire clusters and study all individuals within selected clusters, or sample within selected clusters. Disease severity groups are not natural clusters but artificially created strata.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stratified random sampling involves dividing a heterogeneous population into homogeneous subgroups (strata) based on specific characteristics, then randomly sampling from each stratum to ensure representation of all important subgroups in the study.

questions.text: Which legislation is responsible for ensuring the security and confidentiality of medical records? [INICET MAY 2025]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) DPDP

 

The Digital Personal Data Protection Act (DPDP) 2023 is the legislation responsible for maintaining data security of medical records in India.

 

Key Features of DPDP Act 2023:

 

1. Valid Consent Requirements:

 

  • Patients must provide informed and explicit consent for data processing
  • Consent must be specific, clear, and freely given
  • Right to withdraw consent at any time

 

2. Security Safeguards:

 

  • Healthcare providers must implement appropriate technical and organizational measures
  • Data encryption, access controls, and secure storage requirements
  • Regular security audits and risk assessments

 

3. Breach Notification:

 

  • Immediate notification to Data Protection Authority in case of data breaches
  • Notification to affected patients when breach poses risk
  • Mandatory reporting timelines and procedures

 

4. Patient Rights:

 

  • Right to access their medical data
  • Right to correction of inaccurate data
  • Right to data portability
  • Right to erasure under specific circumstances

 

5. Data Limitation and Retention:

 

  • Data collection must be limited to specific, legitimate purposes
  • Medical records can only be retained for necessary duration
  • Clear data retention policies required

 

6. Data Protection Officer:

 

  • Large healthcare institutions must appoint Data Protection Officers
  • Responsible for compliance monitoring and patient grievance handling

 

Application to Medical Records:

 

  • All digital medical records fall under DPDP Act
  • Electronic Health Records (EHR) systems must comply
  • Telemedicine platforms and health apps are covered
  • Hospital management systems require compliance

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HIPAA: Incorrect. HIPAA (Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act) is a United States federal law enacted in 1996. It establishes data protection and privacy provisions for medical information in the US healthcare system. This law does not apply to India and Indian medical institutions.

 

Option C. MTP: Incorrect. MTP refers to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act, which governs the legal aspects of abortion in India. This act deals with the conditions and procedures for pregnancy termination, not data security or privacy of medical records.

 

Option D. PCPNDT: Incorrect. PCPNDT stands for Pre-Conception and Pre-Natal Diagnostic Techniques (Prohibition of Sex Selection) Act. This law prohibits sex determination tests and sex selection practices to prevent female foeticide. It does not address data security or privacy of medical records.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Digital Personal Data Protection Act (DPDP) 2023 is India's comprehensive data protection legislation that governs the security, privacy, and processing of personal data including medical records, establishing patient rights, consent requirements, and security obligations for healthcare providers.

questions.text: Which infection is most commonly transmitted during the third trimester of pregnancy? [INICET MAY 2025]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Toxoplasmosis

 

Maternal-fetal transmission of infections varies significantly by gestational age, with different pathogens having peak transmission rates during specific trimesters.

 

Third Trimester Transmission Patterns:

 

Toxoplasmosis shows the highest maternal-fetal transmission rate during the third trimester:

 

  • 1st trimester: ~15% transmission rate (but most severe consequences)
  • 2nd trimester: ~30% transmission rate
  • 3rd trimester: ~60-70% transmission rate (highest transmission, but milder disease)

 

Mechanism: As pregnancy progresses, placental permeability increases and maternal immune suppression deepens, facilitating transmission of certain pathogens like Toxoplasma gondii.

 

Clinical Significance:

 

  • Third trimester toxoplasmosis typically causes milder fetal disease
  • Most infections are asymptomatic at birth
  • May cause chorioretinitis, intracranial calcifications, or hydrocephalus
  • Maternal screening and treatment can reduce transmission risk

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herpes simplex infection: Incorrect. Herpes simplex virus (HSV) transmission to the fetus occurs primarily during delivery (intrapartum transmission), not during the third trimester. The risk is highest when there are active genital lesions at the time of delivery. Intrauterine transmission is rare and accounts for less than 5% of neonatal HSV infections.

 

Option C. Rubella: Incorrect. Rubella has the highest transmission risk and most severe consequences during the first trimester (>90% transmission rate in first 12 weeks). The risk of congenital rubella syndrome decreases dramatically with advancing gestational age. Third trimester infection rarely causes congenital abnormalities and transmission rates are much lower.

 

Option D. Parvovirus B19: Incorrect. Parvovirus B19 has relatively consistent transmission rates throughout pregnancy, but the highest risk for fetal complication

 

Educational Objective:

 

Toxoplasmosis demonstrates the highest maternal-fetal transmission rate during the third trimester of pregnancy (~60-70%), following the pattern where transmission risk increases with advancing gestational age while disease severity decreases.

 

Note:

 

  • MC & Most dangerous infection transmitted during 1st trimester â€“ Rubella
  • Infection transmitted during 2nd trimester â€“ Varicella and Parvovirus 
  • Infection transmitted during 3rd trimester â€“ CMV, Syphilis, Toxoplasmosis
  • Infection transmitted at the time of delivery â€“ HIV, Herpes, Hep B and Hepatitis C.

questions.text: Quartiles, Tertiles are measures of which of the following? [INICET MAY 2025]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Locations

 

Quartiles and tertiles are measures of location (also called measures of position). They indicate the position or location of values within a data distribution.

 

Quartiles:

 

  • Divide the dataset into four equal parts
  • Q1 (First Quartile): 25th percentile - 25% of data falls below this value
  • Q2 (Second Quartile): 50th percentile - same as median, 50% of data falls below
  • Q3 (Third Quartile): 75th percentile - 75% of data falls below this value

 

 

Tertiles:

 

  • Divide the dataset into three equal parts
  • T1 (First Tertile): 33.33rd percentile - 33.33% of data falls below this value
  • T2 (Second Tertile): 66.67th percentile - 66.67% of data falls below this value

 

 

Other Position Measures:

 

  • Percentiles: Divide data into 100 equal parts
  • Deciles: Divide data into 10 equal parts
  • Quintiles: Divide data into 5 equal parts

 

Purpose: These measures tell us WHERE a particular value stands in relation to the rest of the data. For example, if a student's score is at Q3, it means 75% of students scored below that student.

 

Applications:

 

  • Growth charts in pediatrics (height/weight percentiles)
  • Performance evaluation (salary quartiles)
  • Risk assessment (blood pressure percentiles)
  • Academic grading (class rank positions)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dispersion: Incorrect. Dispersion measures describe the spread or scatter of data around the central value. Examples include:

 

  • Standard deviation
  • Variance
  • Range
  • Interquartile range (IQR = Q3 - Q1) While quartiles can be used to calculate IQR (a dispersion measure), quartiles themselves are position measures.

 

Option B. Central tendency: Incorrect. Central tendency measures describe the center or typical value of a dataset. Examples include:

 

  • Mean (arithmetic average)
  • Median (middle value)
  • Mode (most frequent value) Note: Q2 (second quartile) equals the median, but quartiles as a group are not central tendency measures.

 

Option D. Correlation: Incorrect. Correlation measures describe the relationship between two variables. Examples include:

 

  • Pearson correlation coefficient (r)
  • Spearman rank correlation
  • Kendall's tau Quartiles and tertiles describe positions within a single variable's distribution, not relationships between variables.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Quartiles and tertiles are measures of location/position that divide a dataset into equal parts, indicating where specific values fall within the distribution relative to other observations, helping to understand the positional ranking of data points.

questions.text:
Under the National Health Mission (NHM), the RMNCH+A strategy has been formulated to provide quality health care to various vulnerable age groups. Which of the following is a component of the RMNCH+A strategy? [INICET MAY 2025]

 

  1. Adolescent health
  2. Family planning
  3. Geriatric health
  4. Maternal and Child health
  5. Infant Health
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 1, 2, 4, 5

 

RMNCH+A represents a life-cycle approach to healthcare delivery under the National Health Mission, targeting specific vulnerable populations from adolescence through childhood.

 

RMNCH+A Acronym Breakdown:

 

R = Reproductive Health

 

  • Encompasses Family planning services (Component 2)
  • Contraceptive counseling and provision
  • Management of RTI/STI
  • Safe abortion services
  • Preconception care

 

M = Maternal Health

 

  • Part of Maternal and Child health (Component 4)
  • Antenatal care with minimum 4 ANC visits
  • Institutional deliveries
  • Postnatal care within 48 hours
  • Management of high-risk pregnancies

 

N = Neonatal Health

 

  • Includes Infant Health (Component 5)
  • Essential newborn care practices
  • Early initiation of breastfeeding
  • Newborn screening programs
  • Management of low birth weight babies

 

C = Child Health

 

  • Covered under Maternal and Child health (Component 4)
  • Immunization as per National Immunization Schedule
  • Growth monitoring and nutrition rehabilitation
  • Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness (IMNCI)
  • Covers age group 0-18 years

 

A = Adolescent Health

 

  • Component 1 - specially emphasized addition
  • Age group 10-19 years
  • Adolescent Friendly Health Services (AFHS)
  • Menstrual hygiene management
  • Counseling on nutrition, substance abuse, and mental health

 

Critical Exclusion: Geriatric Health (Component 3) is NOT part of RMNCH+A

 

  • Focuses on elderly population (typically 60+ years)
  • Managed through separate National Programme for Health Care of Elderly (NPHCE)
  • Falls outside the reproductive and developmental life cycle targeted by RMNCH+A

 

Educational Objective:

 

RMNCH+A strategy follows a life-cycle approach covering Reproductive health (family planning), Maternal health, Newborn/infant care, Child health, and Adolescent health, specifically excluding geriatric care which is addressed through separate elderly healthcare programs under National Health Mission.

questions.text: According to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act, the opinion of two registered medical practitioners is required for termination of pregnancy beyond how many weeks of gestation? [INICET MAY 2025]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 20-24

 

The Medical Termination of Pregnancy Amendment Act 2021 categorizes MTP based on gestational age with different medical opinion requirements:

 

 

High Risk Category Eligibility (20-24 weeks):

 

  • Rape survivors
  • Incest victims
  • Minors (under 18 years)
  • Persons with disabilities
  • Substantial fetal abnormalities

 

Clinical Process:

 

  • First doctor examines and forms opinion
  • Second doctor independently evaluates
  • Both must agree on medical indication
  • Joint recommendation required
  • Documentation of both opinions mandatory

 

Rationale for dual opinion:

 

  • Enhanced safety for late-term procedures
  • Complex ethical considerations
  • Legal protection against misuse
  • Quality assurance through peer review

 

Educational Objective:

 

The MTP Act 2021 requires two doctors' opinion for pregnancy termination between 20-24 weeks gestational age, specifically for high-risk cases including rape survivors, minors, persons with disabilities, and cases of incest, while pregnancies up to 20 weeks require only one doctor's opinion.

choices.text: To reduce number of health workers and professionals
For immediate quarantine measures of symptomatic individuals
To diagnose with lab tests and give potential warning for early outbreaks of fever, diarrhoea, respiratory infections

questions.text: In the Mahakumbh mela, what was the primary purpose of Mobile medical vans having multiple surveillance units for fever, diarrhoea and respiratory illnesses? [INICET MAY 2025]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) To diagnose with lab tests and give potential warning for early outbreaks of fever, diarrhoea, respiratory infections

 

  • Mobile medical vans at Mahakumbh Mela function as active surveillance systems to detect potential disease outbreaks early. 
  • They monitor fever, diarrhoea, and respiratory illness patterns among pilgrims and provide immediate diagnostic testing and treatment.
  • Surveillance is defined as "ongoing systematic process of all factors affecting a disease including data collection, compilation, analysis & interpretation and its application."
  • Early detection of unusual disease patterns allows rapid implementation of control measures, preventing small clusters from becoming major epidemics in densely populated mass gatherings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To reduce number of health workers and professionals: Incorrect. Mobile medical vans require additional health personnel to operate, enhancing rather than reducing healthcare capacity.

 

Option B. For immediate quarantine measures of symptomatic individuals: Incorrect. Quarantine is a secondary intervention. The primary purpose is surveillance and early detection, not quarantine implementation.

 

Option C. For treatment only: Incorrect. Treatment is only one function. The primary objective is surveillance for early outbreak detection combined with clinical care.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mobile medical vans at mass gatherings primarily serve as active surveillance systems for early outbreak detection through systematic monitoring of fever, diarrhoea, and respiratory illnesses.

questions.text:
You are posted as a medical officer at a Primary Health Centre (PHC). A 6-month-old infant is brought in with intensely pruritic, erythematous papules and burrows, especially involving the palms, soles, and diaper area. Scabies is clinically diagnosed. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment option for this infant? [INICET MAY 2025]

 

  1. Ivermectin
  2. 10% crotamiton
  3. 5% permethrin
  4. 25% Benzyl benzoate
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 2, 3

 

For treating scabies in infants, only certain topical agents are safe and effective. 

 

2. 10% crotamiton is another topical agent that can be safely used in infants for scabies treatment.

 

3. 5% permethrin is the drug of choice for scabies across all age groups including infants, children, adolescents, adults, elderly, pregnant and lactating women. It has excellent safety profile and efficacy. 

 

Other Options:

 

1. Ivermectin: Cannot be used in infants because it is contraindicated in patients weighing less than 15 kg. Since infants typically weigh much less than 15 kg, this medication is not suitable for this age group.

 

4. 25% Benzyl benzoate: Cannot be used in infants due to high toxicity risk. While benzyl benzoate can be used for scabies, the concentration needs to be much lower in pediatric patients. For children, 12.5% concentration is recommended, and for infants, only 6.25% concentration should be used to avoid toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

5% permethrin is the drug of choice for scabies treatment in infants, while 10% crotamiton is also safe; ivermectin is contraindicated in patients <15 kg and 25% benzyl benzoate is too toxic for infants.

questions.text:
According to the RCH (Reproductive and Child Health) program guidelines, when should CuT 380A ideally be inserted to ensure maximum compliance? [INICET MAY 2025]

 

  1. Within 48 hours of delivery
  2. Immediate post-partum
  3. Within first 5-7 days of menstrual cycle
  4. Within 7 days of next menstrual cycle
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 1, 2, 3

 

CuT 380A insertion has optimal timing windows that ensure maximum compliance and effectiveness under the RCH program. Post-partum insertion within 48 hours of delivery is considered the best time as it provides immediate contraceptive coverage and protection against the next pregnancy when the woman is already in healthcare contact. Immediate post-partum insertion offers convenience and ensures the woman doesn't need to make additional visits for contraception.

 

Within the first 5-7 days of menstrual cycle is another ideal timing as it ensures the woman is not pregnant and provides immediate contraceptive protection. These timings maximize compliance by utilizing existing healthcare contacts and ensuring optimal placement conditions.

 

Incorrect Option

 

4. Within 7 days of next menstrual cycle: Incorrect. The correct timing is within the first 5-7 days of the current menstrual cycle, not the next cycle. Waiting for the next menstrual cycle would delay contraceptive protection and increase the risk of unintended pregnancy, defeating the purpose of timely insertion for good compliance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Optimal timing for CuT 380A insertion includes immediate post-partum (within 48 hours of delivery) and within first 5-7 days of menstrual cycle to ensure maximum compliance and contraceptive effectiveness under RCH program.

questions.text: In a child diagnosed with Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID), which of the following vaccines is contraindicated ? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) MMR vaccine

 

SCID (Severe Combined Immunodeficiency) is an immunodeficiency condition where the child is severely immunocompromised. In immunosuppressive states like SCID, malnutrition, HIV infection, or pregnancy, live attenuated vaccines are strictly contraindicated. Live attenuated vaccines contain weakened but viable pathogens that can behave like complete viruses or bacteria in immunocompromised individuals, potentially causing the actual disease and serious complications.

 

MMR vaccine is a combination of live attenuated vaccines (Measles, Mumps, Rubella) and is therefore contraindicated in children with SCID and other immunodeficiency states.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IPV (Inactivated Polio Vaccine): Can be safely given to children with SCID as it contains killed/inactivated virus, posing no risk of causing disease in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Option B. Hepatitis B vaccine: Can be safely given to children with SCID as it is a recombinant vaccine containing only hepatitis B surface antigen, not live pathogens.

 

Option D. DTaP: Can be safely given to children with SCID as it is a combination vaccine containing acellular pertussis (proteinaceous components) and diphtheria-tetanus toxoids, which are inactivated components rather than live pathogens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Live attenuated vaccines (like MMR) are strictly contraindicated in immunocompromised conditions such as SCID, while killed/inactivated vaccines and recombinant vaccines can be safely administered.

choices.text: Visual acuity <6/60 after correction in better eye
Visual acuity <3/60 after correction in better eye
Visual acuity <6/60 without correction in better eye
Visual acuity <3/60 without correction in better eye

questions.text: World Health Organisation (WHO) considers blindness as a major public health problem. As per WHO, what is the definition of blindness? [INICET MAY 2025]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Visual acuity <3/60 after correction in better eye

 

According to the World Health Organization (WHO) and the National Programme for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment in India, blindness is defined as visual acuity of less than 3/60 in the better eye with the best possible optical correction. 

 

This definition emphasizes two critical components:

 

  1. Better eye criterion: The measurement is taken from the eye with better vision, not the worse eye
  2. Best possible correction: This includes the use of spectacles, contact lenses, or any other refractive correction

 

The WHO classification system for visual impairment includes:

 

  • Normal vision: 6/6 to 6/18
  • Visual impairment: <6/18 to 6/60
  • Severe visual impairment: <6/60 to 3/60
  • Blindness: <3/60

 

This standardized definition allows for consistent global surveillance, planning of prevention programs, and resource allocation for blindness control initiatives. In India, cataract remains the most common cause of blindness under this definition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

WHO defines blindness as visual acuity <3/60 in the better eye with best possible optical correction. This definition is crucial for epidemiological studies, public health planning, and implementation of blindness prevention programs globally.

questions.text: A primary health centre provides nutritional counseling and treatment to 100 diabetic patients. To assess the effectiveness, the medical officer compares patientsâ€™ weights before and after the intervention. Which statistical test is most appropriate for this analysis? [INICET MAY 2025]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Paired t-test

 

The paired t-test is the appropriate statistical test for this scenario because it is specifically designed for comparing means of the same group at two different time points. In this study design, we have several key characteristics that make paired t-test the correct choice:

 

  1. Same subjects: The 100 diabetic patients are the same individuals measured twice
  2. Quantitative data: Weight is a continuous, normally distributed variable
  3. Before-after design: We are comparing pre-intervention and post-intervention measurements
  4. Paired observations: Each patient's before-weight is naturally paired with their after-weight

 

The paired t-test accounts for the correlation between the before and after measurements in the same individuals, making it more powerful than other tests for detecting differences. It tests the null hypothesis that the mean difference between paired observations is zero.

 

Statistical assumptions for paired t-test include:

 

  • Data should be approximately normally distributed
  • Observations should be independent
  • Data should be measured on a continuous scale
  • The differences between pairs should be normally distributed

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ANOVA: Analysis of Variance is used for comparing means among three or more independent groups, not for before-after comparisons within the same group. ANOVA would be appropriate if we were comparing weights across multiple different treatment groups simultaneously.

 

Option B. Chi-square test: This non-parametric test is used for analyzing categorical or nominal data, not continuous quantitative data like weight measurements. Chi-square test examines associations between categorical variables and would be inappropriate for comparing means of continuous variables.

 

Option D. Unpaired t-test: Also called independent samples t-test, this is used for comparing means between two independent groups where subjects in one group are completely different from subjects in the other group. Since we have the same 100 patients measured at two time points (not two different groups of patients), unpaired t-test would be incorrect and less powerful than the paired t-test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paired t-test is used for comparing means of the same group at two different time points in before-after intervention studies. This test accounts for the natural pairing of observations and is more powerful than unpaired tests for detecting intervention effects.

questions.text: Which HPV strains are the most common cause of cervical cancer in India? [INICET MAY 2025]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) HPV 16, 18

 

HPV types 16 and 18 are the most common oncogenic (cancer-causing) Human Papillomavirus strains responsible for cervical cancer in India and globally. These high-risk HPV types account for approximately 70% of all cervical cancer cases worldwide, with HPV 16 being the single most common type.

 

Key characteristics of HPV 16 and 18:

 

  • High-risk oncogenic types: Capable of causing malignant transformation
  • Persistent infections: More likely to cause persistent infections leading to cancer
  • Vaccine targets: Primary targets in HPV vaccines (bivalent, quadrivalent, and nonavalent)
  • Screening relevance: Targeted in HPV DNA testing for cervical cancer screening

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HPV 6, 11: These are low-risk HPV types that primarily cause benign genital warts (condyloma acuminatum) and respiratory papillomatosis. While HPV 6 and 11 are the second most common HPV types in India, they rarely progress to cervical cancer. They are included in quadrivalent and nonavalent vaccines primarily for preventing genital warts, not cervical cancer.

 

Option C. HPV 31, 33: These are high-risk oncogenic HPV types that can cause cervical cancer, but they rank third in prevalence in the Indian population. While they are important contributors to cervical cancer globally, they are significantly less common than HPV 16 and 18. These types are included in the nonavalent HPV vaccine for broader protection.

 

Option D. HPV 52, 58: These are also high-risk HPV types associated with cervical cancer, but they have even lower prevalence in India compared to the Other Options:. HPV 52 and 58 are more commonly found in certain Asian populations but are not the predominant types causing cervical cancer in India. They are included in the nonavalent vaccine for comprehensive coverage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HPV types 16 and 18 are the most common high-risk oncogenic strains causing cervical cancer in India, accounting for approximately 70% of cases and serving as primary targets for vaccination strategies.

 

Note - The prevalence hierarchy of HPV types in India is:

 

  1. Most common: HPV 16, 18 (cervical cancer)
  2. Second most common: HPV 6, 11 (genital warts, low-risk)
  3. Third most common: HPV 31, 33 (cervical cancer, high-risk)
  4. Others: HPV 45, 52, 58, and other subtypes

choices.text: Admit the patient and give IV antihypertensives
Start the patient on Amlodipine 5mg per day and follow up after 1 month

questions.text: A 45 years old man presented to Ayushman Arogya Mandir with blood pressure measurements of 148/93 and 153/99 on two separate occasions. What is the next step in management? [INICET MAY 2025]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Start the patient on Amlodipine 5mg per day and follow up after 1 month

 

Under the National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases and Stroke (NPCDCS) guidelines implemented at Ayushman Arogya Mandir, this patient falls under Stage 1 hypertension management protocol.

 

Key management principles at Ayushman Arogya Mandir for hypertension:

 

Stage 1 Hypertension Management:

 

  • Single drug therapy is initiated
  • Amlodipine 5mg once daily is the preferred first-line calcium channel blocker
  • Follow-up after 1 month to assess response and adjust therapy if needed

 

Drug Categories used in NPCDCS (A-C-D-B approach):

 

  • A: ACE inhibitors/ARBs (Enalapril, Ramipril, Lisinopril)
  • C: Calcium Channel Blockers (Amlodipine - preferred)
  • D: Diuretics (Enalapide, Chlorthalidone, Spironolactone)
  • B: Beta-blockers (Atenolol, Metoprolol)

 

Stage 2 Hypertension would require initiation with two-drug combination therapy, but this patient's readings qualify for single-drug management as per program guidelines.

 

The systematic approach ensures standardized care delivery at primary healthcare level while maintaining cost-effectiveness and medication availability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Admit the patient and give IV antihypertensives: This approach is reserved for hypertensive emergencies with target organ damage or severely elevated BP (usually >180/120 mmHg) with acute symptoms. 

 

Option C. Immediate referral to higher center: Referral is not indicated for uncomplicated hypertension that can be managed at primary care level. Referral would be considered if there are complications, resistant hypertension, or target organ damage that requires specialist evaluation.

 

Option D. No intervention needed: This is incorrect as both BP readings (148/93 and 153/99 mmHg) clearly indicate hypertension requiring pharmacological intervention. Untreated hypertension leads to increased cardiovascular morbidity and mortality. Even lifestyle modifications alone would be insufficient at these BP levels, necessitating antihypertensive medication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under NPCDCS guidelines at Ayushman Arogya Mandir, Stage 1 hypertension is managed with single-drug therapy using Amlodipine 5mg daily with monthly follow-up, while Stage 2 requires two-drug combination therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common clinical feature of systemic lupus erythematosus? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Arthralgia & Myalgia

 

The most common clinical feature of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is arthralgia and myalgia involving the musculoskeletal system. The musculoskeletal system is the most commonly affected system in SLE, with almost all patients experiencing some form of joint-related symptoms. These manifestations include arthralgia (joint pain), myalgia (muscle pain), and non-erosive polyarthritis. The arthritis in SLE is typically symmetric, polyarticular, and non-erosive in nature, which distinguishes it from rheumatoid arthritis. It is extremely rare to diagnose SLE in a patient who does not have arthralgia, myalgia, or arthritis as part of their clinical presentation.

 

Clinical Manifestations of SLE and Prevalence over the Entire Course of Disease

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Photosensitivity: While photosensitivity does occur in SLE and almost every skin lesion in SLE is photosensitive in nature, it is not the most common overall clinical feature. Photosensitivity affects the skin specifically but is not as universally present as musculoskeletal symptoms.

 

Option B. Nephrotic Syndrome: Nephrotic syndrome can occur in SLE, particularly in lupus nephritis class V (membranous nephropathy), but it affects only a subset of patients with lupus nephritis and is not the most common overall manifestation of SLE.

 

Option D. Anemia & Thrombocytopenia: While hematological manifestations do occur in SLE, with anemia being the most common hematological finding (usually anemia of chronic disease or autoimmune hemolytic anemia), and thrombocytopenia can occur as part of Evans syndrome, these are not as universally present as musculoskeletal symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The musculoskeletal system is the most commonly affected system in SLE, with arthralgia and myalgia being present in almost all patients with the disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common/earliest presenting symptom in patients with Multiple Sclerosis? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sensory Disturbances

 

Sensory disturbances are the most common and earliest presenting symptom in patients with Multiple Sclerosis (MS). According to clinical data, approximately 60% of patients (almost two-thirds) present with some form of sensory disturbance or sensory issue as their initial manifestation. 

 

These sensory symptoms typically include numbness, loss of vibration sensation, loss of proprioception, and other sensory deficits.

 

After sensory disturbances, optic neuritis is the second most common initial manifestation, affecting approximately 20-40% of patients at presentation, though up to 50% develop it during the course of their illness.



Initial Symptoms of Multiple Sclerosis (MS)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vertigo: Vertigo due to cerebellar involvement can occur in MS but is much less common than sensory disturbances, affecting only about 11% of patients at presentation.

 

Option C. Ataxia: Ataxia due to cerebellar involvement occurs in approximately 6% of patients at presentation, making it significantly less common than sensory disturbances.

 

Option D. Facial Palsy: Facial palsy is quite rare as an initial presentation of MS, occurring in approximately only 1% of patients. This is due to involvement of corticobulbar fibers but is not a common initial finding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multiple Sclerosis

 

  • MC degenerative disease
  • â™€: â™‚ = 3:1, HLADRB1 association, linked to vitamin D deficiency & EBV
  • Clinical patterns: RRMS (MC, most progresses to SPMS), PPMS, PRPS
  • Presentation: Sensory (MC)- numbness/loss of vibration/proprioception, optic (UMN)- spasticity/bladder dysfunction, vision loss, diplopia, ataxia, vertigo
  • Charcot's Triad - Intentional tremors, Nystagmus & Staccato speech
  • Can have associated Lhermitte's sign, Uhthoff phenomenon (heat intolerance) & Pulfrich effect
  • Uncommon in MS: Visual field defects, Aphasia, Apraxia, progressive hemiparesis
  • Diagnosis: Revised McDonald's criteria (2017) - DIS + DIT (gold standard = MRI)

 

 

  • MS variants: Marburg variant, Tumefactive MS
  • Management: Acute attack - CS/PEX, Chronic Rx: DMDs (â†“duration of acute attack)

questions.text: 20-year-old female diagnosed with septic shock presents with a blood pressure of 80/60 mmHg. After receiving 3 litres of intravenous fluids, her mean arterial pressure remains 58 mmHg. What is the next best step in management? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Start noradrenaline

 

The next best step is to start noradrenaline (norepinephrine). This patient meets the criteria for septic shock: hypotension with MAP <65 mmHg that persists despite adequate fluid resuscitation (typically 30 mL/kg of crystalloids). 

 

According to the Surviving Sepsis Campaign guidelines, noradrenaline is the first-line vasopressor in septic shock. Noradrenaline is an excellent choice because it provides strong vasopressor effects with good inotropic properties and minimal beta-2 activation, which prevents further blood pressure drop. It can be considered a universal vasopressor that works effectively in most types of shock, particularly distributive shock like sepsis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start dopamine: Dopamine can be used as an alternative vasopressor but is not the preferred first-line choice because it can cause severe tachycardia and has arrhythmogenic potential, making it less ideal than noradrenaline.

 

Option C. Repeat crystalloid fluid: The patient has already received adequate fluid resuscitation (3 liters), and the MAP remains <65 mmHg. Further fluid administration without vasopressor support would not be appropriate and could lead to fluid overload.

 

Option D. Start vasopressin: Vasopressin is typically used as a second-line vasopressor according to the Surviving Sepsis Campaign guidelines, usually added if the patient doesn't respond adequately to noradrenaline, not as first-line therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Noradrenaline is the first-line vasopressor in septic shock when mean arterial pressure remains <65 mmHg despite adequate fluid resuscitation (30 mL/kg crystalloids).

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents with complaints of burning micturition and increased frequency. Prostatic examination is normal. Urinalysis shows >50 pus cells per high power field, but urine culture shows no growth. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic bacterial prostatitis

 

This presentation is classic for chronic bacterial prostatitis. The patient has lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) including dysuria and urinary frequency, with significant pyuria (>50 WBCs/hpf) but negative routine urine culture. 

 

The key feature of chronic bacterial prostatitis is that routine voided bladder cultures (VB1 and VB2) are typically negative, while only cultures of expressed prostatic secretions (EPS) after prostatic massage or urine voided after prostatic massage (VB3) would be positive. 

 

The prostatic examination can be normal in many cases of chronic bacterial prostatitis, which was previously also called chronic pelvic pain syndrome. The significant symptomatology cannot be ignored and simply attributed to sterile pyuria in a symptomatic patient.



Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute bacterial prostatitis: This is ruled out because in acute bacterial prostatitis, the prostate would be exquisitely tender to touch. Prostatic massage is actually contraindicated in acute cases as it can cause pain and shock. The normal prostatic examination effectively excludes this diagnosis.

 

Option C. Chronic Granulomatous prostatitis: This rare condition presents with multiple small granulomas giving a nodular texture to the prostate. The patient would have palpable nodules on prostatic examination that could mimic cancer. A normal prostatic examination rules out this diagnosis, and prostatic biopsy would be required for confirmation.

 

Option D. Sterile pyuria: While the routine urine culture is negative, the significant symptomatology in this 58-year-old male with classic LUTS cannot be dismissed as simple sterile pyuria. The symptoms must be evaluated and cannot be ignored, especially given the clinical presentation consistent with chronic bacterial prostatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic bacterial prostatitis presents with LUTS and pyuria but negative routine urine cultures; only EPS cultures or post-massage urine cultures are positive.

 

Classification of Prostatitis:

choices.text: Perform coronary angiography to rule out ischemic cardiomyopathy
Initiate loop diuretics and SGLT2 inhibitors
Start digoxin to enhance myocardial contractility
Initiate Ivabradine to reduce heart rate and improve diastolic filling

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents with sudden onset of shortness of breath and bilateral pedal edema. He is compliant with his antihypertensive medications, and blood pressure is well controlled. Echocardiography reveals an ejection fraction of 60%, concentric left ventricular hypertrophy, left atrial enlargement, and grade 2 diastolic dysfunction. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to improve his condition? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Initiate loop diuretics and SGLT2 inhibitors

 

This patient presents with Heart Failure with preserved Ejection Fraction (HFpEF). The clinical features that confirm this diagnosis include symptoms of heart failure (shortness of breath and bilateral pedal edema), ejection fraction >50%, left ventricular hypertrophy, and grade 2 diastolic dysfunction. In HFpEF, no single drug improves survival, but certain medications can address symptoms and reduce heart failure hospitalizations. 

 

Loop diuretics are the preferred choice for volume overload states and can relieve congestion, making the patient feel more comfortable. SGLT2 inhibitors (particularly dapagliflozin and empagliflozin) have been shown to reduce heart failure hospitalizations in patients with HFpEF, though they don't affect mortality. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perform coronary angiography to rule out ischemic cardiomyopathy: This is not required at this point. Ischemic cardiomyopathy typically presents with reduced ejection fraction, not preserved ejection fraction as seen in this patient.

 

Option C. Start digoxin to enhance myocardial contractility: This is not appropriate since the myocardium is already contracting well (EF 60%). Digoxin does not improve survival even in HFrEF and has no established role in HFpEF management.

 

Option D. Initiate Ivabradine to reduce heart rate and improve diastolic filling: This is not indicated. Ivabradine has only conditional recommendations even in HFrEF, and most studies have not even evaluated ivabradine in HFpEF patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HFpEF management focuses on symptom relief and reducing hospitalizations using loop diuretics and SGLT2 inhibitors, as no drugs improve survival in this condition.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a symptom of cardiac failure? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Non-pulsatile elevation of JVP

 

Non-pulsatile elevation of JVP is NOT a symptom of cardiac failure; rather, it is a sign of superior vena cava (SVC) obstruction. In SVC obstruction, the communication between the right atrium and jugular veins is cut off, so pressure changes in the right atrium cannot be transmitted to the jugular veins, resulting in absent pulsations. However, due to the obstruction, the JVP will be very high. The key distinction is that while elevated JVP can occur in heart failure, it should maintain pulsatile characteristics reflecting right atrial pressure changes.

 

Diagnostic Criteria

 

Major Criteria

 

  • Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea or orthopnea
  • Neck vein distension
  • Rales
  • Cardiomegaly
  • Acute pulmonary edema
  • S3 gallop
  • Increased venous pressure â‰¥ 16 cm Hâ‚‚O
  • Circulation time â‰¥ 25 seconds
  • Hepatojugular reflux

 

Minor Criteria

 

  • Ankle edema
  • Night cough
  • Dyspnea on exertion
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Pleural effusion
  • Vital capacity decreased one third from maximum
  • Tachycardia rate â‰¥ 120/min

 

Major or Minor Criterion

 

  • Weight loss â‰¥ 2.4 kg in 5 days in response

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right hypochondrial pain: This is a valid symptom of cardiac failure caused by hepatomegaly due to right heart failure and venous congestion. Patients can experience right upper quadrant pain due to liver congestion.

 

Option C. Orthopnea: This is a classic symptom of heart failure where patients experience shortness of breath when lying flat, requiring them to sleep with multiple pillows or in a seated position due to increased venous return and pulmonary congestion.

 

Option D. Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea: This is another classic symptom of heart failure where patients wake up suddenly at night with severe shortness of breath, typically occurring 2-4 hours after lying down due to fluid redistribution.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-pulsatile elevation of JVP indicates SVC obstruction, not heart failure; heart failure causes pulsatile JVP elevation reflecting right atrial pressure changes.

questions.text: A 56-year-old diabetic male presents with a complicated urinary tract infection and is found to be hypotensive. His blood pressure does not respond to intravenous fluids. Which of the following is the most appropriate antibiotic to manage his condition? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Meropenem

 

This patient is in septic shock due to urosepsis (complicated urinary tract infection with hypotension not responding to IV fluids). 

 

In septic shock, broad-spectrum antibiotics covering Pseudomonas and ESBL organisms are essential. 

 

Meropenem is the best choice among the options because: 

 

  1. It provides broad-spectrum coverage including Pseudomonas aeruginosa, 
  2. It is the gold standard for Extended Spectrum Beta-Lactamase (ESBL) producing organisms, which are common in complicated UTIs, and 
  3. It covers both sensitive gram-positive cocci and gram-negative rods. 

 

The five important broad-spectrum drugs for sepsis are piperacillin-tazobactam, cefepime, ceftazidime, meropenem, and imipenem. Meropenem is specifically preferred in urosepsis because complicated UTIs often involve ESBL organisms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amoxicillin-Clavulanate: This has inadequate spectrum for septic shock management. It lacks coverage against Pseudomonas and many ESBL-producing organisms that are commonly involved in complicated UTIs and sepsis.

 

Option B. Nitrofurantoin: This is only used for uncomplicated urinary tract infections and has no role in septic shock or complicated UTIs. It has poor tissue penetration and no systemic efficacy for severe infections.

 

Option D. Ceftriaxone: While this is a good broad-spectrum antibiotic, it lacks reliable coverage against Pseudomonas aeruginosa and many ESBL-producing organisms, making it suboptimal for septic shock in the setting of complicated UTI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meropenem is the preferred antibiotic for septic shock due to urosepsis because it covers Pseudomonas and ESBL organisms commonly involved in complicated UTIs.

choices.text: It helps in determining the duration of antibiotic therapy
It helps in identifying which empirical antibiotics to be given
It can be used to confirm source of infection
It is used to differentiate bacterial from fungal cause

questions.text: A patient underwent cardiac surgery and was admitted to the ICU. He later developed ventilator-associated pneumonia and was started on empirical antibiotics. A few hours later, the patient developed acute kidney injury (AKI). Serum procalcitonin was sent. Which of the following statements regarding procalcitonin is correct? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It helps in determining the duration of antibiotic therapy

 

Procalcitonin is most useful in determining the duration of antibiotic therapy, particularly in ICU settings. It serves as a biomarker that helps clinicians decide when to de-escalate or discontinue antibiotics rather than when to start them. Procalcitonin levels decrease as bacterial infections resolve, making it valuable for guiding antibiotic stewardship and preventing unnecessary prolonged antibiotic courses. This is especially important in ICU patients where antibiotic de-escalation is crucial to prevent resistance and reduce adverse effects. While procalcitonin is a marker of inflammation, it is non-specific like CRP and primarily helps with the "when to stop" rather than "when to start" antibiotics question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It helps in identifying which empirical antibiotics to be given: Procalcitonin does not guide the choice of specific empirical antibiotics. The selection of empirical antibiotics is guided by the clinical situation, suspected pathogens, local resistance patterns, and patient factors, not by procalcitonin levels.

 

Option C. It can be used to confirm source of infection: Procalcitonin cannot confirm the source of infection. It is elevated in any inflammatory condition and is very non-specific, similar to CRP. Clinical evaluation, imaging, and cultures are needed to identify infection sources.

 

Option D. It is used to differentiate bacterial from fungal cause: Procalcitonin cannot reliably differentiate between bacterial and fungal infections. While it may be somewhat helpful in distinguishing bacterial from viral infections, it is not useful for bacterial versus fungal differentiation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Procalcitonin is primarily used as a biomarker to guide antibiotic de-escalation and determine the duration of antibiotic therapy, particularly in ICU settings.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about Multiple Sclerosis are incorrect? (INICET MAY 2025)

 

  1. 70% of patients with MS develop Optic Neuritis during the course of illness 
  2. Oral steroids are first line for acute relapses 
  3. Loss of colour and depth perception is proportional to loss of visual acuity 
  4. Fundus examination can be normal
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A, B, C

 

A. 70% of patients with MS develop Optic Neuritis during the course of illness

 

  • This is correct. Optic neuritis is indeed very common in MS, occurring in approximately 70% of patients at some point during their disease course. It may be the initial presenting symptom in 15-20% of cases.

 

B. Oral steroids are first line for acute relapses

 

  • This is incorrect. Intravenous methylprednisolone (not oral steroids) is the first-line treatment for acute MS relapses. The ONTT (Optic Neuritis Treatment Trial) showed that oral prednisone alone may actually increase the risk of recurrent optic neuritis. High-dose IV steroids are preferred for acute attacks.

 

C. Loss of colour and depth perception is proportional to loss of visual acuity

 

  • This is incorrect. In optic neuritis, loss of color vision (dyschromatopsia) and contrast sensitivity often occurs disproportionately to the loss of visual acuity. Patients may have relatively preserved visual acuity but significant impairment in color discrimination, particularly red desaturation.

 

Correct Statement:

 

D. Fundus examination can be normal

 

  • This is correct. In retrobulbar optic neuritis (which is the most common form in MS), the fundus examination is typically normal initially because the inflammation is behind the optic disc. This is classically described as "the patient sees nothing, and the doctor sees nothing."

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Multiple Sclerosis, 50% of patients develop optic neuritis during illness course, IV steroids are first-line for acute relapses, and color/depth perception loss is out of proportion to visual acuity loss in optic neuritis.

questions.text: According to the Muir-Barclay formula, which of the following is considered the primary fluid for volume replacement? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Albumin

 

The Muir-Barclay formula is specifically designed to calculate the amount of albumin required for replacement in patients with severe hypoalbuminemia, particularly in burn patients. The formula originated from the UK and was primarily devised for albumin replacement. 

 

Formula:

 

(Desired albumin level - Actual serum albumin) Ã— Body weight in kg Ã— 2 

 

For example, if desired albumin is 3.5 g/dL, actual albumin is 2 g/dL, and patient weighs 60 kg, 

 

Then: (3.5-2) Ã— 60 Ã— 2 = 180 grams of albumin to be given over 1-2 days. 

 

While there are many other fluid replacement formulas for different clinical scenarios (like Parkland formula for burns, Evans formula, etc.), the Muir-Barclay formula specifically addresses albumin replacement for hypoalbuminemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Packed Red Blood Cells: PRBCs are used for correcting anemia and blood loss, not for volume replacement calculations in the Muir-Barclay formula.

 

Option B. Fresh Frozen Plasma: FFP is used for coagulation factor replacement, not as the primary fluid in the Muir-Barclay formula.

 

Option C. Dextran 40: Dextran is a colloid solution used for volume expansion but is not the primary fluid calculated by the Muir-Barclay formula.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Muir-Barclay formula is specifically used to calculate albumin requirements for volume replacement in patients with severe hypoalbuminemia, particularly in burn patients.

 

Burns Fluid Resuscitation Formulas

 

 

Pediatric Fluid Resuscitation

 

 

Sepsis & Shock Fluid Resuscitation

questions.text: A patient with long-standing multinodular goiter develops symptoms of thyrotoxicosis following exposure to iodine. What is this phenomenon called? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Jod-Basedow phenomenon

 

The Jod-Basedow phenomenon occurs when a patient with pre-existing thyroid disease (such as multinodular goiter) develops thyrotoxicosis following iodine exposure. 

 

In diseased thyroid glands, instead of being suppressed by iodine as would happen in normal glands, the abnormal thyroid tissue takes up the excess iodine and produces more thyroid hormones, leading to or worsening thyrotoxicosis. This is why iodine-containing medications or contrast agents can precipitate thyroid storm in patients with pre-existing thyroid disease. This phenomenon is also the reason why in thyrotoxic patients, anti-thyroid drugs (like PTU) are given first to block hormone synthesis, and only after one hour is potassium iodide administered to suppress the gland.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wolff-Chaikoff effect: This occurs in normal thyroid glands when they are exposed to excessive iodine, leading to temporary suppression of thyroid hormone synthesis. The gland typically escapes this effect after 8-9 days. This is the opposite of what occurs in the Jod-Basedow phenomenon.

 

Option C. Pemberton sign: This is a clinical sign of retrosternal goiter where raising both arms above the head for 1-2 minutes results in facial flushing, dyspnea, or stridor due to superior vena cava compression.

 

Option D. Plummer disease: This refers to toxic multinodular goiter, which is a chronic condition and not the acute phenomenon described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Jod-Basedow phenomenon is the development of thyrotoxicosis in patients with pre-existing thyroid disease following iodine exposure, due to increased hormone production rather than suppression.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with sudden onset severe headache and vomiting. On examination, he has neck stiffness. A CT scan of the brain shows hydrocephalus. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Subarachnoid Hemorrhage

 

  • The most likely diagnosis is subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). 
  • The patient presents with classic features: sudden onset severe headache (thunderclap headache), vomiting, and neck stiffness (meningismus).
