  • Importantly, in approximately 10% of SAH cases, the initial NCCT can be normal, and these cases require lumbar puncture to prove xanthochromia for diagnosis. 
  • Hydrocephalus is a well-known complication of SAH, occurring when subarachnoid blood clogs the arachnoid granulations that normally absorb CSF, leading to impaired CSF circulation and hydrocephalus. 
  • The young age and acute presentation with meningeal signs in the absence of fever strongly suggest SAH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus: NPH typically occurs in elderly patients and presents with the classic triad of gait disturbance, urinary incontinence, and dementia. It does not present with acute severe headache, vomiting, or neck stiffness.

 

Option B. Bacterial Meningitis: While bacterial meningitis can cause neck stiffness and altered consciousness, it typically presents with fever, which is notably absent in this case. The acute hydrocephalus without fever makes SAH more likely.

 

Option C. Viral Encephalitis: Viral encephalitis typically shows parenchymal changes on imaging rather than isolated hydrocephalus, and fever would be expected. The clinical presentation doesn't fit typical viral encephalitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage can present with normal initial CT in 10% of cases and commonly causes hydrocephalus due to impaired CSF absorption from subarachnoid blood.

 

Investigation for SAH:

 

  • If NCCT positive â†’ Angiogram (DSA vs CTA)
  • If NCCT negative + strong suspicion â†’ LP
  • Star of death sign

questions.text: A 65-year-old known case of Parkinson's disease presents with severe oropharyngeal dysphagia and recurrent episodes of aspiration pneumonitis. CXR reveals bilateral bronchiectasis. What is the most appropriate long-term management plan for this patient? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PEG tube

 

The most appropriate long-term management for this patient with end-stage Parkinson's disease, severe oropharyngeal dysphagia, and recurrent aspiration is a PEG (Percutaneous Endoscopic Gastrostomy) tube. 

 

The patient has developed bilateral bronchiectasis as a consequence of recurrent aspiration pneumonitis due to severe dysphagia. 

 

While the other options address bronchiectasis management, they do not address the primary underlying problem - the aspiration due to severe dysphagia. In end-stage neurodegenerative disorders with severe dysphagia and recurrent aspiration, PEG tube placement provides safe nutritional support while preventing further aspiration episodes. This addresses the root cause of the problem and prevents further lung damage from aspiration.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High-frequency chest wall oscillation therapy: This is a treatment for bronchiectasis to help with airway clearance, but it doesn't address the underlying cause of aspiration that led to bronchiectasis.

 

Option B. Nebulized N-acetylcysteine to reduce secretions: This may help with secretion management in bronchiectasis but doesn't prevent the ongoing aspiration that is causing the problem.

 

Option D. Macrolide therapy: Long-term azithromycin can reduce exacerbations in bronchiectasis and COPD, but it doesn't address the primary aspiration problem and is not curative.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In end-stage neurodegenerative disorders with severe dysphagia and recurrent aspiration, PEG tube placement is the most appropriate long-term management to prevent further aspiration and provide safe nutrition.

questions.text: Which of the following lesions is not typically seen as a glomerular finding in patients with diabetic nephropathy? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Armanni-Ebstein lesion

 

The Armanni-Ebstein lesion is not a glomerular finding and is not specifically associated with diabetic nephropathy. 

 

Armanni-Ebstein lesions are glycogen accumulations that occur in the tubules, specifically in the proximal convoluted tubules (PCT), not in the glomeruli. These lesions are seen in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) and severe, uncontrolled hyperglycemia, but they are not part of the pathognomonic changes of diabetic nephropathy. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mesangial expansion: This is one of the earliest glomerular changes in diabetic kidney disease, occurring due to deposition of extracellular matrix in the mesangium.

 

Option C. Podocyte loss: Podocyte loss is a characteristic glomerular finding in diabetic nephropathy and contributes to proteinuria and progressive kidney disease.

 

Option D. Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules: These represent nodular glomerulosclerosis and are the classic, pathognomonic glomerular change of diabetic nephropathy/diabetic kidney disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Armanni-Ebstein lesions are tubular (not glomerular) glycogen accumulations seen in DKA and severe hyperglycemia, not a specific finding of diabetic nephropathy.

questions.text: Which of the following malignancies has the least or no established association with obesity? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gastric pyloric cancer

 

Gastric pyloric cancer is not associated with obesity. While obesity is linked to many gastrointestinal cancers, the association with gastric cancer is site-specific. 

 

Obesity has been linked to gastric cardia (upper stomach) cancers but not to pyloric (lower stomach) cancers. The relationship between obesity and gastric cancer depends on the anatomical location within the stomach. Gastric cardia cancers, which occur in the upper portion of the stomach near the gastroesophageal junction, show association with obesity, whereas pyloric cancers do not demonstrate this relationship.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meningioma: This is associated with obesity. Meningioma is one of the few brain tumors that has been linked to obesity. Increased BMI has been identified as a risk factor for developing meningiomas.

 

Option B. Pancreatic cancer: This is strongly associated with obesity. Pancreatic cancer is part of the hepatobiliary-pancreatic system cancers that have been linked to obesity and increased BMI. Obesity is considered a significant risk factor for pancreatic adenocarcinoma.

 

Option D. Multiple myeloma: This is associated with obesity. Studies have linked multiple myeloma and some leukemias to obesity and increased BMI. The association between obesity and hematological malignancies, particularly multiple myeloma, has been established in epidemiological studies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastric pyloric cancer is not associated with obesity, unlike gastric cardia cancer which shows positive association with increased BMI.

 

Note â€“ 

 

  • Best answer would be Premenopausal breast cancer (in females) or prostate cancer (in males) â€“ not related to obesity.
  • Ovarian cancer and postmenopausal breast cancer are associated with obesity

questions.text: A post-renal transplant patient presents with fever and breathlessness. Lung biopsy is done. Which of the following stains is least useful in identifying the causative organism? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congo red

 

Congo red stain is least useful in identifying the causative organism in this post-transplant patient with pneumonia. 

 

Congo red is specifically used to detect amyloid deposits, which show characteristic apple-green birefringence under polarized light. It is not used for identifying infectious organisms. 

 

In the context of a post-renal transplant patient presenting with fever and breathlessness, the most likely diagnosis is Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP), which is a common opportunistic infection in immunocompromised patients. The lung biopsy shows cysts typical of Pneumocystis, which would not be detected by Congo red staining.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Periodic Acid-Schiff (PAS): This is a very useful stain for identifying Pneumocystis jirovecii. PAS stain is excellent for detecting the cyst wall of Pneumocystis organisms and is one of the standard stains used for diagnosing PCP in immunocompromised patients.

 

Option C. Gomori Methenamine Silver (GMS): This is considered the gold standard for staining fungal elements, including Pneumocystis jirovecii. GMS stain clearly demonstrates the characteristic cyst forms of Pneumocystis and is the most commonly used stain for diagnosing PCP.

 

Option D. Fontana-Masson: This stain can be useful for identifying certain organisms, particularly those that are argentophilic (silver-loving). While not specifically for Pneumocystis, it can be used to stain organisms like Cryptococcus and has some utility in identifying certain infectious agents, making it more useful than Congo red in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congo red stain is used specifically for detecting amyloid deposits and is not useful for identifying infectious organisms in post-transplant opportunistic infections.

questions.text: A young boy presents with a platelet count of 10,000/Î¼L. Bone marrow aspirate reveals normal cellularity with increased number of megakaryocytes. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this condition? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG)

 

This clinical presentation is consistent with immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). The key features include severe thrombocytopenia (platelet count 10,000/Î¼L), normal bone marrow cellularity with increased megakaryocytes, indicating peripheral platelet destruction rather than production failure. In patients with life-threatening thrombocytopenia or severe bleeding in ITP, intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) is the first-line treatment. IVIG works by blocking or saturating macrophage Fc receptors, providing faster response (24-48 hours) compared to corticosteroids. In non-bleeding patients without urgent symptoms, corticosteroids would be the first-line treatment, but given the severely low platelet count, IVIG is more appropriate for immediate management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methotrexate: This immunosuppressive agent is not used in the initial treatment of ITP. It may be considered as a second-line or third-line agent in refractory cases, but it is not appropriate for initial management, especially in a young patient with severe thrombocytopenia.

 

Option C. Bone Marrow Transplant: This is not indicated in ITP since the condition involves peripheral destruction of platelets rather than bone marrow failure. The bone marrow is functioning normally with increased megakaryocyte production, making transplantation unnecessary and inappropriate.

 

Option D. Aspirin: This would be contraindicated in a patient with severe thrombocytopenia as it would further impair platelet function and significantly increase bleeding risk. Aspirin inhibits platelet aggregation, which would be dangerous in someone with already critically low platelet counts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In ITP with severe thrombocytopenia and bleeding risk, IVIG provides rapid response by blocking macrophage Fc receptors and is the preferred initial treatment.

questions.text:
Which of the following antimalarial drugs are commonly used for the clinical cure of malaria? (INICET MAY 2025)

 

  1. Artemisinin
  2. Sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine
  3. Chloroquine
  4. Primaquine
questions.solution:
Ans. A) a, b, c

 

Clinical cure of malaria refers to achieving resolution of fever and clinical symptoms, which is different from radical cure that eliminates all parasite forms including gametocytes. 

 

a. Artemisinin: Correct for clinical cure Artemisinin and its derivatives are highly effective blood schizonticides that rapidly clear parasitemia and resolve clinical symptoms. They form the backbone of ACT (Artemisinin Combination Therapy), which is the WHO-recommended first-line treatment. A common example is ARTSP (artesunate with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine), demonstrating how artemisinin is combined with other clinical cure agents for enhanced efficacy. These drugs are safe in G6PD deficiency.

 

b. Sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine: Correct for clinical cure This combination effectively clears blood-stage parasites by inhibiting folate synthesis. It's frequently used as part of combination therapy for clinical cure, particularly in ACT regimens like ARTSP (with artesunate). It successfully eliminates parasitemia and resolves symptoms while being safe for patients with G6PD deficiency.

 

c. Chloroquine: Correct for clinical cure Chloroquine remains effective for clinical cure of uncomplicated vivax malaria in areas without resistance. It acts as a blood schizonticide, clearing parasites from the bloodstream and resolving clinical symptoms. Despite P. falciparum resistance in many regions, it continues to be valuable for treating other Plasmodium species and is safe in G6PD deficiency.

 

Incorrect Options:

 

d. Primaquine: Not for clinical cure Primaquine serves a distinctly different purpose - it's used specifically for radical cure to eliminate hypnozoites (dormant liver stages) and gametocytes, particularly in P. vivax and P. ovale infections. While essential for preventing relapses, it's not used for achieving clinical cure of acute symptoms. Importantly, primaquine is contraindicated in G6PD deficiency due to risk of hemolysis, unlike the clinical cure drugs which are generally safe in these patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clinical cure of malaria is achieved with artemisinin, sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine, and chloroquine, while primaquine is reserved for radical cure and is contraindicated in G6PD deficiency.

questions.text: Which of these is not included in the TNM stage T4b of breast cancer? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Skin erythema involving > 1/3rd surface

 

T4b stage of breast cancer involves skin invasion with specific manifestations. According to TNM staging, T4b includes direct skin invasion presenting as ulceration of the skin, satellite skin nodules, or peau d'orange (orange peel appearance due to lymphatic obstruction). These changes must involve less than one-third of the breast skin surface. When skin erythema involves more than one-third of the breast surface (>1/3rd surface), it is classified as T4d (inflammatory breast cancer), not T4b. Therefore, skin erythema involving more than one-third of the surface is not included in T4b staging but rather defines T4d disease. The distinction is important because inflammatory breast cancer (T4d) has a different prognosis and treatment approach compared to T4b disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ulceration: This is incorrect as an answer because ulceration is indeed included in T4b staging. Skin ulceration represents direct tumor invasion through the dermis and epidermis, which is a defining feature of T4b breast cancer.

 

Option B. Satellite nodules: This is incorrect as an answer because satellite nodules are included in T4b staging. These are small tumor deposits in the skin separate from the main tumor mass, indicating advanced local disease with skin involvement.

 

Option D. Peau d'orange: This is incorrect as an answer because peau d'orange is a classic sign included in T4b staging. It results from dermal lymphatic invasion causing skin edema and dimpling that resembles orange peel, representing skin involvement without necessarily being inflammatory breast cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

T4b breast cancer includes skin ulceration, satellite nodules, and peau d'orange affecting less than one-third of breast skin surface, while skin erythema involving more than one-third of the surface is classified as T4d (inflammatory breast cancer).

 

TNM Staging for Breast Cancer:

 

T - Tumor Size (maximum)

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a contraindication to BCT? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tumor limited to one quadrant

 

Breast Conservation Therapy (BCT) involves wide local excision of the tumor followed by radiation therapy. A tumor limited to one quadrant is actually suitable for BCT as it allows for adequate wide local excision with clear margins while preserving most of the breast tissue. BCT is feasible when the tumor is localized and can be completely excised with negative margins while maintaining acceptable cosmesis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prior chest radiation: Incorrect. This is a contraindication to BCT because the breast tissue has already received radiation, and re-irradiation would exceed tissue tolerance, leading to severe complications including tissue necrosis and poor wound healing.

 

Option B. Involved margins after resection: Incorrect. This is a contraindication, especially if margins remain positive after two or more attempts at re-excision. Positive margins indicate incomplete tumor removal and high risk of local recurrence.

 

Option C. Scleroderma: Incorrect. This is a contraindication because scleroderma and other connective tissue disorders cause poor tolerance to radiation therapy, resulting in severe fibrosis, contractures, and poor cosmetic outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tumor limited to one quadrant is not a contraindication to BCT; rather, it is an ideal scenario for breast conservation therapy.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding Vacuum-Assisted Closure (VAC) dressing are correct? (INICET MAY 2025)

 

  1. Reduces bacterial load 
  2. Maximum pressure is -125mm of Hg 
  3. Promotes granulation tissue 
  4. Reduces size of wound
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3 and 4

 

VAC (Vacuum Assisted Closure) dressing, also known as Negative Pressure Wound Therapy (NPWT), is a therapeutic technique that uses controlled negative pressure to promote wound healing. All four statements about VAC dressing are correct.

 

1. Reduces bacterial load 

 

  • VAC therapy uses controlled negative pressure to draw out excess fluid and infectious materials from the wound bed.
  • It decreases local bacterial colonization, helps prevent infection, and supports a cleaner wound environment.
  • This effect enhances the wound's ability to heal efficiently.

 

2.  Maximum pressure is -125 mmHg 

 

  • The standard therapeutic range for VAC dressing is between -75 mmHg to -125 mmHg.
  • -125 mmHg is considered the maximum standard pressure used for optimal clinical benefit.
  • Lower pressures may be used in certain cases, but -125 mmHg is the commonly applied maximum.

 

3.  Promotes granulation tissue 

 

  • The negative pressure improves blood perfusion and oxygen delivery to the wound, encouraging angiogenesis.
  • It promotes the formation of healthy granulation tissue, which is essential for wound healing and epithelialization.

 

4. Reduces size of wound 

 

  • The vacuum effect draws the edges of the wound inward through mechanical approximation, thereby reducing wound dimensions.
  • Over time, this leads to a noticeable decrease in wound size, making it easier to manage and close.

 

Educational Objective:

 

VAC therapy at -100 to -125 mmHg reduces bacterial load through continuous drainage, promotes granulation tissue by improving vascularity and removing MMPs, and mechanically approximates wound edges to reduce wound size.

questions.text: Identify the procedure shown in the image below. (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dog ear correction

 

The image demonstrates dog ear correction, a technique used to address redundant tissue that forms at the ends of a sutured wound. Dog ears occur when there are unequal wound edges or improper wound closure angles. The procedure involves excising the excess triangular skin fold at a 45-degree angle (as shown in panel 1), then removing the redundant tissue (panel 2), and finally achieving a flat, cosmetically acceptable closure (panel 3). The interrupted sutures shown are typical for this correction. This bunching of tissue resembles a dog's ear, hence the name. The technique ensures a smooth, flat scar without protruding tissue at the wound ends.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incision and drainage of abscess: Incorrect. Incision and drainage involves making a linear or cruciate incision to evacuate pus from an abscess cavity. The image shows excision of redundant skin with primary closure, not drainage of any collection.

 

Option B. Skin grafting: Incorrect. Skin grafting involves harvesting skin from a donor site and transplanting it to cover a defect. The image shows direct excision and primary closure without any graft placement.

 

Option C. Keloid excision: Incorrect. Keloid excision involves removing hypertrophic scar tissue that extends beyond the original wound boundaries. The image shows correction of redundant normal skin at wound edges, not pathological scar tissue removal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dog ear deformity is corrected by excising redundant tissue at 45-degree angles at the wound ends when unequal wound edges create tissue bunching during closure.

choices.text: Secure airway, needle thoracotomy and IV fluids
Blood transfusion and send for CT
Take history, administer IV Dextrose, and send for eFAST
CT scan of the head and secure the airway

questions.text: A patient with a history of chest trauma with breathlessness on examination is found to have systolic BP of 90 mm of Hg, SpOâ‚‚ of 85%, GCS 8/15 and absent breath sounds. What is the next step? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Secure airway, needle thoracotomy and IV fluids

 

This patient presents with polytrauma requiring immediate implementation of the ATLS primary survey (ABCDE approach). 

 

The GCS of 8/15 indicates need for immediate intubation (GCS <8 = intubate). The absent breath sounds with hypotension and hypoxia suggest tension pneumothorax requiring urgent needle thoracotomy for decompression. 

 

The hypotension (BP 90 mmHg) necessitates IV fluid resuscitation for circulation support. 

 

Following the ABC priorities - Airway (intubation for GCS 8), Breathing (needle decompression for tension pneumothorax), and Circulation (IV fluids for hypotension) - must be addressed in that sequence before any imaging studies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blood transfusion and send for CT: Incorrect because CT scan cannot be performed in an unstable patient, and blood transfusion is not the immediate priority over securing airway and treating tension pneumothorax.

 

Option C. Take history, administer IV Dextrose, and send for eFAST: Incorrect as taking history is not appropriate in a critically ill patient with GCS 8/15, and dextrose administration is not indicated without evidence of hypoglycemia. eFAST can wait until ABC is secured.

 

Option D. CT scan of the head and secure the airway: Incorrect because sending an unstable patient with GCS 8/15 and signs of tension pneumothorax for CT scan before stabilization would be life-threatening. Airway management must precede imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In trauma patients with GCS â‰¤8, absent breath sounds, and hemodynamic instability, follow ABC protocol: secure airway first (intubate), decompress tension pneumothorax (needle thoracotomy), then address circulation (IV fluids) before any imaging studies.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female with fever, nausea, rebound tenderness with migration of pain to the right iliac fossa (RIF), raised TLC of 15,000. What is the Alvarado score? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 6

 

The Alvarado score (MANTRELS) is calculated based on specific clinical findings. 

 

 

In this patient:

 

  • Fever scores 1 point, 
  • Nausea scores 1 point, 
  • Rebound tenderness scores 1 point, 
  • Migration of pain to RIF scores 1 point, and 
  • Leukocytosis (TLC 15,000) scores 2 points. 

 

Total score: 1+1+1+1+2 = 6 points.

 

The mnemonic MANTRELS represents: M-Migration (1), A-Anorexia (1), N-Nausea/vomiting (1), T-Tenderness in RIF (1), R-Rebound tenderness (1), E-Elevated temperature/fever (1), L-Leukocytosis (2), S-Shift to left (1). 

 

Remember that Leukocytosis and Tenderness in RIF each score 2 points, while all others score 1 point. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Alvarado scoring for appendicitis, Leukocytosis (L) and Tenderness in RIF (T) each score 2 points, while Migration, Anorexia, Nausea/vomiting, Rebound tenderness, Elevated temperature, and Shift to left each score 1 point.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrectly paired with its corresponding classification or criteria system? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Achalasia â€“ LA classification

 

Achalasia is classified using the Chicago classification based on high-resolution manometry findings, not the LA classification. 

 

The Chicago classification divides achalasia into three types: 

 

  • Type I (classic achalasia with minimal esophageal pressurization), 
  • Type II (with panesophageal pressurization), and 
  • Type III (spastic achalasia with premature contractions). 

 

The LA (Los Angeles) classification is actually used for grading the severity of reflux esophagitis seen on endoscopy, grading from A to D based on the extent of mucosal breaks. This makes the pairing of Achalasia with LA classification incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic pancreatitis â€“ Manheim score: Correctly paired. The Manheim score is a multifactorial scoring system used to assess the severity of chronic pancreatitis, incorporating clinical, laboratory, and imaging parameters.

 

Option C. Colonoscopy â€“ Boston score: Correctly paired. The Boston Bowel Preparation Scale (BBPS) is used to assess the quality of bowel preparation during colonoscopy, scoring each colon segment from 0-3 based on visualization quality.

 

Option D. Parathyroid resection â€“ Miami criteria: Correctly paired. The Miami criteria are used intraoperatively during parathyroidectomy, where a >50% drop in PTH levels within 10 minutes after adenoma removal confirms successful surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Achalasia is classified using the Chicago classification (not LA classification); LA classification is used for grading reflux esophagitis on endoscopy.

choices.text: Improper dressing of an open chest wound can lead to tension pneumothorax
Simple pneumothorax can never become tension pneumothorax
It can commonly occur after mechanical ventilation with PEEP
Severe chest trauma with rib fractures can lead to it

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about tension pneumothorax? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Simple pneumothorax can never become tension pneumothorax

 

Simple pneumothorax can indeed progress to tension pneumothorax if the tear in the pleura develops a one-way valve mechanism, allowing air to enter but not escape from the pleural space. This progression occurs when the pleural defect acts as a flap valve during respiratory cycles, trapping air with each breath and progressively increasing intrapleural pressure. The statement that simple pneumothorax "can never become" tension pneumothorax is false, as this conversion is a well-recognized complication that requires vigilant monitoring of patients with simple pneumothorax.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Improper dressing of an open chest wound can lead to tension pneumothorax: This statement is correct. Complete occlusion of an open pneumothorax (sucking chest wound) without allowing air to escape can convert it to tension pneumothorax. This is why three-sided occlusive dressings are recommended.

 

Option C. It can commonly occur after mechanical ventilation with PEEP: This statement is correct. Positive pressure ventilation, especially with PEEP, can rupture emphysematous bullae or cause barotrauma, leading to tension pneumothorax, particularly in patients with COPD or ARDS.

 

Option D. Severe chest trauma with rib fractures can lead to it: This statement is correct. Fractured rib ends can lacerate the visceral pleura, and the torn pleural edges can create a one-way valve mechanism resulting in tension pneumothorax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Simple pneumothorax can progress to tension pneumothorax when a one-way valve mechanism develops at the pleural tear site, making continuous monitoring essential.

questions.text: A female presents with bleeding per rectum. On digital rectal examination, an ulcerated mass is palpated approximately 6 cm from the anal verge. Biopsy confirms intramucosal carcinoma. Based on this information, what is the correct stage of the rectal carcinoma? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stage 0

 

Intramucosal carcinoma of the rectum is classified as carcinoma in situ (Tis) in the TNM staging system. This represents malignant cells confined to the epithelium or invading the lamina propria but not breaching the muscularis mucosae. Since there is no invasion beyond the mucosa, it does not qualify as T1 (which requires submucosal invasion). According to AJCC staging, Tis N0 M0 corresponds to Stage 0, not Stage I. This distinction is critical because intramucosal carcinoma in the colorectum has virtually no risk of lymph node metastasis due to absence of lymphatics in the colonic mucosa, unlike the esophagus where intramucosal carcinoma can metastasize.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage 1: Incorrect. Stage I requires at least T1 disease, which means tumor invasion through the muscularis mucosae into the submucosa. Intramucosal carcinoma does not meet this criterion.

 

Option B. Stage 2A: Incorrect. Stage IIA requires T3 disease (tumor invades through muscularis propria into pericolorectal tissues) with N0 M0, which is far more advanced than intramucosal carcinoma.

 

Option C. Stage 2B: Incorrect. Stage IIB requires T4a disease (tumor penetrates visceral peritoneum) with N0 M0, representing much more advanced disease than carcinoma confined to the mucosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intramucosal carcinoma of the rectum is classified as carcinoma in situ (Tis), which corresponds to Stage 0 in AJCC staging, not Stage I which requires submucosal invasion.

choices.text: SADI-S (Single Anastomosis Duodeno-Ileal Bypass with Sleeve Gastrectomy)

questions.text: Identify the bariatric surgery shown in the image below. (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) SADI-S (Single Anastomosis Duodeno-Ileal Bypass with Sleeve Gastrectomy)

 

The image shows SADI-Sleeve (Single Anastomosis Duodeno-Ileal bypass with Sleeve gastrectomy). This procedure combines a sleeve gastrectomy (vertical stomach resection) with a single anastomosis between the duodenum and ileum, creating a duodeno-ileostomy. 

 

The key identifying features are: removal of part of the stomach (sleeve component) and ONE anastomosis connecting the first part of the duodenum to the ileum, bypassing most of the small intestine. The common channel is typically 250-300 cm. 

 

SADI-S is a simplified version of the duodenal switch, maintaining metabolic benefits while reducing surgical complexity by having only one anastomosis instead of two.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sleeve gastrectomy: Incorrect. Sleeve gastrectomy involves only stomach resection without any intestinal bypass or anastomosis. The image clearly shows an intestinal connection which is not present in simple sleeve gastrectomy.

 

Option C. BPD - Biliopancreatic Diversion: Incorrect. BPD is largely obsolete and involves two anastomoses: a gastro-ileostomy and a separate ileo-ileostomy creating a Roux-en-Y configuration. The image shows only one anastomosis at the duodenal level.

 

Option D. DS - Duodenal Switch: Incorrect. Classic duodenal switch involves sleeve gastrectomy with TWO anastomoses: duodeno-ileostomy and a separate jejuno-ileostomy forming a Roux limb. The image shows only a single anastomosis, distinguishing it from DS.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

SADI-Sleeve is identified by the combination of sleeve gastrectomy with a single duodeno-ileal anastomosis, differentiating it from DS (two anastomoses) and simple sleeve gastrectomy (no anastomosis).

questions.text: A female is cooking in the kitchen. Suddenly the cooker blasts, leading to dermo-epidermal burns of the face with singeing of eyebrows, bilateral upper limbs, and front of chest. What is the area of the burn? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 27-30%

 

Using Wallace's Rule of Nines for calculating Total Body Surface Area (TBSA) in adults: 

 

Bilateral upper limbs account for 9% each (total 18%), the anterior chest represents 9% (anterior trunk is 18% total, with chest being half of this), and partial face involvement from the cooker blast adds approximately 4-4.5% (since the entire head and neck together equal 9%). 

 

Singeing of eyebrows indicates facial burns from the explosion. 

 

The calculation yields: 18% (bilateral upper limbs) + 9% (anterior chest) + 4% (partial face) = 31% maximum. 

 

Since facial involvement is partial, the realistic range is 27-30% TBSA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In adults using Wallace's Rule of Nines: head and neck = 9%, each upper limb = 9%, anterior trunk = 18%, with face alone representing approximately 4-4.5% of TBSA.

questions.text: What is the Z-plasty surgical technique? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Technique for Scar Lengthening

 

Z-plasty is a plastic surgery technique used for scar lengthening and contracture release. It involves creating two triangular transposition flaps on either side of a scar or contracture, typically at 45-60 degree angles, forming a Z-shape. When these flaps are transposed (exchanged in position), the central limb of the Z is lengthened, effectively releasing contractures and reorienting scars along relaxed skin tension lines. 

 

 

The image demonstrates the classic steps: initial Z-incision design, flap elevation, and final transposition. This technique gains length by recruiting lateral tissue and can achieve 25-75% lengthening depending on the angles used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Technique of pedicled flap creation: Incorrect. While Z-plasty uses local flaps, it specifically creates transposition flaps, not pedicled flaps. Pedicled flaps maintain a vascular pedicle and are transferred to distant sites, whereas Z-plasty flaps are locally transposed.

 

Option C. Zigzag suture technique: Incorrect. Although the final scar appears zigzag-shaped, Z-plasty is not a suturing technique but a surgical procedure involving tissue rearrangement through flap transposition.

 

Option D. Technique of giving injection: Incorrect. The Z-track injection technique for intramuscular medications (pulling tissue laterally before injection) is completely different from Z-plasty surgical technique and should not be confused despite similar names.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Z-plasty is a transposition flap technique that lengthens scars and releases contractures by creating and exchanging triangular flaps at specific angles, achieving 25-75% length gain.

questions.text: In peripheral vascular disease (PVD), an Ankle-Brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) of which value indicates imminent risk of gangrene? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 0.3

 

Ankle-Brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of ankle systolic pressure to brachial systolic pressure, used to assess peripheral arterial disease severity. Imminent gangrene occurs when ABPI falls below 0.4, indicating critical limb ischemia with severely compromised tissue perfusion. At ABPI of 0.3, the limb has reached a critical state where tissue death is impending without urgent intervention. This represents end-stage peripheral vascular disease where the arterial supply is insufficient to maintain tissue viability, leading to irreversible ischemic changes and gangrene formation. Immediate revascularization is required to salvage the limb.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 0.9: Incorrect. ABPI of 0.9 is the lower limit of normal (normal range 0.9-1.3). Patients may have mild PAD but are typically asymptomatic or have minimal claudication symptoms.

 

Option B. 0.7: Incorrect. ABPI of 0.7 indicates moderate peripheral arterial disease with intermittent claudication during exercise. The limb is still adequately perfused at rest without tissue loss risk.

 

Option C. 0.5: Incorrect. ABPI of 0.5 causes severe claudication and rest pain, particularly at night. While concerning, it hasn't reached the critical ischemia threshold where gangrene is imminent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Critical limb ischemia with imminent gangrene occurs when ABPI falls below 0.4, with ABPI of 0.3 representing severe ischemia requiring urgent revascularization to prevent tissue loss.

questions.text: All of the following are associated with recurrent urinary stone formation except: (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hyper-citralluria

 

Hypercitraturia (elevated urinary citrate) is actually protective against stone formation, not a cause of recurrent stones. 

 

Citrate is a natural inhibitor of calcium stone formation as it binds to calcium in urine, forming soluble complexes that prevent calcium from precipitating with oxalate or phosphate. Citrate also directly inhibits crystal growth and aggregation. 

 

In fact, hypocitraturia (low citrate levels) is a risk factor for recurrent stones, and citrate supplementation (potassium citrate) is commonly used for stone prevention. 

 

Normal urinary citrate acts as a protective buffer against stone formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperoxaluria: Incorrect. Hyperoxaluria causes recurrent calcium oxalate stones, the most common type of kidney stones. Excess oxalate combines with calcium to form insoluble crystals that aggregate into stones.

 

Option B. Hyperuricosuria: Incorrect. Hyperuricosuria leads to uric acid stone formation and can also promote calcium oxalate stones by providing a nidus for heterogeneous nucleation through epitaxy.

 

Option C. Hypercalciuria: Incorrect. Hypercalciuria is the most common metabolic abnormality in stone formers, causing recurrent calcium oxalate and calcium phosphate stones through supersaturation of urine with calcium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypercitraturia is protective against kidney stones as citrate inhibits calcium stone formation; hypocitraturia (not hypercitraturia) is a risk factor for recurrent urolithiasis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common inherited bleeding disorder? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Von Willebrand Disease

 

Von Willebrand Disease (vWD) is the most common inherited bleeding disorder worldwide. It is caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor (vWF), a protein essential for platelet adhesion and stabilization of Factor VIII. The disease follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance in most cases, making it equally prevalent in males and females.

 

Von Willebrand Disease has three main subtypes:

 

  • Type 1 (most common, ~70% of cases): Partial quantitative deficiency of vWF with mild symptoms, follows autosomal dominant inheritance
  • Type 2: Qualitative defect where vWF is present in normal amounts but functions abnormally
  • Type 3 (most severe): Complete or near-complete absence of vWF with severe bleeding manifestations, follows autosomal recessive inheritance

 

The prevalence of vWD is approximately 1% of the general population, though many cases remain undiagnosed due to mild symptoms. This makes it significantly more common than hemophilia, which affects approximately 1 in 5,000-10,000 males.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC): This is incorrect because DIC is not an inherited disorder but rather an acquired condition. DIC is a pathological activation of the coagulation cascade that occurs secondary to various underlying conditions such as sepsis, malignancies (particularly acute promyelocytic leukemia and pancreatic cancer), obstetric complications (retained placenta, amniotic fluid embolism), and severe trauma. It results in simultaneous thrombosis and bleeding due to consumption of clotting factors and platelets.

 

Option C. Factor V Deficiency: This is incorrect because Factor V deficiency is an extremely rare inherited bleeding disorder with a prevalence of approximately 1 in 1 million. While it is indeed inherited (autosomal recessive pattern), its rarity makes it far less common than von Willebrand Disease. Interestingly, Factor V Leiden mutation (different from deficiency) causes hypercoagulability rather than bleeding, increasing the risk of thrombosis in affected individuals.

 

Option D. Hemophilia: This is incorrect as the most common inherited bleeding disorder, though hemophilia is indeed a common inherited bleeding disorder. Hemophilia follows an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern, affecting primarily males. Hemophilia A (Factor VIII deficiency) occurs in approximately 1 in 5,000 male births, while Hemophilia B (Factor IX deficiency) occurs in about 1 in 30,000 male births. Despite being well-known, hemophilia is less prevalent than von Willebrand Disease. Patients with hemophilia typically present with deep tissue bleeding, hemarthrosis, and prolonged bleeding following trauma or surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Von Willebrand Disease is the most common inherited bleeding disorder, with autosomal dominant inheritance (Type 1), affecting approximately 1% of the population, making it more prevalent than hemophilia or other inherited coagulation disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following renal histological features is characteristically seen in diabetic nephropathy but not typically seen in other glomerulonephritis? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kimmelstiel-Wilson

 

Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions, also known as nodular glomerulosclerosis, are the most characteristic and pathognomonic histopathological finding of diabetic nephropathy. These are acellular, eosinophilic, PAS-positive nodular lesions located in the mesangial regions of glomeruli. They represent advanced glycosylation end products and extracellular matrix accumulation resulting from chronic hyperglycemia.

 

The Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesion is considered the hallmark feature that is specific to diabetic nephropathy and is not typically seen in other forms of glomerulonephritis. This nodular pattern of glomerulosclerosis is so characteristic that its presence on renal biopsy is virtually diagnostic of diabetic nephropathy, even in the absence of a known history of diabetes. These nodules develop in approximately 15-30% of patients with diabetic nephropathy and indicate advanced diabetic kidney disease.

 

The formation of these nodules results from the chronic effects of hyperglycemia leading to increased production of advanced glycation end products (AGEs), activation of protein kinase C, and increased expression of growth factors like TGF-Î², all contributing to excessive extracellular matrix deposition in discrete nodular patterns within the mesangium.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mesangial sclerosis: This is incorrect because mesangial sclerosis, while commonly seen in diabetic nephropathy, is not specific to it. Diffuse mesangial sclerosis can be observed in various other glomerular diseases including IgA nephropathy, lupus nephritis, and chronic glomerulonephritis. In diabetic nephropathy, diffuse mesangial sclerosis typically precedes the development of nodular lesions and represents mesangial matrix expansion, but this finding alone is not pathognomonic of diabetic kidney disease.

 

Option C. GBM thickening: This is incorrect because glomerular basement membrane (GBM) thickening is a common but non-specific finding. While GBM thickening is indeed one of the earliest morphological changes in diabetic nephropathy, it is also seen in many other conditions including membranous nephropathy, lupus nephritis class V, and even as a normal aging change. The GBM thickening in diabetes results from increased synthesis and decreased degradation of type IV collagen and other matrix proteins, but this change is not unique to diabetic nephropathy.

 

Option D. Foot process effacement: This is incorrect because foot process effacement (podocyte foot process fusion) is a non-specific finding seen in virtually all proteinuric kidney diseases. It is commonly observed in minimal change disease, focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, membranous nephropathy, and many other glomerular diseases. While podocyte injury and foot process effacement do occur in diabetic nephropathy and contribute to proteinuria, this finding is not characteristic or specific to diabetic kidney disease and is actually more prominent in other conditions like minimal change disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions (nodular glomerulosclerosis) are the pathognomonic histological feature of diabetic nephropathy, while mesangial sclerosis, GBM thickening, and foot process effacement are non-specific findings seen in multiple glomerular diseases.

questions.text: Which of the following immunodeficiency disorders is least likely to cause rejection of a mismatched transplant due to absent or severely impaired immune function? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bare lymphocyte syndrome

 

Bare Lymphocyte Syndrome (BLS) is a rare form of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) caused by a failure to express Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) molecules on the surface of antigen-presenting cells. There are two types:

 

  • Type I BLS: Defective MHC Class I expression
  • Type II BLS (more common): Defective MHC Class II expression

 

In either case, this defect severely impairs antigen presentation, which is crucial for initiating a T-cell-mediated immune response.

 

  • In Type II BLS, absence of MHC Class II leads to:
    • Lack of CD4+ T-cell maturation
    • Impaired B-cell activation and antibody production
    • Global suppression of adaptive immunity

 

Since transplant rejection depends on the recipient's immune system recognizing and attacking donor antigensâ€”a process that requires intact MHC-mediated antigen presentation and T-cell activationâ€”patients with BLS are unable to mount such a response effectively. As a result, they are the least likely to reject a mismatched transplant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chediak-Higashi syndrome: Incorrect. This is a primary immunodeficiency affecting neutrophil function, characterized by defective lysosomal degranulation and giant cytoplasmic granules. While it causes increased susceptibility to infections, the basic immune recognition mechanisms and MHC function remain intact, so transplant rejection can still occur.

 

Option B. Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome: Incorrect. This is an X-linked immunodeficiency affecting primarily T cell function and platelet function, but MHC expression and basic antigen presentation mechanisms remain functional. Patients can still mount immune responses against mismatched transplants, though the response may be somewhat impaired.

 

Option D. Job syndrome: Incorrect. Also known as Hyper-IgE syndrome, this condition is characterized by elevated IgE levels, recurrent infections, and eczema. While immune function is abnormal, MHC expression and antigen presentation pathways remain functional, allowing for transplant rejection to occur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bare lymphocyte syndrome causes defective MHC class I or II expression, preventing proper antigen presentation and making transplant rejection least likely among immunodeficiency disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following is the incorrect association? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) p53 and mucosal neuroma

 

The incorrect association is p53 and mucosal neuroma. 

 

Mucosal neuromas are characteristic features of Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2B (MEN 2B or MEN 3 syndrome), which is caused by mutations in the RET gene, not p53. MEN 2B presents with the classic triad of medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and mucosal neuromas, along with a marfanoid habitus.

 

The RET gene encodes a receptor tyrosine kinase, and germline mutations lead to constitutive activation of this receptor, resulting in the development of endocrine tumors. The mucosal neuromas in MEN 2B appear as small, benign tumors on the lips, tongue, and oral mucosa, giving a characteristic appearance.

 

p53, known as the "guardian of the genome," is a tumor suppressor gene that is mutated in approximately 50% of all human cancers. While p53 mutations are indeed common in many cancers including breast, colon, lung, and ovarian cancers, they have no association with mucosal neuromas or MEN syndromes. p53 mutations are associated with Li-Fraumeni syndrome when inherited in the germline, predisposing to multiple cancers but not mucosal neuromas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PTEN and thyroid: This is a correct association. PTEN mutations cause Cowden syndrome (PTEN hamartoma tumor syndrome), which significantly increases the risk of thyroid cancer, particularly follicular thyroid carcinoma. Patients with Cowden syndrome have up to a 35% lifetime risk of developing thyroid cancer, making thyroid surveillance crucial. Other features include trichilemmomas, macrocephaly, and increased risk of breast and endometrial cancers.

 

Option B. BRCA2 and prostate: This is a correct association. BRCA2 mutations significantly increase the risk of prostate cancer in males, with carriers having up to a 20% lifetime risk compared to 12% in the general population. BRCA2-associated prostate cancers tend to be more aggressive with higher Gleason scores and poorer prognosis. While BRCA2 is better known for its association with breast and ovarian cancers, the prostate cancer risk in male carriers is substantial. BRCA2 mutations also increase the risk of pancreatic cancer.

 

Option C. STK11 and breast cancer: This is a correct association, though less commonly known. STK11 (also known as LKB1) mutations cause Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, characterized by hamartomatous polyps throughout the gastrointestinal tract and mucocutaneous pigmentation. While patients are primarily at risk for gastrointestinal cancers (colon, pancreatic), females with STK11 mutations have significantly increased risks of breast cancer (32-54% lifetime risk) and ovarian cancer. The breast cancer association makes this a particularly tricky option, as many are unaware of this connection beyond the classic GI manifestations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucosal neuromas are associated with MEN 2B syndrome caused by RET gene mutations, NOT p53; while PTEN causes Cowden syndrome with thyroid cancer risk, BRCA2 increases prostate cancer risk, and STK11 (Peutz-Jeghers) increases breast cancer risk in females.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best gene analysis investigation for a female patient with history of breast and ovarian cancer? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) BRCA1, 2 gene

 

BRCA1 and BRCA2 gene analysis is the most appropriate investigation for a female patient with a history of both breast and ovarian cancer. This combination strongly suggests Hereditary Breast and Ovarian Cancer (HBOC) syndrome, which is caused by germline mutations in BRCA1 (chromosome 17q) or BRCA2 (chromosome 13q) genes.

 

BRCA1 and BRCA2 are tumor suppressor genes involved in DNA repair through homologous recombination. Mutations in these genes significantly increase lifetime cancer risks:

 

  • BRCA1 mutations: 60-80% lifetime risk of breast cancer and 40-60% risk of ovarian cancer
  • BRCA2 mutations: 45-85% lifetime risk of breast cancer and 10-30% risk of ovarian cancer

 

The presence of both breast and ovarian cancer in the same patient, especially if occurring at a young age or with positive family history, is a classic presentation that warrants BRCA1/2 testing. Identifying these mutations has important implications:

 

  1. Guides treatment decisions (PARP inhibitors for BRCA-mutated cancers)
  2. Informs risk-reduction strategies (prophylactic surgeries, enhanced surveillance)
  3. Enables cascade testing of family members who may be at risk

 

Additionally, BRCA mutations are associated with increased risks of pancreatic cancer, prostate cancer (especially in BRCA2), and male breast cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PTEN gene: This is incorrect because PTEN mutations cause Cowden syndrome, which primarily increases the risk of thyroid cancer (35% lifetime risk), breast cancer, and endometrial cancer. While Cowden syndrome does increase breast cancer risk, it is not typically associated with ovarian cancer. 

 

Option B. P53 gene: This is incorrect as the best specific test, although p53 is indeed the most commonly mutated gene in breast cancer overall (found in approximately 50% of all human cancers). However, germline p53 mutations cause Li-Fraumeni syndrome, which presents with a different spectrum of cancers including sarcomas, brain tumors, adrenocortical carcinomas, and early-onset breast cancer. 

 

Option D. CDH1 gene: This is incorrect because CDH1 mutations are associated with Hereditary Diffuse Gastric Cancer syndrome and lobular breast cancer specifically. CDH1 encodes E-cadherin, and mutations lead to increased risk of diffuse gastric cancer (70% lifetime risk) and lobular breast cancer (40% risk in women). The histological pattern of "Indian file" arrangement is characteristic of lobular carcinoma associated with CDH1 mutations. However, CDH1 mutations are not associated with ovarian cancer risk.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

BRCA1/2 gene analysis is the gold standard investigation for patients with both breast and ovarian cancer, as this combination strongly suggests Hereditary Breast and Ovarian Cancer syndrome, guiding treatment decisions and family risk assessment.

questions.text: Which type of programmed cell death primarily involves the action of caspase-1? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pyroptosis

 

Caspase-1 is a key inflammatory caspase that plays a central role in pyroptosis. When activated, caspase-1 is responsible for the conversion of interleukins into their active forms, specifically converting pro-IL-1Î² and pro-IL-18 into mature, biologically active IL-1Î² and IL-18. This process occurs during pyroptosis, a highly inflammatory form of programmed cell death that primarily occurs during bacterial infections. The activation of caspase-1 leads to inflammasome formation and the subsequent release of these active inflammatory cytokines, which results in cell death accompanied by fever and systemic inflammatory responses. 

 

Pyroptosis involves caspases 1, 4, 5, and 11, with inflammasome formation and IL-1 release being characteristic features. This makes pyroptosis distinct from other forms of cell death as it serves as a host defense mechanism against bacterial pathogens while triggering robust inflammatory responses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Apoptosis: This is incorrect. Apoptosis is mediated by different caspases including executioner caspases (3, 6, 7) and initiator caspases (8, 9). The intrinsic apoptotic pathway involves caspase-9, which binds to the cytochrome C and APAF-1 complex, while the extrinsic pathway involves caspase-8. Apoptosis is characterized by the absence of inflammation and does not involve caspase-1 or interleukin conversion.

 

Option C. Necroptosis: This is incorrect. Necroptosis represents programmed necrosis that occurs through a caspase-independent pathway. It involves receptor-interacting protein kinases (RIPK1 and RIPK3) and does not require caspase-1 activation or interleukin conversion. While necroptosis does cause inflammation and plasma membrane damage, it operates through entirely different molecular mechanisms.

 

Option D. Necrosis: This is incorrect. Classical necrosis is an uncontrolled form of cell death resulting from severe cellular injury, toxins, or ischemia. It is not a programmed process and does not involve specific caspase activation pathways or organized interleukin conversion. The inflammatory responses in necrosis occur as consequences of cellular damage rather than through coordinated molecular pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Caspase-1 is the primary caspase responsible for pyroptosis and functions by converting interleukins (pro-IL-1Î² and pro-IL-18) into their active forms, leading to inflammasome-mediated inflammatory cell death.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with a history of coronary heart disease (CHD) and renal failure was admitted to the ICU with elevated blood pressure (BP 190/110 mmHg) and declining urine output. The intensivist administers fenoldopam intravenously. How does this drug help in improving renal function in this patient? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) D1 agonism

 

Fenoldopam is a selective dopamine D1 receptor agonist that improves renal function through renal vasodilation. The mechanism works as follows:

 

D1 receptors are G-protein coupled receptors (GPCR) that stimulate adenylyl cyclase, leading to increased cAMP levels. These receptors are abundantly present in renal blood vessels, particularly in the afferent and efferent arterioles of the glomerulus.

 

When fenoldopam binds to D1 receptors in renal vessels, it causes:

 

  1. Renal vasodilation - Direct relaxation of renal vascular smooth muscle
  2. Increased renal blood flow - Enhanced perfusion to both cortical and medullary regions
  3. Improved glomerular filtration rate - Better kidney function due to increased perfusion pressure
  4. Enhanced natriuresis - Increased sodium excretion through tubular effects
  5. Diuretic effect - Improved urine output due to better renal perfusion

 

This mechanism is particularly beneficial in patients with renal impairment and hypertensive emergencies, as it simultaneously reduces blood pressure while protecting and improving kidney function. Fenoldopam is especially valuable because it maintains or improves renal blood flow even while lowering systemic blood pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. D2 antagonism: This is incorrect. Fenoldopam does not work by blocking D2 receptors. D2 receptors are involved in inhibiting adenylyl cyclase (Gi protein-coupled), and their antagonism would not produce the desired renal vasodilation. Additionally, fenoldopam is a D1 agonist, not a D2 antagonist.

 

Option C. Alpha antagonism: This is incorrect. While alpha-1 antagonists like doxazosin can cause vasodilation and reduce blood pressure, fenoldopam does not work through alpha-adrenergic receptor blockade. Alpha antagonists primarily affect peripheral vascular resistance but don't have the specific renal protective effects that fenoldopam provides through D1 receptor stimulation.

 

Option D. Muscarinic antagonism: This is incorrect. Muscarinic receptor antagonism (anticholinergic effects) would actually be counterproductive in this clinical scenario. Anticholinergic effects include tachycardia, reduced GI motility, and urinary retention - none of which would improve renal function or be desirable in a patient with renal failure and hypertensive crisis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fenoldopam is a selective D1 receptor agonist that improves renal function by causing renal vasodilation, increasing renal blood flow, and enhancing glomerular filtration rate, making it particularly useful in hypertensive emergencies with renal compromise.

questions.text:
Match the following drugs with their respective Schedules: (INICET MAY 2025)

 

 

Choose the option where the match for Morphine is correct.
questions.solution:
Ans. D)  A-3, B-4, C-1, D-2

 

A. Hepatitis B vaccine - Schedule G (3): Vaccines require medical supervision and guidance for administration. Schedule G drugs require expert medical guidance and supervision during administration. Healthcare professionals must oversee vaccine administration due to potential adverse reactions and the need for proper technique.

 

B. Veterinary drugs - Schedule Z (4): This is specifically designated for animal/veterinary medications. Schedule Z covers all drugs meant for veterinary use, ensuring they are not used in humans and meet specific standards for animal healthcare.

 

C. Morphine - Schedule X (1): Morphine is a controlled narcotic substance requiring extreme caution. Schedule X drugs are addictive substances that require:

 

  • Double prescription system
  • Pharmacist must retain photocopy of prescription
  • Special storage and dispensing requirements
  • Strict record-keeping to prevent abuse

 

D. Insulin - Schedule H (2): Insulin is a prescription-only drug requiring handwritten prescription. Schedule H drugs cannot be dispensed without a valid prescription from a registered medical practitioner and require careful dispensing protocols.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Some important Drug Schedule:

 

  • C â€“ Drugs required COLD STORAGE like Vaccines. 
  • G â€“ require expert GUIDANCE like hormones, vaccines, etc 
  • H â€“ require PRESCRIPTION (Hand written)
  • J â€“ JADU (Treatment of diseases like HIV/AIDS, cancer, etc )
  • M â€“ GMP (provides guidelines for manufacturing unit of drugs)
  • P â€“ Period (describes the Shelf Life of drugs)
  • T â€“ Traditional medicine regulations (Ayurveda, Unani, etc)
  • X â€“ eXtreme cautions â€“ mainly for addictive drugs like morphine, ketamine, etc
  • Y â€“ Yes to Clinical Trial (guidelines)
  • Z â€“ ZOO (covers Veterinary drugs)

choices.text: It is used in type 2 lepra reaction (ENL)
It is used in relapsing multiple myeloma

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding thalidomide is false? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It acts as an antimetabolite

 

Thalidomide does not act as an antimetabolite. This statement is false because thalidomide's mechanism of action is fundamentally different from antimetabolites.

 

Thalidomide's actual mechanism of action:

 

  • Immunomodulatory effects: Modulates various cytokines including TNF-Î±, interleukin-6, and interleukin-10
  • Anti-angiogenic properties: Inhibits new blood vessel formation by affecting VEGF and bFGF
  • Protein targeting: Affects cereblon protein, which normally helps in limb development during embryogenesis
  • T-cell modulation: Alters T-helper cell responses and reduces inflammatory cytokine production

 

Antimetabolites, in contrast, are drugs that mimic natural metabolites and interfere with DNA synthesis or other metabolic pathways (like methotrexate, 5-fluorouracil, or 6-mercaptopurine). Thalidomide does not interfere with nucleotide synthesis or act as a false substrate in metabolic pathways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It is a teratogenic drug: This is true. Thalidomide is highly teratogenic, causing severe birth defects, particularly phocomelia (absence or malformation of limbs). It affects cereblon protein function during embryonic development, leading to impaired limb formation. This teratogenic effect led to its initial withdrawal from the market in the 1960s.

 

Option C. It is used in type 2 lepra reaction (ENL): This is true. Erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL) is a type 2 lepra reaction that occurs in patients with lepromatous leprosy. Thalidomide is highly effective for this indication due to its immunosuppressive properties, particularly its ability to reduce TNF-Î± levels and modulate the inflammatory response.

 

Option D. It is used in relapsing multiple myeloma: This is true. Thalidomide is an established treatment for multiple myeloma, often used in combination with other agents. Its anti-angiogenic and immunomodulatory properties help control the disease by inhibiting tumor blood supply and modulating the bone marrow microenvironment that supports myeloma cell growth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thalidomide is not an antimetabolite but works through immunomodulatory and anti-angiogenic mechanisms, affecting cytokines and the cereblon protein, and is used clinically for multiple myeloma and erythema nodosum leprosum despite its teratogenic potential.

questions.text: Which of the following drug is associated with cholestasis without significant portal inflammation? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Oestrogen plus androgen

 

Oestrogen plus androgen cause pure cholestasis without significant portal inflammation. This represents a distinct pattern of drug-induced liver injury characterized by:

 

Mechanism of estrogen/androgen-induced cholestasis:

 

  • Altered bile acid synthesis: Hormones modify hepatic bile acid metabolism
  • Reduced bile flow: Decreased canalicular bile acid-dependent and independent flow
  • Membrane effects: Changes in hepatocyte membrane fluidity affecting bile transport
  • Transporter inhibition: Interference with bile salt export pumps (BSEP) and multidrug resistance proteins

 

Clinical presentation:

 

  • Elevated alkaline phosphatase and bilirubin
  • Minimal elevation of aminotransferases (ALT/AST)
  • Absence of significant hepatocellular necrosis
  • No inflammatory infiltrate in portal areas
  • Reversible upon discontinuation

 

This type of cholestasis is commonly seen with oral contraceptives, anabolic steroids, and hormone replacement therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acetaminophen: This is incorrect. Acetaminophen causes acute hepatocellular necrosis with significant portal inflammation. It produces centrilobular hepatic necrosis through its toxic metabolite NAPQI (N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine), which depletes glutathione stores and causes direct hepatocyte damage. This results in massive hepatocellular injury with inflammatory infiltrate and potential acute liver failure.

 

Option B. Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid: This is incorrect. Amoxiclav is associated with mixed hepatocellular-cholestatic injury with portal inflammation. The clavulanic acid component particularly causes hepatotoxicity with inflammatory changes in the liver parenchyma and portal areas. This can progress to significant hepatocellular damage with portal tract inflammation.

 

Option C. Isoniazid: This is incorrect. Isoniazid causes hepatocellular injury with portal inflammation. It produces hepatotoxicity through formation of toxic metabolites that cause direct hepatocyte damage, leading to hepatocellular necrosis with inflammatory infiltrate in portal areas. This can progress to fulminant hepatic failure in severe cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Estrogens and androgens cause pure cholestasis without portal inflammation by affecting bile flow and transport mechanisms, whereas other hepatotoxic drugs like acetaminophen, amoxiclav, and isoniazid cause hepatocellular injury with significant inflammatory changes.

questions.text:
Erythropoietin is primarily used in the treatment of which type of anemia? (INICET MAY 2025)

 

  1. Nutritional anemia
  2. Chronic kidney disease (CKD)-related anemia
  3. Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS)-related anemia
  4. Aplastic anemia
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 & 3

 

Erythropoietin is used when the bone marrow is not producing enough RBCs due to insufficient erythropoietin stimulus, and it works by stimulating the bone marrow to increase red blood cell production.

 

2. Chronic kidney disease (CKD)-related anemia: This is the PRIMARY indication for erythropoietin. In CKD, the kidneys (which normally produce ~90% of the body's erythropoietin) have reduced capacity to synthesize erythropoietin. This leads to decreased stimulation of erythropoiesis in the bone marrow, resulting in anemia. Exogenous erythropoietin administration compensates for this deficiency and stimulates RBC production.

 

3. Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS)-related anemia: This is a secondary indication where erythropoietin can be useful, particularly in early stages of MDS. While the effectiveness is limited and variable, it can provide benefit in selected patients with lower-risk MDS who have relatively preserved bone marrow function. The response rate is generally lower compared to CKD-related anemia.

 

The mechanism in both conditions involves stimulating erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow when the marrow retains some capacity to respond to erythropoietin stimulation.

 

Incorrect Options:

 

1. Nutritional anemia: This is incorrect. Nutritional anemias (like iron deficiency, B12 deficiency, or folate deficiency) are caused by lack of essential nutrients needed for RBC production, not by insufficient erythropoietin. These conditions require specific nutritional supplementation (iron, vitamin B12, folic acid) rather than erythropoietin. Giving erythropoietin without correcting the underlying nutritional deficiency would be ineffective.

 

4. Aplastic anemia: This is incorrect. In aplastic anemia, there is severe bone marrow failure with destruction or suppression of hematopoietic stem cells. The bone marrow lacks the cellular machinery to respond to erythropoietin stimulation. Treatment requires immunosuppressive therapy, bone marrow transplantation, or supportive care, but erythropoietin is not effective because the target cells (erythroid precursors) are severely depleted or absent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythropoietin is primarily indicated for CKD-related anemia (due to decreased renal erythropoietin production), anticancer drug induced anemiaâ€™s and rarely can be used in selected cases of myelodysplastic syndrome, but is not effective for nutritional deficiencies or aplastic anemia where the underlying pathophysiology differs.

questions.text:
Which pharmacokinetic parameters are used to determine the loading dose of an orally administered drug? (INICET MAY 2025)

 

  1. Volume of distribution (Vd)
  2. Half-life
  3. Plasma concentration
  4. Bioavailability
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3 and 4

 

The loading dose calculation for orally administered drugs requires three pharmacokinetic parameters:

 

Loading Dose Formula for Oral Administration: 

 

LD = (Vd Ã— Target Plasma Concentration) Ã· Bioavailability

 

1. Volume of distribution (Vd): This represents the theoretical volume into which the drug distributes in the body. A larger Vd means the drug distributes extensively into tissues, requiring a higher loading dose to achieve the desired plasma concentration.

 

3. Target Plasma Concentration: This is the desired steady-state concentration we want to achieve rapidly. The loading dose is calculated to immediately reach this therapeutic level without waiting for multiple maintenance doses.

 

4. Bioavailability (F): For oral administration, bioavailability accounts for the fraction of the administered dose that reaches systemic circulation. Since oral drugs may have incomplete absorption due to first-pass metabolism, poor absorption, or other factors, the loading dose must be adjusted by dividing by the fractional bioavailability to ensure adequate drug reaches the systemic circulation.

 

The relationship shows that if bioavailability is low, a higher oral loading dose is needed to achieve the same plasma concentration compared to intravenous administration.

 

Incorrect Option:

 

2. Half-life: This is incorrect. Half-life determines how frequently maintenance doses should be given and how long it takes to reach steady-state, but it does not directly influence the loading dose calculation. The loading dose is designed to rapidly achieve target concentration regardless of the drug's elimination rate. 

 

Half-life is relevant for maintenance dosing: 

 

MD = Clearance Ã— Target Plasma Concentration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Loading dose for oral drugs depends on volume of distribution, target plasma concentration, and bioavailability, but not half-life, as the formula is 

 

LD = (Vd Ã— Target Plasma Concentration) Ã· Bioavailability (F)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the pharmacological relationship between imipramine and diphenhydramine? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both block muscarinic receptors

 

Both imipramine and diphenhydramine share a common pharmacological property: both block muscarinic receptors, resulting in significant anticholinergic effects.

 

Imipramine (Tricyclic Antidepressant):

 

  • Primary mechanism: Inhibits reuptake of norepinephrine and serotonin
  • Secondary properties: Strong anticholinergic activity, alpha-1 adrenergic blockade, antihistaminic effects, and potential to cause seizures
  • Anticholinergic effects: Blocks muscarinic receptors leading to dry mouth, blurred vision, constipation, urinary retention, and tachycardia

 

Diphenhydramine (First-Generation Antihistamine):

 

  • Primary mechanism: H1 receptor antagonist
  • Secondary properties: Strong anticholinergic activity and ability to cross the blood-brain barrier (unlike second-generation antihistamines)
  • Anticholinergic effects: Blocks muscarinic receptors causing similar side effects as tricyclics

 

Shared Clinical Consequences: Both drugs produce anticholinergic toxicity including:

 

  • Dry mouth (xerostomia)
  • Blurred vision (cycloplegia)
  • Tachycardia
  • Constipation
  • Urinary retention
  • CNS effects (confusion, sedation)

 

This shared property makes concurrent use potentially dangerous due to additive anticholinergic effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Imipramine inhibits diphenhydramine's action: This is incorrect. There is no direct inhibitory relationship between these drugs. They work through different primary mechanisms (norepinephrine/serotonin reuptake inhibition vs H1 receptor antagonism) and do not directly interfere with each other's primary actions.

 

Option B. Diphenhydramine inhibits imipramine's action: This is incorrect. Diphenhydramine does not interfere with imipramine's ability to block monoamine reuptake. The drugs work on different primary targets and do not have a direct antagonistic relationship.

 

Option D. Both are norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors: This is incorrect. While imipramine is indeed a norepinephrine (and serotonin) reuptake inhibitor, diphenhydramine is not. Diphenhydramine's primary mechanism is H1 receptor antagonism, not monoamine reuptake inhibition. Its anticholinergic effects are due to muscarinic receptor blockade, not norepinephrine reuptake inhibition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Both imipramine (tricyclic antidepressant) and diphenhydramine (first-generation antihistamine) share significant anticholinergic properties through muscarinic receptor blockade, leading to similar side effects including dry mouth, blurred vision, and tachycardia.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is most teratogenic and strongly associated with neural tube defects (NTDs) when used during pregnancy? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Valproic acid

 

Valproic acid is the most teratogenic antiepileptic drug and has the strongest association with neural tube defects during pregnancy.

 

Mechanism of teratogenicity:

 

  • Folate metabolism interference: Valproic acid inhibits folate-dependent enzymes involved in DNA synthesis and methylation
  • Histone deacetylase inhibition: Affects gene expression during critical periods of neural development
  • Oxidative stress: Increases reactive oxygen species that can damage developing neural tissue
  • Disrupted neural tube closure: Interferes with the normal process of neural tube formation during weeks 3-4 of gestation

 

Clinical consequences:

 

  • Neural tube defects: 1-2% risk (10-20 times higher than general population)
  • Spina bifida: Most common NTD associated with valproate
  • Anencephaly and encephalocele: Less common but severe NTDs
  • Other malformations: Cardiac defects, cleft lip/palate, limb defects
  • Neurodevelopmental effects: Cognitive impairment and autism spectrum disorders

 

Prevention strategy:

 

  • High-dose folic acid: 4-5 mg daily (higher than standard 400 mcg prenatal dose)
  • Preconception counseling: Start folate supplementation before conception

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lamotrigine: This is incorrect. Lamotrigine is considered the least teratogenic antiepileptic drug and is preferred during pregnancy. It has minimal risk for major malformations and no significant association with neural tube defects. Lamotrigine levels should be monitored during pregnancy due to increased clearance.

 

Option B. Oxcarbazepine: This is incorrect. While oxcarbazepine does carry some teratogenic risk, it is significantly lower than valproic acid. It may be associated with minor malformations but does not have the strong association with neural tube defects that characterizes valproate exposure.

 

Option D. Levetiracetam: This is incorrect. Levetiracetam is considered one of the safer antiepileptic drugs during pregnancy with relatively low teratogenic potential. Current evidence suggests it has a lower risk profile compared to traditional antiepileptics like valproate, though long-term data is still being accumulated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Valproic acid is the most teratogenic antiepileptic drug with a 1-2% risk of neural tube defects, requiring high-dose folic acid (4-5 mg) supplementation for prevention, while lamotrigine is the least teratogenic alternative.

choices.text: It is a non-competitive Inhibitor ATP citrate lyase
It inhibits the de novo synthesis of cholesterol in hepatocytes
It can be used concomitantly with statins

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding bempedoic acid? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is a non-competitive Inhibitor ATP citrate lyase

 

Bempedoic acid is a competitive inhibitor of ATP citrate lyase, NOT a non-competitive inhibitor. This statement is false.

 

Mechanism of action: Bempedoic acid works upstream of HMG-CoA reductase in the cholesterol synthesis pathway. The enzyme ATP citrate lyase converts citrate (from the TCA cycle) to acetyl-CoA, which is the first step in cholesterol biosynthesis. Bempedoic acid competitively inhibits this enzyme, meaning it competes with the natural substrate (citrate) for the same binding site on ATP citrate lyase.

 

Competitive vs Non-competitive inhibition:

 

  • Competitive inhibition: The inhibitor competes with substrate for the active site; can be overcome by increasing substrate concentration
  • Non-competitive inhibition: The inhibitor binds to a different site, changing enzyme shape; cannot be overcome by increasing substrate concentration

 

Bempedoic acid's competitive inhibition mechanism allows for reversible binding and explains why it effectively reduces cholesterol synthesis when present in therapeutic concentrations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It is a dicarboxylic acid: This is TRUE. Bempedoic acid is chemically classified as a dicarboxylic acid, containing two carboxylic acid functional groups (-COOH) in its molecular structure. This chemical classification is accurate and represents one of the drug's defining structural characteristics.

 

Option C. It inhibits the de novo synthesis of cholesterol in hepatocytes: This is TRUE. Bempedoic acid specifically targets the cholesterol biosynthesis pathway by blocking ATP citrate lyase, preventing the conversion of citrate to acetyl-CoA. This effectively stops de novo cholesterol synthesis in hepatocytes (liver cells), which is the primary site of cholesterol production in the body.

 

Option D. It can be used concomitantly with statins: This is TRUE. Bempedoic acid can be used either as monotherapy in statin-intolerant patients or as combination therapy with statins for enhanced cholesterol reduction.
