Since it works upstream of HMG-CoA reductase (statin target), the combination provides synergistic cholesterol-lowering effects through complementary mechanisms without significant drug interactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bempedoic acid is a competitive inhibitor of ATP citrate lyase that blocks cholesterol synthesis upstream of statins, can be used alone or with statins, and is chemically classified as a dicarboxylic acid.

choices.text: Refractory seizures due to pharmacodynamic resistance
Carbamazepine toxicity due to drug interaction
Erythromycin toxicity due to enzyme induction
Decreased absorption of carbamazepine leading to subtherapeutic levels

questions.text: A 28-year-old male with a known history of generalized tonic-clonic seizures is on long-term carbamazepine therapy. He recently developed a sore throat and was prescribed erythromycin by a local physician. Two days later, he presents to the emergency department with complaints of dizziness, diplopia, ataxia, and confusion. What is the most likely explanation for his symptoms? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Carbamazepine toxicity due to drug interaction

 

This patient is experiencing carbamazepine toxicity due to drug interaction with erythromycin. The constellation of symptoms - dizziness, diplopia, ataxia, and confusion - represents classic cerebellar symptoms that occur with antiepileptic drug overdose.

 

Mechanism of interaction: Erythromycin is a microsomal enzyme inhibitor that significantly impairs the metabolism of carbamazepine. Carbamazepine is metabolized by CYP3A4 enzymes, and erythromycin potently inhibits these enzymes. When erythromycin blocks carbamazepine's metabolism, the antiepileptic drug cannot be broken down normally, leading to:

 

  • Accumulation of carbamazepine in plasma
  • Elevated drug levels exceeding therapeutic range
  • Development of dose-related toxicity symptoms

 

Cerebellar toxicity pattern: All antiepileptic drugs can cause cerebellar symptoms when levels become excessive. These symptoms include ataxia (unsteady gait), diplopia (double vision), dizziness, and confusion - exactly what this patient is experiencing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Refractory seizures due to pharmacodynamic resistance: This is incorrect. The patient is not having seizures; he's experiencing toxicity symptoms. Pharmacodynamic resistance would manifest as breakthrough seizures, not cerebellar symptoms. The temporal relationship with erythromycin administration points to drug interaction rather than treatment resistance.

 

Option C. Erythromycin toxicity due to enzyme induction: This is incorrect on multiple levels. First, the symptoms described are not typical of erythromycin toxicity (which usually involves GI effects and QT prolongation). Second, erythromycin is an enzyme inhibitor, not inducer. Third, enzyme induction would decrease drug levels, not increase them.

 

Option D. Decreased absorption of carbamazepine leading to subtherapeutic levels: This is incorrect. Subtherapeutic levels would cause breakthrough seizures, not the cerebellar toxicity symptoms described. Additionally, erythromycin doesn't interfere with carbamazepine absorption; the interaction occurs at the metabolic level through enzyme inhibition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythromycin inhibits microsomal enzymes (CYP3A4) that metabolize carbamazepine, leading to drug accumulation and characteristic cerebellar toxicity symptoms (ataxia, diplopia, dizziness, confusion) in patients on chronic antiepileptic therapy.

choices.text: To make the compound more permeable across membranes
To extract functional proteins through oxidase/reductase reactions
To introduce or expose functional groups for further metabolism
To directly conjugate the compound and facilitate excretion

questions.text: What is the main role of Phase 1 in xenobiotic metabolism? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) To introduce or expose functional groups for further metabolism

 

Phase 1 metabolism's main role is to introduce or expose functional groups for further metabolism. Phase 1 reactions essentially "prepare" the drug molecule by creating or exposing reactive sites that can then be acted upon by Phase 2 enzymes.

 

Mechanism of Phase 1 reactions: Phase 1 reactions are primarily catabolic and include:

 

  • Oxidation (most common Phase 1 reaction)
  • Reduction
  • Hydrolysis
  • Deamination
  • Cyclization

 

These reactions create or expose functional groups such as:

 

  • Hydroxyl groups (-OH)
  • Carboxyl groups (-COOH)
  • Amino groups (-NH2)
  • Sulfhydryl groups (-SH)

 

Purpose: The exposed functional groups serve as "handles" or attachment points for Phase 2 conjugation reactions. This is why Phase 1 makes the drug molecule "sticky" - it creates reactive sites where conjugating molecules can attach during Phase 2 metabolism.

 

Sequential process: Phase 1 â†’ Phase 2 â†’ Excretion

 

  1. Phase 1 exposes functional groups
  2. Phase 2 conjugates these groups (making the compound water-soluble)
  3. Water-soluble metabolites can be excreted

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To make the compound more permeable across membranes: This is incorrect. Phase 1 doesn't primarily aim to increase membrane permeability. In fact, the ultimate goal of drug metabolism is to make compounds less permeable (more water-soluble) for excretion, but this is achieved by Phase 2, not Phase 1.

 

Option B. To extract functional proteins through oxidase/reductase reactions: This is incorrect. Phase 1 reactions don't extract proteins. They use oxidase and reductase enzymes (like cytochrome P450) to modify drug molecules, but the goal is to modify the drug substrate, not extract proteins.

 

Option D. To directly conjugate the compound and facilitate excretion: This is incorrect. Direct conjugation is the function of Phase 2 metabolism, not Phase 1. Phase 2 reactions include glucuronidation, sulfation, acetylation, and other conjugation reactions that make compounds water-soluble for excretion. Phase 1 prepares the molecule for these conjugation reactions but doesn't perform them directly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phase 1 metabolism primarily functions to expose or introduce functional groups on drug molecules through oxidation, reduction, and hydrolysis reactions, preparing them for subsequent Phase 2 conjugation reactions that achieve water solubility and excretion.

choices.text: Both act on GABA chloride channels
Benzodiazepines increase the duration of chloride channel opening
Barbiturates are used to treat acute anxiety

questions.text: Which of the following statements about barbiturates and benzodiazepines is correct? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Both act on GABA chloride channels

 

Both barbiturates and benzodiazepines act on GABA chloride channels. This statement is correct. Both drug classes work by enhancing GABAergic neurotransmission through modulation of GABA-A receptor chloride channels.

 

Mechanism of action:

 

  • GABA-A receptors: These are ligand-gated chloride channels in the CNS
  • GABA binding: When GABA binds to its receptor, chloride channels open
  • Chloride influx: Causes hyperpolarization of neurons, leading to CNS depression
  • Drug enhancement: Both barbiturates and benzodiazepines enhance this natural process but through different mechanisms

 

Specific differences:

 

  • Benzodiazepines: Increase the frequency of chloride channel opening
  • Barbiturates: Increase both frequency and duration of chloride channel opening

 

Both mechanisms result in enhanced inhibitory neurotransmission and CNS depressant effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Flumazenil is antagonist of barbiturates: This is incorrect. Flumazenil is specifically an antagonist of benzodiazepines only. It works by competitively blocking benzodiazepine binding sites on GABA-A receptors. There is no specific antidote for barbiturate overdose - treatment is supportive care including mechanical ventilation, cardiovascular support, and enhanced elimination techniques.

 

Option C. Benzodiazepines increase the duration of chloride channel opening: This is incorrect. Benzodiazepines increase the frequency of channel opening, not duration. They make the channels open more often when GABA is present, but each opening lasts the same amount of time. Barbiturates are the ones that increase both frequency and duration of channel opening, making them more potent and dangerous.

 

Option D. Barbiturates are used to treat acute anxiety: This is incorrect. Benzodiazepines are used for acute anxiety treatment, not barbiturates. Barbiturates have largely been replaced by benzodiazepines for anxiety disorders due to barbiturates' narrow therapeutic window, high abuse potential, and dangerous interactions. Barbiturates are now primarily used for anesthesia, seizure control in specific situations, and euthanasia protocols.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Both barbiturates and benzodiazepines enhance GABA-mediated chloride channel function to produce CNS depression, but benzodiazepines are preferred for anxiety due to better safety profile, while flumazenil only reverses benzodiazepine effects, not barbiturates.

questions.text: The MRI scan below displays a classic 'Honda sign'. This radiologic finding is most characteristic of which of the following conditions? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sacral insufficiency fracture

 

The Honda Sign is a characteristic MRI finding that represents a sacral insufficiency fracture. On STIR (Short Tau Inversion Recovery) or T2-weighted sequences, this sign appears as bilateral vertical hyperintense lines running parallel through the sacral ala, connected by a horizontal hyperintense line across the upper sacral body, resembling the Honda motor company logo.

 

Sacral insufficiency fractures occur when normal stress is applied to bone with decreased elastic resistance, commonly seen in elderly patients with osteoporosis, particularly postmenopausal women. The fracture pattern typically involves the sacral ala bilaterally and may extend across the sacral body. STIR sequence is the optimal MRI sequence for detecting bone marrow edema and stress fractures as it suppresses fat signal and highlights areas of increased water content (edema).

 

The white (hyperintense) signal on STIR represents bone marrow edema at the fracture site. When this edema pattern forms the characteristic H-shaped or Honda logo appearance across the sacrum, it is pathognomonic for sacral insufficiency fracture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multiple myeloma: This would present as multiple lytic lesions throughout the skeleton rather than the specific bilateral sacral ala pattern. On MRI, myeloma typically shows diffuse bone marrow replacement with intermediate signal on T1 and variable signal on T2, but does not create the Honda sign pattern.

 

Option C. Acute osteomyelitis: While osteomyelitis can cause bone marrow edema, it typically presents as a more diffuse, irregular pattern of hyperintensity with associated soft tissue changes and enhancement. The Honda sign's specific bilateral symmetrical pattern along stress lines is not characteristic of infectious processes.

 

Option D. Bone marrow edema: Although bone marrow edema is indeed present and visible on the MRI, this is a finding rather than a diagnosis. The question asks for the underlying pathological condition causing this specific pattern of bone marrow edema, which is sacral insufficiency fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Honda Sign on MRI STIR sequence is pathognomonic for sacral insufficiency fracture, appearing as bilateral vertical hyperintense lines in the sacral ala connected by a horizontal line across the sacral body, resembling the Honda logo.

questions.text: A brain MRI reveals the characteristic 'Eye of the Tiger' sign in the globus pallidus region. This radiologic finding is most suggestive of which of the following conditions? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pantothenate kinase associated neurodegeneration

 

The Eye of the Tiger sign is a pathognomonic MRI finding seen in Pantothenate Kinase Associated Neurodegeneration (PKAN). This sign appears as bilateral hypointensity in the globus pallidus with a central area of hyperintensity on T2-weighted images, creating an appearance that resembles a tiger's eye.

 

PKAN belongs to the group of Neurodegeneration with Brain Iron Accumulation (NBIA) disorders. It was previously known as Hallervorden-Spatz disease. The condition results from mutations in the PANK2 gene, leading to abnormal iron deposition in the globus pallidus and substantia nigra. The characteristic MRI appearance occurs due to iron accumulation causing T2 hypointensity (dark signal) in the outer globus pallidus, while the central region shows hyperintensity due to gliosis and tissue rarefaction.

 

The Eye of the Tiger sign is best visualized on T2-weighted or T2* (susceptibility-weighted) sequences and is considered pathognomonic for PKAN when seen in the appropriate clinical context.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Krabbe disease: This is a lysosomal storage disorder (globoid cell leukodystrophy) that primarily affects white matter, causing demyelination. MRI shows symmetric white matter changes but does not produce the Eye of the Tiger sign in the globus pallidus.

 

Option C. Wilson disease: This condition causes copper accumulation in the brain, particularly affecting the basal ganglia. On MRI, Wilson disease typically shows hyperintensity in the basal ganglia on T2-weighted images but produces a more diffuse pattern rather than the specific Eye of the Tiger sign.

 

Option D. Huntington chorea: This neurodegenerative condition causes selective atrophy of the caudate nucleus, leading to ventricular dilatation (boxcar ventricles). The characteristic finding is caudate atrophy rather than iron deposition in the globus pallidus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Eye of the Tiger sign on T2-weighted MRI, characterized by bilateral hypointense globus pallidus with central hyperintensity, is pathognomonic for Pantothenate Kinase Associated Neurodegeneration (PKAN).

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on the radiographic findings shown below? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Follicular carcinoma

 

The X-ray shows multiple lytic lesions throughout the skull, which is characteristic of metastatic disease. Among thyroid malignancies, follicular carcinoma has the highest propensity for hematogenous spread and bone metastases.

 

Follicular carcinoma is the most vascular thyroid malignancy and preferentially spreads through the bloodstream to distant organs, particularly bones (including skull), lungs, and liver. The skull is a common site for follicular carcinoma metastases due to its rich vascular supply. These metastases typically appear as multiple, well-defined lytic (punched-out) lesions on plain radiographs.

 

Follicular carcinoma accounts for approximately 10-15% of thyroid cancers but is responsible for the majority of thyroid cancer bone metastases. The aggressive vascular invasion characteristic of this tumor type facilitates early hematogenous dissemination, making skull metastases a relatively common presentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Papillary carcinoma: This is the most common thyroid cancer but predominantly spreads via lymphatic channels to regional lymph nodes. Distant metastases, particularly to bone, are rare in papillary carcinoma. When distant spread occurs, it typically involves lungs rather than bones.

 

Option B. Hurthle cell carcinoma: While this is an aggressive variant of follicular carcinoma, it is much less common than conventional follicular carcinoma. Although it can metastasize to bones, the statistical likelihood is lower compared to follicular carcinoma.

 

Option D. Thyroid lymphoma: Primary thyroid lymphoma typically remains localized to the thyroid gland and regional lymph nodes. It rarely causes distant bone metastases and when it does spread systemically, it follows lymphatic pathways rather than causing the pattern of multiple skull lesions seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Follicular carcinoma is the most vascular thyroid malignancy with the highest propensity for hematogenous spread to bones, commonly causing multiple lytic skull metastases visible on plain X-rays.

questions.text: A child presents with seizures, and a contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) scan is obtained as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neurocysticercosis

 

The CECT shows a ring-enhancing lesion with a characteristic central hyperdense dot, which represents the scolex of the cysticercus larva. This central dot or "scolex sign" is pathognomonic for neurocysticercosis (NCC) and is the hallmark finding that distinguishes it from other ring-enhancing lesions.

 

Neurocysticercosis is the most common parasitic infection of the central nervous system, caused by the larval stage of Taenia solium. The cysticercus larva consists of a cyst wall containing the scolex (the head of the larva). On contrast-enhanced CT, the scolex appears as a central hyperdense dot within the cyst, creating the characteristic "target" or "dot-in-hole" appearance.

 

In children presenting with seizures, particularly in endemic areas, neurocysticercosis should be strongly considered when imaging shows ring-enhancing lesions with the characteristic central scolex. The seizures occur due to the inflammatory response around the degenerating cyst.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tuberculoma: While tuberculoma can also present as a ring-enhancing lesion in children with seizures, it lacks the pathognomonic central scolex. Additionally, tuberculoma would show a lipid lactate peak on MR spectroscopy, which is not mentioned in this case.

 

Option C. Brain abscess: Brain abscesses typically present as large lesions with thick, irregular peripheral enhancement and significant surrounding edema. They lack the characteristic central scolex and usually have a more aggressive clinical presentation with systemic signs of infection.

 

Option D. Cerebral Metastasis: Metastatic lesions in children are extremely rare, and when they occur, they typically present as multiple lesions rather than a single ring-enhancing lesion. Moreover, they would not show the characteristic central scolex pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The central hyperdense dot (scolex sign) within a ring-enhancing lesion on CECT is pathognomonic for neurocysticercosis and distinguishes it from other causes of ring-enhancing brain lesions.

questions.text: A male patient presents with an 8-month history of chronic diarrhea. Based on the CT findings shown below, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ulcerative colitis

 

The CT shows the characteristic "lead pipe colon" appearance, which is pathognomonic for ulcerative colitis. This sign is characterized by complete loss of haustrations (ahaustral appearance) giving the colon a smooth, tubular appearance resembling a lead pipe.

 

In ulcerative colitis, chronic inflammation leads to muscular hypertrophy and fibrosis of the colonic wall, resulting in loss of the normal haustral pattern. The disease typically affects the rectum and extends proximally in a continuous fashion. The lead pipe appearance represents the end-stage changes of chronic ulcerative colitis with mucosal atrophy and wall fibrosis.

 

The clinical presentation of chronic diarrhea for 8 months is consistent with ulcerative colitis, which typically presents with bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, and tenesmus. The continuous involvement pattern and characteristic imaging findings make this diagnosis most likely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tubercular colitis: Tuberculosis typically affects the ileocecal junction and presents with a "pulled-up cecum" sign due to fibrosis and contracture. The imaging would show thickening and narrowing at the IC junction rather than the diffuse ahaustral pattern seen in this case.

 

Option C. Crohn's disease: Crohn's disease predominantly affects the terminal ileum and shows a "string sign" due to severe narrowing and ulceration of the ileal lumen. It causes segmental, discontinuous involvement (skip lesions) rather than the continuous colonic changes seen here.

 

Option D. Pseudomembranous enterocolitis: This condition, typically caused by C. difficile infection, shows the "accordion sign" on CT due to severe mucosal and submucosal edema causing marked wall thickening. The colon appears like an accordion with alternating bands of density, which is distinctly different from the smooth lead pipe appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "lead pipe colon" sign on CT, characterized by complete loss of haustrations giving a smooth tubular appearance, is pathognomonic for chronic ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: What is the most useful investigation for localizing a parathyroid adenoma? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sestamibi scan

 

Sestamibi scan (Technetium-99m sestamibi scintigraphy) is the most useful investigation for localization of parathyroid adenomas. 

 

`SPECT (Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography) sestamibi is preferred over planar sestamibi imaging because it provides superior 3D localization capabilities.

 

The principle behind sestamibi scanning is that parathyroid adenomas have increased mitochondrial content and enhanced blood supply, leading to preferential uptake and retention of the radiotracer. The scan is typically performed as a dual-phase study - early images show uptake in both thyroid and parathyroid tissue, while delayed images (2-3 hours later) show washout from normal thyroid tissue but persistent retention in hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue.

 

SPECT imaging provides cross-sectional views that significantly improve localization accuracy compared to planar imaging, making it particularly valuable for detecting ectopic parathyroid adenomas and for preoperative planning. Currently, 4D CT (dynamic contrast-enhanced CT) is also emerging as an excellent modality for parathyroid adenoma localization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. USG: While ultrasound can detect parathyroid adenomas, especially those located near the thyroid gland, it has limited sensitivity for ectopic locations and deeper adenomas. It is operator-dependent and cannot reliably distinguish between thyroid nodules and parathyroid adenomas in all cases.

 

Option C. FDG PET: FDG PET is not the first-line investigation for parathyroid adenomas. Parathyroid tissue typically shows low FDG uptake, making this modality less useful for routine parathyroid imaging compared to sestamibi.

 

Option D. MRI: MRI can visualize parathyroid adenomas but lacks the functional information provided by sestamibi scanning. It cannot distinguish between hyperfunctioning and non-functioning parathyroid tissue, which is crucial for surgical planning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SPECT sestamibi scan is the most useful investigation for parathyroid adenoma localization due to its superior 3D localization capabilities and functional assessment of hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with colicky pain and is suspected to have a ureteric stone. Which of the following is the best diagnostic investigation for this case? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) NCCT KUB

 

NCCT KUB (Non-contrast CT of Kidneys, Ureters, and Bladder) is the investigation of choice for diagnosing ureteric stones. It has extremely high sensitivity and specificity for detecting urinary tract calculi and can identify virtually all types of stones regardless of their composition.

 

The major advantage of NCCT is that nearly all urinary stones are radiopaque on CT imaging. The only exception is indinavir stones (a protease inhibitor medication), which remain radiolucent even on CT. All other stones including uric acid, cystine, xanthine, and struvite stones that may be radiolucent on plain X-rays are clearly visible on CT due to their higher density compared to surrounding soft tissues.

 

NCCT also provides additional valuable information including exact stone location, size, degree of obstruction, presence of hydronephrosis, and can identify alternative diagnoses if no stone is present. It can detect stones throughout the entire urinary tract from the renal pelvis to the bladder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. USG KUB: While ultrasound is often used as the initial investigation and is readily available, it has significant limitations for ureteric stone detection. The ureter is a retroperitoneal structure that is difficult to visualize completely on ultrasound. USG can miss ureteric stones, particularly those in the mid-ureter, and cannot provide accurate size assessment or detect all stone compositions.

 

Option C. CECT KUB: Contrast-enhanced CT is not required for stone detection and may actually obscure small stones due to the contrast material. Additionally, it involves unnecessary radiation exposure and contrast-related risks without providing additional diagnostic benefit over NCCT.

 

Option D. Ureteroscopy: This is an invasive therapeutic procedure used for stone removal or fragmentation, not for initial diagnosis. Ureteroscopy should only be performed after confirming the presence and location of the stone through non-invasive imaging. It carries procedural risks and is not appropriate as a diagnostic investigation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NCCT KUB is the investigation of choice for ureteric stones because all stones except indinavir are radiopaque on CT, providing excellent sensitivity and specificity for stone detection.

questions.text: Which diagnostic investigation is depicted in the image below? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) X-ray Defecography

 

The image shows X-ray defecography, which is a functional imaging study used to evaluate anorectal function and pelvic floor disorders. The investigation involves introduction of barium contrast into the rectum, and the patient is asked to evacuate while lateral X-ray images are taken.

 

The key identifying features are: 

 

(1) Plain X-ray technique visible in the background, 

(2) Barium contrast outlining the rectum and anal canal, 

(3) Lateral projection showing the anorectal anatomy. 

 

This investigation is used to diagnose conditions like rectal prolapse, rectocele, anismus, and other defecatory disorders.

 

X-ray defecography provides dynamic functional information about the evacuation process and can identify structural abnormalities during straining and defecation that may not be apparent on static imaging studies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MR Defecography: While MR defecography exists and provides excellent soft tissue resolution, the image clearly shows a plain X-ray technique rather than MRI. MR defecography would show high-resolution soft tissue details without the characteristic appearance of plain radiography.

 

Option C. Barium Swallow: This investigation evaluates the esophagus after oral administration of barium contrast. The anatomy shown is clearly the rectum and lower pelvis, not the thoracic esophagus, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Barium meal follow through: This study traces the entire gastrointestinal tract from stomach to small bowel after oral barium administration. The image shows rectal contrast administration and rectal anatomy, not the small bowel loops that would be seen in a follow-through study.

 

Educational Objective:

 

X-ray defecography is identified by barium contrast in the rectum on lateral X-ray projection, used for functional evaluation of anorectal disorders and pelvic floor dysfunction.

questions.text: Which of the following modalities is contraindicated in pregnancy? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CT

 

CT (Computed Tomography) is contraindicated in pregnancy because it uses ionizing radiation, which can be harmful to the developing fetus. Ionizing radiation exposure during pregnancy can lead to teratogenic effects, growth retardation, and increased risk of childhood malignancies, particularly during organogenesis in the first trimester.

 

CT scans deliver relatively high radiation doses compared to plain X-rays due to multiple exposures from different angles and the use of high-energy X-ray beams. The radiation dose from a typical abdominal or pelvic CT can range from 10-25 mGy, which significantly exceeds the recommended safety limits for pregnancy.

 

The general principle in radiology is to avoid any imaging modality that uses ionizing radiation during pregnancy unless there is a life-threatening emergency where the benefits clearly outweigh the risks. Alternative imaging modalities that do not use radiation should be preferred whenever possible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. USG: Ultrasound is completely safe in pregnancy as it uses sound waves rather than ionizing radiation. It is the primary imaging modality for monitoring fetal development and diagnosing pregnancy-related complications. There are no known harmful effects of diagnostic ultrasound on the fetus.

 

Option B. MRI: MRI is safe in pregnancy as it uses magnetic fields and radiofrequency waves without ionizing radiation. While some guidelines recommend avoiding MRI in the first trimester as a precautionary measure, it is generally considered safe throughout pregnancy when clinically indicated and is often used when ultrasound is insufficient.

 

Option D. Doppler: Doppler ultrasound is a specialized form of ultrasound that evaluates blood flow. Like conventional ultrasound, it uses sound waves and is completely safe in pregnancy. It is routinely used to assess fetal blood flow, umbilical artery flow, and maternal vascular conditions during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CT is contraindicated in pregnancy due to ionizing radiation exposure, while USG, MRI, and Doppler are safe imaging modalities that do not use ionizing radiation.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old man presents with complaints of decreased libido and infertility. Based on this clinical picture and understanding of hypogonadism in males, which of the following statements are accurate? (INICET MAY 2025)

 

  1. Kallmann syndrome is categorized under primary hypogonadism.
  2. In secondary hypogonadism, serum LH and FSH are typically low or inappropriately normal.
  3. Decreased LH and FSH in the setting of low testosterone suggest primary testicular failure.
  4. Clinical features of hypogonadism can include loss of libido and infertility.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 4

 

Statement 2 is correct: Secondary (central) hypogonadism results from hypothalamic or pituitary dysfunction. Hence, LH and FSH are either low or inappropriately normal due to deficient GnRH or pituitary hormone release.

 

Statement 4 is correct: Common symptoms of male hypogonadism include decreased libido, erectile dysfunction, reduced facial/body hair, fatigue, and infertility.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 1 is Incorrect: Kallmann syndrome is a form of secondary hypogonadism, not primary. It involves GnRH deficiency and is associated with anosmia.

 

Statement 3 is Incorrect: In primary hypogonadism (testicular failure), testosterone is low but LH/FSH are elevated due to loss of negative feedback.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Primary hypogonadism: Low testosterone + high LH/FSH (testicular failure).
  • Secondary hypogonadism: Low testosterone + low/inappropriately normal LH/FSH (hypothalamic or pituitary failure, e.g., Kallmann).
  • Clinical presentation includes decreased libido, infertility, and impaired secondary sexual characteristics.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl presents with developmental delay, facial dysmorphism, and multiple congenital anomalies. Her pediatric geneticist suspects a syndrome involving multiple potential point mutations across various genes. Which of the following is the most appropriate genetic test to comprehensively evaluate this patientâ€™s condition? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Exome sequencing

 

Exome sequencing (also known as whole-exome sequencing) targets the protein-coding regions of the genome, which comprise ~1â€“2% of the entire genome but account for ~85% of known disease-causing mutations. It is particularly useful when:

 

  • The diagnosis is unclear and may involve multiple possible genes.
  • There are multiple mutations across different sites suspected.
  • A broad, unbiased genetic screening is needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sanger sequencing: This is ideal for identifying known point mutations in a single specific gene, but it is inefficient and costly for screening multiple genes or mutations.

 

Option C. Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism (RFLP): Used historically for specific known mutations, this technique lacks the sensitivity and breadth required for modern multigene analyses.

 

Option D. Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization (FISH): FISH detects large chromosomal abnormalities (like deletions, duplications, and translocations), not point mutations or sequence-level changes across exons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exome sequencing is the preferred genetic test when evaluating a patient with an undiagnosed condition that may involve multiple mutations across different exons or genes. It provides broad coverage of clinically relevant coding regions, making it superior to more targeted or structural tests in such cases.

choices.text: Surface plasmon resonance â€“ binding affinity
Western blot â€“ protein size and abundance

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the technique shown and the parameter it most directly assesses? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Surface plasmon resonance â€“ binding affinity

 

  • Surface Plasmon Resonance (SPR) is a real-time, label-free method used to analyze biomolecular interactions.
  • In the setup shown, changes in the angle of light reflected from a metal surface occur when analytes (e.g., antibodies) bind to immobilized ligands.
  • This change correlates with the binding kinetics and affinity of the interaction, providing precise information about how strongly molecules interact (e.g., antibody-antigen).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Competitive ELISA â€“ antigen concentration: Competitive ELISA measures concentration, but it uses labeled antigens/antibodies, not a label-free real-time detection.

 

Option B. Radioimmunoassay â€“ antigen-antibody complex formation: Radioimmunoassay involves radioactive labels and measures concentration, not affinity.

 

Option D. Western blot â€“ protein size and abundance: Western blot assesses the presence and size of proteins via electrophoresis and labeled antibodies, not interaction kinetics or binding affinity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Surface Plasmon Resonance (SPR) is a real-time, label-free technique used to study the affinity and kinetics of biomolecular interactions like analyzing antibody-antigen binding strength.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most frequently diagnosed pituitary neoplasm in routine clinical settings? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nonfunctioning pituitary adenoma

 

Nonfunctioning pituitary adenomas (NFPAs) are the most common pituitary tumors encountered in clinical practice. They do not secrete biologically active hormones, hence they often present late, usually due to mass effect symptoms such as headaches or visual field disturbances (e.g., bitemporal hemianopsia). Hormonal workup in these patients is typically normal or may show mild pituitary insufficiency due to compression of surrounding pituitary tissue.

 

Since these tumors do not produce clinical syndromes like galactorrhea, acromegaly, or Cushingâ€™s disease, they are frequently diagnosed incidentally on imaging or investigated when compressive symptoms occur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prolactin-secreting pituitary adenoma: Also known as prolactinomas, these are very common but less frequently diagnosed than NFPAs when all pituitary neoplasms are considered, especially in asymptomatic individuals. They commonly present with galactorrhea, amenorrhea, or infertility.

 

Option B. ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma: These cause Cushingâ€™s disease and present with classical features like weight gain, moon facies, and striae. They are relatively rare compared to nonfunctioning adenomas.

 

Option C. Growth hormoneâ€“secreting pituitary adenoma: These lead to acromegaly (in adults) or gigantism (in children), both of which have distinct clinical findings. They are far less common than nonfunctioning adenomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nonfunctioning pituitary adenomas are the most frequently diagnosed pituitary tumors in routine clinical practice, often discovered due to mass effect symptoms or incidentally on imaging.

choices.text: A lumbar puncture is indicated when subarachnoid hemorrhage is suspected and CT is inconclusive.
LP can be safely performed if platelet count is above 10,000/mmÂ³.
Meningitis is a rare but documented complication of lumbar puncture.
Postâ€“lumbar puncture headache is more likely in younger female patients.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the indications or complications of lumbar puncture is inaccurate? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) LP can be safely performed if platelet count is above 10,000/mmÂ³.

 

LP can be safely performed if platelet count is above 10,000/mmÂ³. False. LP is contraindicated in severe thrombocytopenia due to the risk of spinal hematoma. A safe minimum threshold is typically >40,000â€“50,000/mmÂ³, not just 10,000.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A lumbar puncture is indicated when subarachnoid hemorrhage is suspected and CT is inconclusive: True. LP is urgently indicated to detect xanthochromia and red blood cells in CSF when CT does not reveal subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), especially if clinical suspicion remains high.

 

Option C. Meningitis is a rare but documented complication of lumbar puncture: True. Meningitis is a rare complication and usually results from poor aseptic technique. It's considered unusual, especially when sterile procedures are followed.

 

Option D. Postâ€“lumbar puncture headache is more likely in younger female patients: True. Postâ€“LP headache is more common in young females, particularly in those with a prior history of headaches, and not in the elderly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lumbar puncture is an important diagnostic tool but must be performed with proper indications and safety thresholdsâ€”platelet count should be >40,000/mmÂ³. Post-LP headache is more likely in young women, and meningitis is a rare complication with proper technique.

choices.text: The total number of chromosomes in an individual
The variety of alleles within a specific population
The genes shared among members of a nuclear family
The combination of maternal and paternal genes in a zygote

questions.text: In the context of genetics, the term "gene pool" most accurately refers to which of the following? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The variety of alleles within a specific population

 

The gene pool is defined as the complete collection of alleles for all genes present in a reproductive population. It includes all the genetic variation that can be passed on to the next generation and serves as the foundation for evolutionary processes such as natural selection, genetic drift, and gene flow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The total number of chromosomes in an individual: This describes a karyotype, not a gene pool. An individual's chromosomes do not represent the full genetic diversity of a population.

 

Option C. The genes shared among members of a nuclear family: This pertains to pedigree analysis or familial inheritance but does not account for broader allele variation across a population.

 

Option D. The combination of maternal and paternal genes in a zygote: This represents the genome of an individual, not the collective gene set within a population.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The gene pool is a concept used in population genetics to describe the total range of alleles available in a population. Understanding the gene pool is essential for studying genetic variation, evolution, and natural selection.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with a painful breast lump and purulent discharge. Histopathology reveals a granulomatous inflammatory response predominantly involving neutrophils. Culture of the lesion identifies a Gram-positive bacillus. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this presentation? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Corynebacterium kroppenstedtii

 

  • Corynebacterium kroppenstedtii is increasingly recognized as a cause of neutrophilic granulomatous mastitis, particularly in non-lactating women.
  • It is a lipophilic Gram-positive bacillus often missed on routine cultures, but now linked with chronic mastitis presenting with abscess formation and granulomatous inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Corynebacterium minutissimum: Causes erythrasma, a superficial skin infection. It is not associated with granulomatous mastitis.

 

Option C. Mycobacterium tuberculosis: Can cause granulomatous mastitis, but the infiltrate is lymphocyte-rich, not predominantly neutrophilic.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus aureus: Common cause of acute mastitis or abscesses, but not granulomatous in nature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Always consider Corynebacterium kroppenstedtii in chronic granulomatous mastitis with neutrophilic infiltrates, especially when cultures are initially negative. Lipid-rich medium may be required for growth.

choices.text: The organism only becomes pathogenic in the presence of bile reflux
Most strains of H. pylori lack virulence factors such as CagA and VacA
Gastric mucosa becomes immune to colonization in healthy individuals
The infection remains localized to the duodenum in asymptomatic patients

questions.text: A 42-year-old man undergoes upper GI endoscopy for evaluation of persistent dyspepsia. Biopsy reveals Helicobacter pylori colonization of the gastric antrum, but no ulceration was observed. Which of the following best explains why H. pylori infection does not always lead to ulcer formation? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Most strains of H. pylori lack virulence factors such as CagA and VacA

 

  • H. pylori is a common gastric pathogen, but not all infected individuals develop ulcers.
  • Virulence factors like CagA (cytotoxin-associated gene A) and VacA (vacuolating cytotoxin A) are responsible for more severe inflammation and mucosal damage.
  • Host genetics, immune response, NSAID co-use, and environmental factors (e.g., smoking) also influence disease progression.
  • Many H. pylori infections remain asymptomatic, particularly when colonization is by less virulent strains.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The organism only becomes pathogenic in the presence of bile reflux: Bile reflux is not a necessary co-factor for H. pylori pathogenicity.

 

Option C. Gastric mucosa becomes immune to colonization in healthy individuals: Healthy mucosa may be colonized; mucosal immunity is not absolute.

 

Option D. The infection remains localized to the duodenum in asymptomatic patients: H. pylori primarily colonizes the gastric antrum, not the duodenum directly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ulcer development in H. pylori infection is multifactorialâ€”depending on bacterial virulence, host susceptibility, and environmental co-factors. The presence of H. pylori alone does not predict ulcer risk.
